It would be tempting to call Sam Raimi's Drag Me to Hell a budding cult classic, except its profitability and popularity may eclipse cult status.
Departures is a film steeped in warmth, tenderness and genuine conflict.
Very funny.
I never know quite what they were saying about heroism and then there are all these unanswered questions.
As much as there is to admire about Soderbergh, his indifference to time sequencing hurts the story here.
I think you should see Summer Hours.
This is a family comedy that will entertain the kids and amuse the grown-ups. It's also a rare Hollywood sequel that's better than the original.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: You know precisely where it's headed and how it will get there halfway into Act One.
This is the worst big budget summer release I've seen in some time.
Funny, but ordinary.
An amusing tail of incompetent criminals.
We're left to wonder, who in the Vatican can really be trusted? And also, will Ron Howard continue to make movies about a character who comes alive on the page, but sputters on the big screen?
From the start, it's clear there's a riddle to solve...I'm just not sure you'll care about the solution.
I'd say Love 'n Dancing felt like an after-school special about overcoming disabilities and being the best you can be, but I fear I'd be doing a disservice to after school specials.
It was funny, it was sweet, it was warm but it never felt hacky or maudlin.
Ultimately the second half completely undermined the first half.
Rian Johnson's clever, impressively shot film [features] outstanding work from [its] three leading actors.
I think you should go ahead and rent the movie.
We have A Very Murray Christmas, and at the very least there are certainly worse ways to spend 56 minutes on a wint'ry December evening than watching it.
Like oral surgery without laughing gas, the latest family film to star former wrestler Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson is an annoying pain we could all do without.
Gibson remains as rough and tough as ever, yet his older figure and stern demeanour provide a personable core to what could have spiralled out into a violence frenzy or incomprehensible whodunit.

How locations, production design, editing choices and shot compositions partner with Ryan's "journey to self" is masterful, as is Reitman's inclusion of real people who speak directly to camera about being retrenched.
The absurd pandemonium of the finale's confessions stretches to breaking point but befits a unique musical oddball that will prove strangely affecting to those swept up in it.
Nine is bold enough to embrace Fellini's self-defeating smirk about movies being "dead" as soon as they leave their creator's mind.
A bleak, depressing odyssey you can firmly admire and marvel at, even as it rips your heart out.
A welcome departure from the usual type of Frenchy fare we receive, here be a hip, acne-tastic lesson about teens and their hot pants.
Jeff Bridges' consuming, complete performance ranks among the finest works of his considerable career.
Valentine's Day is like a box of fancy chocolates from a secret admirer. Intentions may be genuine, but knowing nothing about the other party kills off meaning or a reason to care.

Whether audiences will get behind The Lightning Thief is hard to predict. Overall, it's an entertaining introduction to a promising new world -- but will the consuming shadow of Potter be too big to break free of?
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: With politics and philosophy largely absent from James's tour of extreme duty, it settles into a somewhat comforting pattern of danger and mild relief, which can diffuse the knots in your stomach.
While Scorsese overcooks the final stages of explanation and recollecting critical events, it doesn't alter how grand a job he has done of covering tracks. Excellent.

Despite massive production troubles including key personnel changes, elaborate CGI and substantial reshoots, this long-delayed update of a classic 1940s monster movie finally hits screens with an exuberant roar.
Damon transforms better than many of his A-list peers, and his Mark makeover is the reason to see The Informant!
The woeful shell of a romantic comedy, a motionless movie which shows no attempt to do anything but point a camera at shapely Aniston.
Such an overtly dramatic movie always runs the risk of being overrated and Precious isn't the life-changing outing it has been declared to be. But it's also very difficult to shake off.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Kelly's most accessible ambiguous odyssey to date, The Box dares you to open it up again and again.
Austere treatment of a terribly personal WWII tragedy keeps this Polish elegy at arm's length.
A smart, snappy upgrade doesn't tarnish memories of a childhood favourite.
Dragon burns to satisfy a broad audience with a searing blend of rollercoaster action, winning comedy and actual emotion.
Hardly a massive gamble, Cameron Diaz and Ashton Kutcher play a safe romcom hand you can tolerate.
Character depth and stirring subtext is what books are for. Adamson's Narnia adaptations remove all that pesky claptrap so that we can glide through a superficial reading.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Another disappointment from M, despite some disturbing violence and chilly moments.
More action, less poncing, than that last Hulk movie ensures a stronger response.
If only the Zohan hadn't messed with us. Worse than his excruciating Chuck And Larry, Sandler seems determined to refine the unfunny comedy. Please, Mr Sandler, stop it. Please. It hurts.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Leonardo DiCaprio and Russell Crowe fire up Ridley Scott's terrific political thriller, which might finally drag audiences to a flick about the War On Terror.
The collision of styles and genre ideas runs along a familiar road, losing control when the paint job can't disguise what's under the bonnet.
Malkovich's unabashed performance drives a fierce fable which seems intent on forcing viewers away.
Cooler than you'll ever be, and more irritating, Jarmusch's star-infused indie overload strives to divide audiences. Mission accomplished.
Lee's sizeable re-creation of the planet's greatest music festival is a sanitised trip.
Getting past the passages of forced teen coolness, this likable sci-fi romp brings some PG-tastic fun.
Two chewed thumbs up.
Harold And Kumar Go To Kalgoorlie? A cruisey comedy you'll like to like, even when the buzz flickers.
Not going to live forever. Not going to light up the sky like a flame.

To avoid paying for a holiday to hell, don't see Couples Retreat. A prime contender for 2009's Worst Film, this star-studded but startlingly drab "comedy" is the kind of terrible trip you pray will be over long before it's time to go home.
A fun-tastic adventure that virtually guarantees enjoyment for the whole family.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Micmacs is Jeunet in every way -- except the daffy if slim story of Bazil (French comedy king Dany Boon) isn't as rich or memorable as past Jeunet efforts.
Watts and Penn work their magic, as Liman avoids Bush bashing, to present well argued and personable "intel".
This handsome, well-tuned adaptation of Jay Parini's Tolstoy biography avoids being a dour subtitled slog by its strong casting, layered contrasts of love and duty, and admirable air of enthusiasm.
Glum, grey portrait of an unhappy life.
Looks like a Merchant Ivory movie. Bores like a lesser one, too.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A spirited and visually resplendent fantasy adventure that is let down by it's youthful cast.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Entertaining, spirited mystery which mercifully avoids the grisly path, but loses its way in simplified sermons.
Virtually guarenteed to make your blood boil, debut documentariab Fox's remarkably likeable investigation pours forth a persuasive call-to-arms.
With the calendar almost closed, the best mature drama of 2010 arrives. Firth and Rush are majestic, as is Hooper's handling of touching history.
Not first-date material, this sombre portrait of failed dreams is buoyed by excellent leads and a yearning heart.
Takes an unpopular group - upper management! - and humanises their involvement in screwing the world. Quite the achievement, really.
A film about people discussing people, which attempts to do something different? Believe it - or not.
A solid historical drama that carries a few too many political messages.
Apart from a middle section which reveals moments of clarity and actual emotion, this is a bloated, self-indulgent bore of fine imagery.

Cinemas, quake in fear! Michael Bay has conceived yet another screen-smashing spectacle which sets the bar even higher for what blockbuster action can provide. Ignore all the annoying cliches and stupid bits - and just get some big-budget exhiliration.
Highly unusual drama - with black comedy elements - which allows Duvall to showcase his refined skills.
It's almost impossible to describe how distressing, intense and finely crafted this undeniably controversial drama is. Proceed with caution.
Thompson's poise and charm always keep her supernanny away from being a poor Poppins clone.

The time is right for the return of Gordon Gekko, but making him a sidekick in a convoluted revenge plot, loaded with GFC history and allusions, stifles his totemic comeback. Less might well have been more, Mr Stone.
This tragic effort at a homegrown comedy delivers second hand laughs.
Trying to turn bad into good-bad results in wonky entertainment.
Foot tapping fun that makes the most of the third dimension.
Humorous, charming and quaint, I Love You Too has the goods to earn more than just patriotic affection.
Iron Man 2 injects more heroes and villains without losing sight of what made its predecessor a surprise smash hit in 2008.
As a whole, this movie is a mediocre postcard you keep hoping will become the enthralling slide show it thinks it is.
Learning what made Hood is well and good, but couldn't that have taken 30 minutes, with the rest of the movie being about a wanted philanthropic criminal?
Fully sick -- only if you are a Wog Boy fan. Yes, we do blame you.
This tragic effort at a homegrown comedy delivers second hand laughs.

This presentation of two artists pursuing passion without concern for social or marital rules becomes a well-groomed melodrama that deflates interest by closely guarding the feelings of those involved.
Prince of Persia largely avoids action blasts and trudges through dull episodes. Not exactly a princely start to an aspiring franchise.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Where's the excitement, thrills and dizzying nonsense promised by its rockin' trailers?
All in all, it's not the spectacular send-off Shrek deserves but, as a way to get out, it's not too shabby either.
It must try all manner of bizarre/obscene/silly things to sustain itself beyond stating the obvious about celebrity excess.
Well worth the wait, Rocket Science is a winning coming of age comedy with a difference.
The pain of goodbye is beautifully balanced by the trademark excellence of the Toy Story series. A fantastic way to go out.

The new Karate Kid runs with the original's underdog structure, mixed with on-screen fights and words of wisdom, but major changes rip the heart out of what was a touching coming-of-age journey anyone could relate to.
If you have a problem and no one else can help, you must see The A-Team. Action excellence guaranteed.
Washington is always watchable and will hold your gaze during a highly ambitious but ultimately wonky attempt to inject spiritual depth into the blockbuster flock.
Pusher is an exciting, visceral and utterly compelling film!
On the whole it's an enjoyable film, and a big step up from some of the muddled, self-important sci-fi flicks that have come out this year. Definitely worth a watch.
Shell is an excellent film with some truly fantastic performances.

It's perfectly enjoyable and worth watching for Urban, Thirlby and Headey if nothing else. It does however, lack the conviction, originality and sadly the budget that would take this from being a good movie to an excellent one.
One of the most ambitious and interesting movies of the last few years.
All in, The Wolverine is a refreshingly good entry in the X-Men franchise that completely wipes out the nasty taste Origins: Wolverine left.
It may not quite live up to the standards of its predecessor, but it far exceeds its source material.
Sharp, original and exceptionally funny without sacrificing emotional engagement for cheap laughs, Warm Bodies is a substantial step above most zombie films.
Five Foot Two is an entertaining and humanising documentary for this artist who started her career with a kind of alien appeal. But it's also a carefully calculated film...
Maintains a white-knuckled momentum throughout its admittedly brief runtime.
movie_title: The Corpse Of Anna Fritz (El Cad√°ver De Anna Fritz) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's the intimacy of even the most gargantuan conflict that hits home in Kurosawa's masterful hands.
It is admittedly another entry into the hip New York twenty-something subgenre. It is also, however, a frank and very funny debut from an interesting new talent.
The return to that galaxy far, far away that audiences have longed for.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Deadpool brandishes its meta-credentials with the title character's cocky, abrasive relish.
Ostensibly a saucy, knockabout swimming pool romp, it develops into a surreal dive into the waters of destructive sexuality.
Striking a balance between the dark and combative religious humour and its more saccharine elements proves difficult.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [It] soars, not least during its incredibly taut bad-weather flights which pound with the slow thudding tension akin to the depth-charges of Wolfgang Petersen's Das Boot.

There was a horrible inevitability to the fact that Anthony Weiner's career in the US Congress would end in sexual scandal, but watching him try to rejuvenate his flagging fortunes amidst a modern media circus is fascinating.
Hugely entertaining, if not Lloyd at the peak of his powers.
Ilo Ilo is an affectionate and poignant - if slight - slice of family life.
This haunting and esoteric work manages to seduce and repulse in uncanny harmony.
There are no answers here, as there were not in Bowles original story, but there are fascinating questions about the paths we travel and the tracks we leave behind.
movie_title: The Sky Trembles and the Earth Is Afraid and the Two Eyes Are Not Brothers (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Nasty, nerve-wracking and not for the squeamish.
For much of its run time Bang Gang manages to be an engaging treatment of teenage relationships -- it just doesn't know how to see it through.
Easily the most incoherent and irrelevant of Bryan Singer's X-Men movies.
A bewitching cinematic collage.
A masterful adaptation of a master by a master.
If you can tune in to its broadcast frequency, Midnight Special will shine its light on you.
Wedding Doll may be a small film, but it's deftly executed and built on two remarkable leading performances.
There is meaning beneath the madness, but Men & Chicken is best recommended to those who are prepared to sit through the deeply sinister absurdity.
A film full of worthy, valid points that are threatened to be lost amidst Moore's trademark style.
Stewart traps the duo in tight two-shots, heightening the claustrophobia and emphasising the regime's moral redundancy in distorting visuals.
The prospect of crafting a worthy successor to the phenomenal The Act of Killing is a daunting one, but Joshua Oppenheimer has risen to the challenge.
A beguiling and impressionistic coming-of-age sketch, it trades on atmosphere and intimacy.
The final film by the legendary documentarian Albert Maysles, Iris is a warm and sincere portrait of a woman who is irresistibly great company.
The Mars landscapes are stunningly rendered, but The Martian is Matt Damon's show.
A breakneck Aaron Sorkin script combined with a subtle, confident performance from Fassbender results in a meticulously constructed character study.
Like a super-powered heist movie, mixing fantastic invention with a tried, tested and all-too-familiar formula.
Subversive yet heartwarming - it's a joy to watch.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Out-of-focus ideas don't hamstring what is still an interesting companion to the original work.
Charlie Kaufman's first foray into stop-motion animation is a typically existential and deeply moving affair.
Even when The Waiting Room seems not to be saying anything, Jasmin expresses so much -- in expressing so little -- as to utterly beguile.
This is a brilliantly contained and sublimely ridiculous send-up of competitive male egos from a refreshing female perspective.
[A] candid and absorbing documentary.
A bombastic and incoherent world overflowing with half-baked allegory, baffling characterisation and back-breaking mythological portent. It's a laudably bold, utterly exhausting, mess of a film.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The deft and highly emotive handling of his condition and the wider ramifications of [Gen's] story make The Dark Horse a lot more than merely the against-the-odds chess story that it may initially appear to be.
There's no doubt that the people that Fox singles out are worthy of his camera's attention, but it doesn't equate to a coherent feature film as much as an enormously wasted opportunity.
movie_title: How to Let Go of the World and Love All the Things Climate Can't Change (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The POV gimmickry of Ilya Naishuller's debut quickly wears thin.
his will hardly put off Hong's hordes of acolytes -- for this is a thematically interesting work -- but Right Now, Wrong Then is perhaps best enjoyed by fans.
A fully-fledged horror complete with all manner of squeamish moments.
Both a humane character study and issue-driven polemic.
A knotty, funny, ambiguous character study with an exceptional turn from Rebecca Hall.
Wise beyond her years, [Nika, played by Bronislawa Zamachowska] has a curt, verging on antagonistic relationship with her old man, but she's a ray of light in an otherwise grave endeavour.
[Salt and Fire] is littered with preposterous musings and every line intentionally overwritten to surreal effect.
Tribute is paid to Pablo Neruda's memory by mixing an exquisite and irreverent cocktail of his passions: poetry, politics and pulp.
The land is glorious and forbidding and the soundtrack's howling winds whip up and exacerbate the feeling of isolation, but onwards they plod.
That is Kieslowski's underlying point; that each death is a morally repugnant as the other -- and A Short Film About Killing tackles that subject with gloomy poetry and undeniable power.
Suwichakornpong confidently defies conventional forms and linearity. She collapses the past into the present as a way to probe the haunted recesses of both national and personal memory.
movie_title: By the Time It Gets Dark (Dao khanong) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a film swimming in symbolism, transgressive eroticism and perplexing details that will infuriate some audiences but for others will add to its irresistible allure.
There's ample complexity and nuance written into these issues and characters, but it only intermittently coalesces to truly satisfying ends.
It's just a shame that despite some funny moments, Pitch Perfect 3 isn't quite the same quality of material as before, meaning the Bellas close on something of a bum note.
The characters are not unfeeling automatons, but the almost Brechtian removal of sentimental cues makes the observations about our baser instincts all the more confrontational.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are no set pieces here, which there could well have been. The director is not tempted to employ familiar techniques of shooting or representing this events usually confined to horror movies.
Poitras places her unreliability on centre stage, and in doing so, makes sure that we're acutely aware of how she - and indeed Julian Assange - want us to digest each frame of Risk.
This is a film portraying patriarchal misogyny, not condoning it. However, Verhoeven has no interest in delivering his biting critiques in easily digestible pieces.
The visuals echo the sensation of running your hand over a surface, giving Aquarius a completely apposite tactile quality that Dona Clara would cherish.
There's perhaps little of Free Fire that will linger too long in the memory after the credits roll, but there's still fun to be had.
It's impossible not to be sucked into Akerman's final film.
It's as a scrupulous whole that Spotlight truly shines as one of the year's finest and most compelling dramas.
Its title may refer to an undeniably physical barrier but Tadhg O'Sullivan's The Great Wall... opts for a more transmutable definition of no more permeable boundaries.
La La Land is finely cut, A-grade nostalgia that proves nigh-on-impossible to resist.

[Morris'] film makes for a fittingly positive monument to [Dorfman's] often overlooked and under-appreciated work, but this intimate conversation and reflection also allows him to also do so much more.
movie_title: The B-Side: Elsa Dorfman's Portrait Photography (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Even when little of substance seems to be happening, the narrative feels propulsive.
The most damning indictment of Suicide Squad is that it's unrelentingly bland.
"It's unlikely you're going to come across too many documentaries this year with a yarn to spin as tangled and twisted as Tickled."
Yet another contradiction at the heart of the fascinating and stimulating Kate Plays Christine: it speaks her name whilst wishing she'd been left to rest.
Even as she challenges accepted mythologies, she crafts her own both warning against nostalgia and passionately arguing for it; both being seduced and seducing at once.
The Cinema Travellers acts as both paean and elegy for this declining but inherently charming mode of exhibition.

Hansen-L√∏ve's unobtrusive and novelistic approach doesn't see Nathalie embark on a spiral of loneliness or an arc of self-discovery, but a tide of breakthroughs and setbacks punctuated by grace and grief.
While Into the Inferno is not Herzog's tightest work, it offers no fewer riches.
Stewart is exceptional in the lead role, her awkwardness a product a woman looking for meaning, whether in a haunted house or through the ping of a new SMS message.
An agonising procedural that records the slow death-rattle in a mordant and stifling chamber piece.
movie_title: The Death of Louis XIV (La mort de Louis XIV) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Gut-wrenchingly powerful, not least through its chilling and upsetting climax.
Grounds its outrageousness with an undercurrent of knowing sarcasm, much like its winning star.
A film that slowly constructs the dislocation and oppression that Olga feels.
Moana is a toe-tapping, heart-stealing adventure packed with laughs and featuring a kick-ass princess with nary a love interest on the horizon.
The Autopsy of Jane Doe is good genre fun - if little more.
A clunky and turgid affair, albeit one with a few bizarre moments thrown into the mix to keep audiences on their toes.
Johnson is pushing the audience to see these images as a dialogue between herself and these subjects, both in the frame of her representation of them and their impact on her.
Best described as a poetic and philosophical essay rather than a traditional doc.
The spectacularly unfunny supporting cast -- including Dave Foley, Jeffrey Tambor and David Koechner -- doesn't help either. But luckily Kutcher is there to try to clean up the mess.
Better Luck Tomorrow, a corrosive, insightful study of the pressure-packed lives of suburban high school students, brings a new variant to gangster movies: gangsters with perfect SAT scores.
Quote not available.
With performers as good as these and the freshness of Bill Condon's screenplay and Marshall's direction, there's really very little wrong with Chicago. What it lacks is something intangible -- heat.
The worst thing about Rugrats Go Wild is that the Rugrats have dragged the Thornberrys down into the diaper bag with them.
A wan attempt to transpose the sports-movie formula onto the extreme-sports scene, Grind achieves extremes only of lameness.

A wonderfully weird bit of French animation that amounts to little but a celebration of its creator's bountiful imagination, yet manages to enthrall because writer-director Sylvain Chomet is such a solid visual storyteller.
When Farrell's on screen, Daredevil becomes more than just a finely tuned entertainment machine. In a movie that will rake people in no matter what, it's fun to see something unexpected.
Mandy is a totally uncompromising vision from a singular filmmaker - a pulsing, twisted descent into heavy metal vengeance that must be seen to be believed.
Sadly, this film stumbles in its telling from its opening moments, and one problem quickly rises above the rest: Paul Rudd is heinously miscast in this role.
It's a shame that the painstaking work of the CGI animators was ultimately doomed to failure by the script.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Tyler Perry movies certainly have their place in society, as they undoubtedly have a strong moral core and are made with noble intentions. On the evidence of For Colored Girls though, he should leave the serious drama alone.
An impressive blockbuster that does exactly what it says.
The boys may well love Mandy Lane, but cinemagoers are best advised to stay well away from her and the shockingly abysmal film that bears her name.
movie_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Winter's Bone is a rewarding watch that does repay a fairly slow-moving narrative with heightened tension and twists at the end.
Behind the frivolity of this rom-com also lurks a serious theme about the importance of proper old-school journalism.
While a disappointment, The Ward is by no means a complete dud.
It's great fun.
Get Smart certainly has its moments, but suffers badly from an inability to balance the surreal humor and life-threatening terrorist threat.
Just how was this staggeringly poor script given the green light?
The cracking performances from Alba and Cook do wonders at papering over these creative fissures.
Stone has a glittering career as a leading lady ahead of her.
An execrable movie that's incredibly uninspired.
Ultimately, there simply wasn't enough narrative development to justify a feature length film.
Soon we realize that Sicko hinges not on what Michael Moore is uncovering, but on what he's hiding. This is a real shame as he's a talented documentary maker.
The real thrill of the film lies in watching these two men, sat on various sides of the moral fence, gradually converge and respect each other.
An action blockbuster with rollercoaster thrills and laughs that has a fundamentally intelligent core.
Fingers crossed that this turns into a franchise, as Mick Haller is such a charismatic and intriguing character with many layers still to be peeled.
The real battle in this duff alien invasion movie is whether the direction is worse than the writing.
Not every movie needs to be a thought-provoking work of art...

Expecting logic from the director of the wonderful Con Air is not the wisest move, yet Simon West frequently depicts events in such a baffling manner that one wonders whether someone snuck into the editing suite with a pair of scissors.
A supremely rewarding film, Black Swan harnesses its complex subject matter through Aronofsky's genius and uniformly excellent portrayals of the damaged characters.
Described by Boyle as an "action movie with a guy who can't move", 127 Hours is a dynamic gem that makes for thrilling, if often uneasy, viewing.

For all of the hundreds of animators who spent over a year painstakingly assembling each pixel in the computer-generated world, not one person was employed who could write a competent screenplay that harnessed their efforts.

The powerful performances by the leads, unobtrusive direction that is exemplified in a beguiling courtroom clash, and Larsson's deftly interwoven fabric of treachery and compassion all ensure that we are left yearning for more.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Eat lots of popcorn to distract you, pray for it to end, and love Richard Jenkins. Amen.
The amount of preposterous coincidences that lead to the precarious predicament of the three muppets and their continued suffering also robs Frozen of any remote credibility.
Affleck's direction adds visceral qualities that complement the cerebral merits of the movie.
Well worth seeing for the barrage of genuine laugh-out-loud moments in its first half, The Other Guys is an example of a movie that peters out by conforming to storytelling convention.
Shooter is nothing special, but a combination of appealing performances, intriguing plot twists and exciting action sequences mean that we're never less than entertained.
Quite possibly the best film of the year, it is to be seen at all costs.
Kevin Smith's latest offering provides a constant stream of laughs throughout its duration, but crucially fails to nail the emotional realism it tries so hard to achieve.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The actors try their best to transcend the flimsy script and unappealing direction, but ultimately the movie offers a mostly hollow experience that delivers a night that you will struggle to remember.
Have low expectations for this movie and you might just be surprised.
Brighton Rock's pros and cons pretty much cancel each other out when assessed as a standalone movie, but it comes nowhere close to breaking free from the shackles of its 1947 antecedent.
This magnificently realized musical from Stephen Sondheim contains the right blend of emotional pathos, stunning visuals and accessible songs.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Fifty Dead Men Walking is a largely uninvolving crime thriller that fails to do justice to the intriguing story of an informant within the IRA.

Savour one of cinema's rawest talents finally powerslamming his way to glory and be grateful that Aronofsky dragged himself off the ropes on countless occasions to convince the money men to finance the movie with such a seemingly unbankable lead actor.
Anyone with a decent knowledge of horror flicks will surely recoil in terror at how terribly several masterpieces of the genre have been shamelessly ripped off.
The terrific dual performances in The Devil's Double ensure that this sensationalized account of Saddam Hussein's merciless son and his beleaguered lookalike is a worthwhile experience.
Hunger will leave you feeling emotionally battered and bruised -- yet emerging from the cinema a stronger person for having witnessed such a beautiful and brutal film.
This latest installment in the franchise is a near-perfect blockbuster that provides a myriad of visual and cerebral treats to devour.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A waste of talent, it proves that the most important people involved in cinema are those responsible for the scripts. Whether there are flies buzzing around it or not, some turds cannot be polished.
Director Oliver Parker displays a shocking inadequacy at generating even a mild titter from a few moments that had the potential to be funny.
To be consistent with his previous efforts, Anderson deploys a relentless stream of fight sequences that revert to nauseating and outmoded slow-mo during moments of supposedly heightened tension.
As funny, spooky and marvellous as ever.
A powerful reminder of the magic of cinema and Martin Scorsese's astounding versatility...

A mesmerizing movie that veers towards an unbearably tense climax, The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo benefits from invigorating direction and superb acting that allows the old-fashioned mystery to unravel in a hugely satisfying and captivating way.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A tense journey into the darkness of Middle America, Red State holds the power to both shock and amuse with its increasingly audacious story and strong performances.

Superb performances from James McAvoy and Robin Wright Penn alongside an increasingly focused narrative ensure that The Conspirator ultimately proves to be a rewarding experience with a powerful message.
Managing to overcome the contrivances and implausibilities of the storyline, The Next Three Days succeeds through the sheer verisimilitude of the performances and direction.
A clever structure, glorious ensemble cast and above all conviction ensure that laughter will be rippling like thunder inside the cinema.
Sadly, while Juno may be able to carry a big bun in her oven, this film can't quite bear the heavy burden of expectation so well.
It never feels contrived or overwritten, managing to deftly pack emotional punches through the strength of its performances and direction.
Seriously, you'll find yourself more emotionally and viscerally involved by sticking some Lego men in a water filled blender and watching them go round and round.
While the meagre rationing of shocks is undoubtedly frustrating for the bulk of the movie, this allows the final act plenty of room to crank the fear factor up to 11.
There is much to recommend in this reunion of the creative forces behind the dazzling first Saw movie.
Meet The Spartans? For those unlucky enough to be lured into the cinema, there's every chance you'll be wanting to meet your maker instead.
As the film drags on, there are several nauseatingly dogmatic moments that make you feel like you're trapped in some kind of uber-liberal rally.

Sadly not a movie about the big-chinned ski jumper Eddie Edwards, this underwhelming feature instead revolves around the 'Ted and Ralph' style bromance between a master and servant during the Roman occupation of England.
A mostly absorbing tale of the hunter being subverted into the hunted, No Country For Old Men deserves to be lauded for its gripping, relentless thrills rather than its flawed denouement.
Attack the Block is exactly the kind of distinctly homegrown product that the British film industry should be making.

A storyline that unimaginatively rehashes countless pivotal elements from other stalker-themed movies means that the whole production is a dull and pointless exercise that twists and turns in precisely the manner you expect it to.
A tonally uneasy mish-mash of stale slapstick and na√Øve representations of drug use.
Enjoy the audacious, electrifying and subversive components thrown at the audience in scattergun style.
There's an overriding sense that many aspects of the movie have either been shockingly underdeveloped... or left on the cutting room floor.
There's currently plenty of Oscar buzz and it's richly deserved, as Slumdog Millionaire ranks alongside The Wrestler as the two latest masterpieces of the 21st Century.
Alfredson excels at bringing out the best from his cast and foregrounding their convincing portrayals while seamlessly slipping in several valuable flashbacks.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The pace may flag at times, but the potent and authentic characterisation of Mikael and Lisbeth does wonders for the stamina.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Although comfortably under 90 minutes, Marmaduke is an epic chore to sit through.
Shane Meadows's movies are always brimming full of originality and verve and Le Donk & Scor-zay-zee is arguably his most daring effort so far.
Too often it feels like one of the robotic surrogates was left in charge of the scripting and directing duties for large portions of the movie.
While Pine is superb in the lead role, almost everything else fails to convince in this vastly uneven, unfunny and only sporadically dramatic enterprise.
Devoid of personality and full of characters so one-dimensional that they aren't even worth mentioning in this review, Whiteout is a movie that sees no-one emerge with any credit.
Both the visceral sense and the little grey cerebral cells are well served within the company of such a pleasingly ambiguous age-defying title character in the shape of Dorian Gray.
Cheap, dire, tedious, unfunny, offensive and desperate attempt to induce laughter. Those are just a small selection of the disparaging adjectives that can be applied to this putrid tripe.

Ultimately, if you want to watch a dire attempt at comedy revolving around a misguided father and troubled daughter then go off and rent Curly Sue. It's a cut above Imagine That, but that's hardly a compliment.
A Perfect Getaway is hardly groundbreaking, but it's a diverting slice of escapism that wallows in manipulating the viewer.
The Proposal is not a marriage made in heaven by any means, but the eventual charm of the leads and a gag-packed second half manage to salvage the movie from inauspicious beginnings.
An eerie, disturbing and moving film, but not without occasional bursts of humour, Moon is a refreshing antidote to the dumb action-orientated futuristic fodder has dominated cinemas in recent years.
It's just a shame the plot wasn't fleshed out more to enable a more complete cinematic experience, rather than a handful of inspired components.

Failing to work on so many levels, The Informers operates as a time capsule of 1983 and a time when substance was negated in favour of style. Sadly, this movie is severely lacking in both of those departments.
A fascinating, understated look at the human condition.

Br√ºno is guilty of being both unbelievably crude and side-splittingly funny. While it's certainly very close to Borat at times, as well as the proverbial bone, with Sacha Baron Cohen in such fine form almost anything is forgivable.
Fired Up is a desperate and vacuous attempt at a teen comedy that not only lacks laughs, but even the gross-out moments and shameless nudity used by other such genre offerings.
Tension and mystery are both constants throughout this very decent indie movie, which could have easily become a cult classic in future years if Sean's two pursuers were better handled by the script.
Its biggest shock is that there's much to praise, with a couple of stellar performances complementing the mounting tension and intriguingly twisting narrative.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: After the infectious fun of JJ Abrams' M:I 3, which sparkled with the wit and charm of his espionage series Alias, the fourth installment is a thudding disappointment.
This superb film shows, his conversations with Richard Nixon were far more illuminating than his recent banter with Lloyd Grossman.
The franchise simply can't compete with better written and directed comic book offerings out there. This includes Howard The Duck...

Some judicious editing could have cut a cracking hour-long film out of the final product, but as things stand Vicky Cristina Barcelona is a decent flick blessed with great performances and a corking set up.

Such is the one-dimensional nature of the slabs of meat masquerading as characters that it's hard to care for their fates, and a painfully contrived romantic intrigue between two of them hardly helps the cause.

This excruciatingly bad attempt at a breezy romcom is an ill-conceived, dreadfully executed mess. Totally bereft of laughs, drama and chemistry between the leads, the movie is so nausea-inducing that it belongs in a sub genre of its own - the vomcom.
Destined to become a fully-fledged classic of the horror genre.
Uninspired and inconsequential, The International provides less thrills than a meeting with your local bank manager to discuss interest rates.

Dark, subversive and politically incorrect humour can be brilliant in capable hands and with the right purpose (like the wonderful South Park), but here it's offensively bereft of any wit and is simply unpleasant.
Is Anybody There? conjures up a winning concoction of laughs, tears and '80s nostalgia. Above all, it showcases the breadth of British acting talent.
Ch√©ri is a very enjoyable and fascinating cinematic experience. Despite being set almost a century ago, the movie's central themes are very relevant to our age-obsessed contemporary society.

Funny, moving and fine escapist entertainment, the magnificent Star Trek is cranked up to Warp Factor 11 by the cast and crew. May the franchise live long and prosper under the guidance of J.J. Abrams.

The superb Drag Me To Hell deserves to be seen on a large screen with a sizeable crowd. Much like a theme park rollercoaster ride, the synchronised gasping, screaming and relieved bursts of laughter can only enhance the experience.
Last Chance Harvey deserves supreme praise for being a vessel that allows cinemagoers to bask in two wonderful turns by Dustin Hoffman and Emma Thompson.
Traitor is undeniably an intelligent, watchable thriller that wisely steers clear of racial stereotyping, yet manages to fall short of delivering a wholly satisfying cerebral or visceral experience.

Paranormal Activity taps into our primal fears of the unknown to provide a procession of increasingly nervewracking and frenzied moments of terror. Cut off any distractions, glue your eyes and ears to the screen and prepare to be scared silly.
A certain faecal word certainly sums up the artistic merits of The Box, a tedious and often excruciating production from Donnie Darko director Richard Kelly.

The only merriment that The Merry Gentleman delivers is through Michael Keaton's masterful direction and the performances of the two leads. It's perfectly watchable, but the story lacks the content and incident to deliver an emotional punch.
Despite the efforts of the cast, the lack of creative storytelling flair scuppers the sense of adventure and fun one would expect from a Jerry Bruckheimer summer blockbuster.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: What makes The Losers such winning entertainment is its refusal to take the story or the characters too seriously, alongside a uniformly excellent cast who all step into the shallow boots of their characters with aplomb.
Even if Lawrence was selected to play the corpse at the funeral, he'd have found a way of unleashing his sickly gurning and feral facial expressions to kill any nearby gag.

Paragraph after paragraph can be spent dissecting the flaws, the portrayal of men as either evil or nerdish, and the cringeworthy decision to make the lead actresses all strip down to their skimpies at various stages of the movie.

It makes for a reasonably absorbing watch and is a potent reminder of the underappreciated talents of several members of the cast and crew. It's just a shame that the storyline and characterisation lacks sufficient spark and innovation.
Despite a cracking central premise and outstanding visuals, 300 ultimately leaves you feeling more gutted than some of the disemboweled soldiers on display throughout the movie.
The form and content are a perfect match in Heartless. Both are desperately terrible.
Ultimately the lack of tautness in the storytelling, seemingly stemming from a desire to be as faithful as possible to Graysmith's book, costs the film dearly.
Superb pacing, robust acting and a very fishy Fishburne all help to overshadow some poorly directed set pieces and ensure that the mandible-possessing aliens are back hunting with the requisite bang.
The positives of The Rebound vastly outweigh the minor criticisms. It's also not afraid to adopt a sudden tonal shift at a key juncture of the plot, which works fairly well.
Thrilling action, well-timed humour and a strong moral heart help to justify the slightly overlong length of the movie.
Go and rent the far superior and similarly themed The Losers instead.
One shouldn't knock the plotting for being distinctly old-school, but criticism deserves to be levelled at the manner in which so much talent is squandered.
Salt deserves to carve a path through the likes of BA Baracus and Sly Stallone to pick up the crown for this summer's top action flick.
Sunshine is a fantastically enjoyable film that works our minds, delights our senses and shows that futuristic science fiction can be serious drama rather than mere popcorn fodder.
Sandler. Schneider. Rock. Spade. Hayek. Hang your heads in shame...
The remake of A Nightmare On Elm Street only serves to tarnish the legacy of the original franchise, substituting any creative flair with bogstandard writing and direction.
A trio of captivating performances from the young leads and a mesmerising soundtrack cannot drag Cherrybomb out of the creative mire.
The Stepfather is full of unintentional laughs, shameless plot contrivances and cheap scare tactics, but this adds to the fun once you've tapped into the risible nature of the production.
The very impressive Spread deserves to be a cherished gem.

Doing for Christianity what Battlefield Earth did for Scientology, The Book Of Eli is an ill-conceived, preachy leaden dud that's painfully pretentious and deserves to limp off the cinema screens in a mercifully swift time. Avoid.

Ninja Assassin is little more than a sporadically diverting disposable movie that will probably spawn several straight-to-DVD sequels. The butcher's shop window is still a more fulfilling proposition though.
Far less than the sum of its parts, Brothers fails to reach the heights that the intriguing premise, talented cast and award-winning director could have attained with some tweaking to the script.
Stylishly told and earnestly acted, Precious is a far from pleasant cinemagoing experience but a worthwhile one.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Making good use of its excellent premise, this flawed gem deserves to find an audience.
A regularly ribtickling but ultimately unsatisfying ride into the realms of teen angst - but one that showcases the undoubted talents of Michael Cera when he has the opportunity to play against type.
Don't expect the little grey cells to be stimulated while watching the movie. Do expect several shivers down the spine at regular intervals.

This thoroughly engrossing tale deserves to reach an audience, as one hopes that such brave and powerful filmmaking will encourage others in the industry to invest in the unique and young home-grown talent responsible for this triumph.

Only the procession of unintentional laughs and an unflinchingly confident turn by youngster Jodelle Ferland as Lilith emerge as reasons not to bury your head in a bucket of popcorn and rue the regrettable moment a certain vault was unlocked.
Be warned -- you'd be better off picking up a blindfold and ear plugs when entering the cinema than a pair of specs.
A trio of superb performances and slick direction ensure that this edgy little movie is eminently watchable and often gripping.
The concept of organ repossession is introduced in masterful fashion by director Miguel Sapochnik, through a glorious juxtaposition of sound and vision entwined with a viciously dark humour.

A thoroughly entertaining demon-slaying romp set in 16th Century Britain. Boasting an impressive lead performance by James Purefoy as the anti-hero seeking redemption, the film bears enough individual traits and dynamism to overcome its numerous flaws.
While less than 'ledgendary' (groan), this movie delivers enough entertainment and excitement to pass muster for an escapist trip to the cinema.
The Wedding Ringer simply doesn't seem to know what it is - a trashy flick designed to shock or a high-concept comedy about the value of real friendship.
Nicolas Cage's return to the blazing bike saddle is a distinct improvement on its dire predecessor, although that is hardly a blistering recommendation of its quality.
Boasting brilliant performances from the two leads, it will be the cause of many a nightmare.
The Woman in Black: Angel of Death reeks of a film that was hastily cobbled together in order to capitalise on the original film's success.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: What is ultimately being released reeks of the studio's contempt towards modern audiences...
Kon-Tiki is a film that inspires awe and wonder with almost every wave...
Sometimes you fancy the finest caviar known to humanity. Other times you fancy some greasy fish and chips. No Good Deed belongs in the latter category.
Third Person suffers from a script that fails to hook you in during its opening section and drags on without sufficient emotional connection for 137 minutes.
Carell delivers a commanding, unnerving portrayal of a man with cold, dead eyes and a matching heart who watches over his underlings with the predatory gaze of an eagle.
Uplifting, heartbreaking, electrifying and terrifying, it's a highly personal film but one with universal themes that we can all connect to.

The Drop sees our hopes plummet to the ground with a resounding thud, squandering the brilliant Tom Hardy and much-missed James Gandolfini with a poorly contrived tale that's often alienating to watch.
It should have been renamed TMNT: The Secret of the Snooze.
It's an extraordinary cinematic debut for director Yann Demange, whose unflinching lens quickly establishes an environment that seethes with danger and menace...
Lead actors Kristen Stewart and Peyman Moaadi deliver highly convincing portrayals as camp guard Amy and 'detainee' Ali...
Want to know what's really scary about Annabelle? Its staggering lack of imagination.
The market has been saturated with vampires in recent years, but fortunately Dracula Untold - an origins story that will hopefully lead to future outings - doesn't feel stale.
Full of intrigue and well-orchestrated twists, it's a brutal yet funny viewing experience.
The end result finds you abruptly flitting between laughter and disinterest, but is ultimately a rewarding enough experience.
The Guest is assured of cult classic status in years to come, but will hopefully entertain the masses with its winning blend of crowd-pleasing humour and suspense.
The group sex sessions are briefly interesting, not for their titillation value but the shifting powerplays that emerge between the main characters.
Much like the character of Maleficent veers between hero and villain during the story, the film straddles the line between magnificence and misery.
A fascinating study of power games, sexual manipulation and textual interpretation, driven by dazzling performances from Emmanuelle Seigner and Mathieu Amalric.
Dramatisation or reconstruction? Devil's Knot fails on both fronts given its inadequate and dissonant treatment of real events...
Echoing the dystopian brilliance of Blade Runner and Brazil and beset by remarkably similar studio wrangling over the final cut, Snowpiercer is an audacious, immersive and nightmarish masterpiece.
Andy Goddard's stylishly shot movie doesn't succeed in forming a sustained emotional connection with the viewer.
It's a noble failure, felt all the more because Anderson's films are usually so aesthetically and thematically rich and rewarding...
Izzard deftly brings out layers to the character, ensuring that no airbrushed idealisation takes place. There's an underlying sadness in his soul that emerges.
The urine you discharge during the inevitable p*ss-break is guaranteed to flow better than any dialogue in this near three-hour movie.

The beauty of Dawn of the Planet of the Apes lies in how we don't root for either species to win. We treat each individual, whether human or ape, on his or her own merits. This is the way it should be.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The Purge: Anarchy is that rare beast - a sequel infinitely better than its predecessor.
If it wasn't for a nostalgic affection for the cast and their previous endeavours, The Expendables 3 would be borderline unreleasable.
Just when you thought it was safe to go back in the water, it's time to strap on your wellies and plunge into the hilarity.
The class of the impressive cast and the immersive film noir atmosphere just about sustains our interest in a film that's most striking visual effect is the hair on Bruce Willis's head.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The tragic loss of Philip Seymour Hoffman resonates through Anton Corbijn's challenging but ultimately rewarding thriller.
An abject lack of creativity to the writing and cohesion to the direction scupper any chance of the movie transcending its mundane status.
"... a film laden with dignity and restraint that never needs to resort to melodrama or contrivance."
It won't let you go and you can't shake it off. Whether you like it or not.
Allow yourself to be consumed by the eerie tone and convincing performances and there is every chance you will be consistently gripped for this impressive foray into old-school horror.
It gives a newfound appreciation of what [Edwards] achieved and turns his struggles into an amiable and enjoyable adventure.
All you need to know is that you should see it as soon as you can. It's fantastic.
Using the animal kingdom as a means to convey so much sense about our own contemporary world is a masterstroke which owes a debt to George Orwell.
Simply put, Creed is a total triumph.
Grimsby is unashamedly crude and vulgar -- seriously, don't go expecting highbrow LOLs -- but outrageously funny as a result.
It's a vibrant, dangerous tale of revenge dominated by a stunning, multi-layered performance from Kate Winslet.
A script lacking in fresh ideas proves to be an insurmountable obstacle. For a film revolving around trees, The Hallow is sadly nowhere near barking enough.
Smart enough to challenge your views, yet not too cerebral to alienate the mainstream, Sicario is a thoroughly engrossing watch that dazzles visually and connects emotionally.
Spearheaded by Michael Fassbender's mesmerising lead performance, this tragic tale grips your senses from the beginning and never lets go.
The Visit doesn't contain enough mystery or thrills to be deemed a success...
For the bulk of No Escape's running time, there's every chance you'll yearn to escape the popcorn-encrusted cinema seat you're in.
At many times throughout this film, you'd rather be watching someone play a 106-minute game of Pong.
Boasting powerful performances from its lead stars, wonderfully creative direction and a story that will have you howling with laughter and recoiling with horror, it's a film that really resonates.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Gallows is a terrible film. That is all you need to know.
Let's just hope it generates a strong buzz, makes people realize that Heaven is a place on Firth and leads to audiences leaving the cinema beaming. It's that kind of movie.
Bring me Louis Theroux! There are many moments during this disappointing depiction of Scientology where you may be crying out that very same plea.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This pedestrian thriller plonks poor Liam Neeson back in a leather jacket and armed with a gun for another one of those 'Taken Lite' outings.

Wild Card clearly has aspirations beyond the beat-em-up genre. But it sorely lacks any connection between the characters and the viewer, failing to establish and relatable moments to rouse our interest.
John Wick is exactly what you'd hope for from a modern action movie - laced with tension, loaded with thrills and not afraid to unleash a few well-timed laughs.

A reasonably engaging thriller, Son of a Gun is most notable for reminding us of that Ewan McGregor still possesses that irresistibly dangerous and edgy quality that propelled him to stardom in Shallow Grave and Trainspotting.
It does for Skype what The Blair Witch Project did for forests.
Unrestrained and uncompromising, this hugely enjoyable blockbuster provides a mad and memorable ride. More please!
... packs a powerful emotional punch thanks to its sensitive treatment of emotive themes and an incredible, multi-layered performance from Sarah Snook.
A fresh premise and shrewd direction breathed new life into the Insidious franchise, delivering the most terrifying chapter yet.
It's so irredeemably bad that even Alan Smithee wouldn't touch it.
A worthwhile stab at approaching the zombie subgenre in a character-driven, personal manner, Maggie lacks the substance to soar and occasionally plods along like a lethargic zombie.
An utterly heartbreaking and compelling experience...
Beyond showcasing Pacino's enduring skills and exploiting our weakness for injured animals, Manglehorn doesn't seem to have a purpose.
Full of smiles and tears, much like childhood itself, Inside Out ticks so many boxes without ever feeling contrived.
Only a partially successful venture due to a script lacking invention and narrative hooks, The Messenger is nonetheless a showcase for homegrown talent and particularly Robert Sheehan.
There's little to enjoy about this daft spy thriller beyond the sight of Pierce Brosnan looking vaguely like a Spanish pimp when he wears a pencil-thin moustache as a disguise.

Taking us beneath the prop mask, in psychological rather than physical terms, Fassbender astounds with how much he's able to convey through movement and tone of voice, capitalising on dialogue that's extremely effective in its minimalism.
Even McBain would turn this down.
Such is the ferocity of the action, The Raid 2's 150-minute running time breezes past, with only the occasional brief lull caused by convoluted plot exposition.

There are flashes of visual invention scattered throughout and Helen Mirren steals the show with a stunning vocal display of austerity, but this is very much a case of Pixar going through the motions...

It may look aesthetically alluring, much like the Instagram-enhanced pictures the juvenile crooks upload onto their social network feeds throughout the course of the movie, but it's as equally hollow. Maybe that was the purpose - for art to imitate life?
Don't be fooled by Frances with all her feigned insecurity and branding of herself as "undateable" and predicting she'll be a lonely spinster. She's a psychopath.
The staggeringly unconvincing dynamic between the central characters not only leaves Fey and Rudd helpless, it ensures the whole movie is effectively rudderless.
Those brave souls who do venture to the cinema to witness this demonic dirge can at least feel relieved that it's nowhere near as dismal a viewing experience as The Devil Inside.
With a script that exposes its own mechanics and contrivances with such reckless abandon, Deadfall simply can't be prevented from flatlining by the solid ensemble cast and luscious visual palette.
The movie's best moments belong to Gerard Butler though, thriving in a role that's perfect for his capabilities as he establishes a hero we can't help but root for.
A must-see for horror fans, Evil Dead is great fun from start to finish and establishes the basis for a rejuvenated franchise that could fuse with past demon defiance rather than overwrite them.
A protracted and tedious build up leads to a mildly unnerving pay-off in this largely uninspired horror movie.
Reminiscent of classic Flintstones and Simpsons episodes.
This dismal remake of the overrated '80s cult flick is littered with the type of nausea-inducing patriotic dialogue lampooned by the likes of Team America: World Police.
What a cast. What a disappointment.
Far too busy doing the filmic equivalent of poking you with a stick to see how much you flinch, and unashamedly so.

Often moving and deeply personal, Robot & Frank is a rewarding - if often underdeveloped - antidote to the plethora of loud and overblown movies that tackle the theme of technology's role in our futures
Arbitrage is a rewarding, thought-provoking movie that deserves to find a wide audience.
Bereft of engaging characters or dialogue, it lurches from one blood-splattered action sequence to the next, even threatening viewers with a sequel at the end.
A largely ineffective and ponderous movie that harnesses many of the worst elements of both the horror genre and the found footage trope.
Consistently solid acting, smart direction and striking imagery cannot overcome a hackneyed storyline that cobbles together stale ideas and scenarios to a fittingly alienating effect.
With the exception of Guy Pearce's old school anti-hero Snow, Lockout is a pointless exercise that's bereft of originality in both its plotting and direction.
Who'd have thought that a movie entitled Piranha 3DD could be so bereft of titillation?
It may be all brawn and no brain, but there's plenty to enjoy on a non-cerebral level here.
Ultimately, it's a totally watchable action thriller but not the film it could and should have been.
Despite admirable intentions and assured performances, Dredd 3D suffers from a structurally flawed script that fails to engage and repetitive fight sequences that fail to excite.
Along with the capability to bash the brains out of any foe with something as seemingly mundane as a spoon, [Statham] can also emote. Tears shall flow.
Still relevant. Still scary. Make a date on Halloween night to witness cinema's scariest Michael Myers (unless you've seen The Love Guru) causing carnage on the big screen.
Appealing supporting turns from Russell Crowe and Lucy Liu can't salvage this shoddily structured and messily executed homage to the martial arts movie genre.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An enchanting yet savagely funny movie, Gremlins belongs alongside Ghostbusters as an enduring mainstream masterpiece from the summer of 1984. Just don't watch it after midnight.

This Irish/British horror-comedy deals with menacing tentacles of an extraterrestrial kind, with an inspired premise, appealing cast and mix of laughs and thrills ensuring it's destined for cult status.
The anthology framework works well and features enough audacious moments to merit a viewing.
Hitchcock happily displays its skeleton, but is lacking in the way of flesh. Not unlike Norman Bates's mother.
It's an uncomfortable reminder of how the memory can cheat and the Academy Awards can favor nostalgic sentimentalism over strong storytelling.
If you crave a genial crime thriller about a forensic psychologist then go and buy a boxset of Cracker. Alex Cross is simply an inexcusable misfire.

Squandering a promising premise and depriving John Cusack of sufficient dramatic meat to stake his claim to be the definitive portrayal of Poe, The Raven feels like a hollow shell - without a beating (or tell-tale) heart.
A winning combination of audacious set pieces, outrageous stunts, brawny banter and plot twists.

The East suffers from a critical identity crisis, squandering an initially intriguing premise to veer awkwardly between intimate character study and formulaic espionage thriller. It satisfies on neither count.
For those familiar with Chan-wook Park's mesmerising 2003 original, Spike Lee's remake of Oldboy is tantamount to cultural vandalism.

American Hustle confidently tackles this concept of transcending reality through deception, showcasing the versatility of its exceptional cast amidst a tale peppered with savage laughs and dark twists.
As the old adage goes, you can't polish a turd. But you can sprinkle plenty of CGI and countless close-ups of Keanu Reeves looking morose onto it.
As Mitty explains, the purpose of life is to feel. This film certainly makes us do that.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Much like the worm that's forced into Kris's body, you can't wriggle free from this film and it won't stop growing inside you as time goes by.

Kenneth Branagh's reboot of Tom Clancy's courageous CIA agent is smart and thrilling enough to soar above most espionage movies while still retaining plenty of crowd-pleasing moments to set pulses racing.
The Butler provides a well-paced look at the fluctuating and often shocking socio-political landscape of the 20th Century...
... a soulless metallic carcass designed by committee to amplify external gloss and maximise commercial profit.
Non-Stop keeps you too busy clinging to the edge of your seat to cynically probe for plot holes, providing relentless entertainment from take off to touchdown.
Even dental extraction is more enjoyable to endure than this artistically bankrupt misfire.
Noah is not Aronofsky's best work, but the auteur delves deep into the convoluted psyche of the central character much as he did with his masterpieces Black Swan and The Wrestler.
A lack of engaging ideas and mediocre execution ensures that The Quiet Ones makes little noise beyond a faint whimper.
While it fails to reach its potential due to its identity issues, abandoning veracity in favour of thrills, Honour deserves credit for broaching such tricky subject matter...
If Richard Ayoade continues in this vein, we could be looking at a director to rival David Cronenberg and David Lynch during their prime...
War. What is it good for? IMAX 3D movies that wallow in the spectacle of horrific real-life battles, judging by Stalingrad.
Structured to fine effect, Milius is both a celebration of one man's unique artistry and a cautionary tale about the propensity for self-destruction.
The found footage conceit - which once appeared so fresh in The Blair Witch Project and was rejuvenated by Paranormal Activity's use of static cameras - is now in dire need of a rest or reinvention.
An admirable thriller bursting with tension and superb turns by its stars Vanessa Hudgens, Nicolas Cage and John Cusack.
The problem is that both lead characters are interminably dull, with the camera's gaze repeatedly dwelling on their mundane private moments and imploring us to be intrigued.
Guillermo del Toro blows the likes of Battleship and Transformers out of the water with action sequences that are breathtaking in scope and ferocious in intensity.
The pairing of Nicolas Winding Refn and Ryan Gosling again delivers a terrific fusion of star, subject matter and style.
Focusing on a movie's strengths can be tough for any sequel that fails to live up to the expectation and hype. Kick-Ass 2's idolisation of its predecessor merely compounds this problem.
Too often, audience expectations are built up only for the payoff to fall short.
A bonkers idea executed with supreme confidence, This Is The End unleashes a bombardment of crowdpleasing hysteria and could be this summer's biggest surprise.
Riddick manages to flit effortlessly between moments of humour and menace, with Vin Diesel at his best in the role that propelled him to stardom.

A movie in which women are either pouting, flesh-baring sluts or morbidly obese figures of mockery with terrible personal hygiene, where rampant homophobia is deemed funny and laddish, and where crude racial stereotyping is acceptable.

Scheduling may make it a largely unwanted new release, but there is enough solid action and sturdy chemistry between the leads Channing Tatum and Jamie Foxx to make this a reasonably enjoyable thriller.
James Wan's desultory sequel lazily trots out the same procession of scare techniques but with vastly diminished returns.
A bloated blockbuster that squanders a promising premise in favour of soulless set-pieces and ejaculatory explosions of CGI.
There are no babies crawling on ceilings like in Welsh's Trainspotting, but Filth bears the same subversion and euphoria that made that 1996 film so iconic.
The Zero Theorem is an uneven endeavour that feels thematically outdated despite its futuristic setting.
Manages to salvage the flagging 'geriaction' genre with plenty of old school laughs and thrills.
Sight, sound and story all fuse into an impressively cohesive whole that help the movie zoom past the finish line after shakier beginnings.
Woefully ponderous, convoluted and improbable.
It's still a kick seeing the show's retro-cool, Hanna-Barbera-style animation blown up to 35 mm, even if The Powerpuff Girls Movie only plays like a long, slightly average episode.
First-time Australian director Alison Thompson was either dipping a bit too heavily into High Times' stash on the job or really doesn't have a clue what she's doing.
Justin Bieber's Believe is exactly the movie you think it is, and that's fine.

A muddled, directionless splatter of concert footage, studio cin√©-verit√©, music-video abstraction and Haitian/Jamaican travelogue exotica that aspires to mythmaking but instead strangles itself on its own self-indulgence.
Very "meta," very funny and very, very touching.
The spectre of imminent mortality ... adds a layer of poignancy to what might otherwise have been a more prosaic, if still totally interesting, portrait of an eccentric creator.
You don't need to like Lamb of God's music - although, for the record, you should because it's awesome - to walk away from As the Palaces Burn feeling genuinely fond of the band.
movie_title: Lamb Of God's As The Palaces Burn (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A rare, if dated, treat -- an intelligent film that's grown-up enough to deal with sex, sexism and friendship, with wit and honesty.

Travolta and Newton-John burn up the screen with all the passion of a potato salad while occasionally singing a song you know all the words to because they play it every week in small-town nightclubs.
Fiorentino lights up this stylish noir classic and breaths new, menacing life into the femme fatale role. Barbara Stanwyck would be proud.

Slow-burning and bleak, this detailed study of deception and self-justification is brought to life by the virtuoso performance of Klaus Maria Brandauer and the perfectly restrained direction of Istvan Szab√≥.

Although French directing duo Alexandre Bustillo and Julien Maury add some extra griminess and the central mystery is clever enough, Leatherface never truly escapes just how pointless and misaligned its whole set-up is.
Another sure-fire cult hit from Don Mancini that takes Chucky to terrifying new heights, even if it is missing the ending it deserves.
In doubling down on the humour and keeping the practical effects at the forefront, Adam Green has once again delivered a hugely satisfying, fan-centric slasher with a lot of personality.

Everything from the style to the substance is spot on here and Wingard shepherds in his very different vision of the manga beautifully, it's just crammed into too small a time-space to really make an effect.
Both Tragedy Girls, and its fiendishly loveable starring duo, happily join the pantheon of teen movie greats; a genuine cult hit in the making.
Genre movies don't get more thrilling than this bag of fireworks - a total wild-eyed thrill ride hung on three of the best female characters of the year.

There's a very well-managed use of space, and Botet's performance has a lot more behind it than meets the eye, but otherwise it's a film that exists almost purely to show off a bunch of unsuspecting pranks.
Horror hounds, sci-fi fans and even just those chasing a good old-fashioned mystery will find a lot to love in Radius.
Although the higher order thinking that sits just below the surface throughout isn't always entirely clear, it remains, for the most part, emotionally gripping.
A mindblowingly silly, seriously extravagant and really mostly un-called for experience, but one the right audience will have a totally wild and unexpected blast with.
A Dark Song is a ridiculously strong and beautifully acted piece of work, but one that deserves a much more satisfying conclusion.
This Canadian feature cleverly mixes archetypes from war films and coming-of-age movies, defamiliarizing both genres in the process.
A breakthrough -- not just for indie writer-director Andrew Bujalski, but for American movie comedy.
The movie's an eyeful, and the filmmakers' attention to surface texture results in passages of genuine eroticism.
Holofcener elicits relaxed and relatable work from the entire cast, and she displays a strong ear for the patter of upper-middle-class passive-aggression.
The movie displays a fair amount of visual invention in its sight gags, stunt choreography, and bright color schemes.
For better and for worse, this feels less like a feature film than a stretched-out Daily Show segment.
This latter-day B movie can be rather fun in its preposterousness and bargain-basement style.

Though writer-director Haifaa Al-Mansour doesn't break new ground aesthetically, she relates the experience of a Saudi Arabian girl's coming of age clearly and unsentimentally, which alone makes this a must-see.
With its stunning Anatolian landscapes, arty photography, and pregnant silences, this debut feature by writer-director Emin Alper initially recalls the work of Nuri Bilge Ceylan.
Any insights the film has to impart about the writing process are delivered in embarrassingly literal fashion.
The movie is lifeless for its first hour, and the last-minute outpourings are too little, too late.
Most impressive, however, is Farahani's lead performance. Though often pitiable, the heroine never registers as a martyr or a victim, but a relatable, multifaceted human being.
Writer-director Lucy Mulloy displays much promise in her first feature, a gritty teen drama shot in Havana with a nonprofessional cast.
Screenwriters Ziad Doueiri and Joelle Touma pull quite a few punches here, making the doctor improbably naive about Israeli-Palestinian tensions so that his transformation seems profound.
As an educational film, though, it's quite successful, explaining concepts like trade deficits and supply and demand with enough visual pizzazz to hold the interest of a lay audience.
Writer-director David Lowery strains for poetry at every turn, and only the strain registers.
The action choreography (by the great Yuen Woo-ping) feels oddly rhythmless; likewise, Wong's depictions of the larger-than-life characters achieve little emotional resonance.
This often feels familiar, but it's refreshing to see such time-worn material revived without ironic detachment.
That rarest of breeds: the intellectual blockbuster.
At least most of the cast is appealing, with Mark Ruffalo, Gwyneth Paltrow, Josh Gad, and Alecia Moore (better known as pop singer Pink) delivering the uninspired dialogue with relative finesse.
Even as someone who finds Metallica's music silly (ditto the movie's incoherent apocalyptic fantasy sequences), I was floored by much of the visual imagination.
Foote's metaphors and psychological insights are so clearly delineated that there's little room for spontaneity, though the actors do what they can with the space they're given.
Shaka King's low-budget debut feature is slim on plot but rich in attitude and on-the-ground detail of New York neighborhood life.

This sequel is a triumph of production design: Philip Messina's settings are so detailed that they convey how the movie's dystopic U.S. functions beyond the story at hand, and Trish Summerville's costume design shows a similar degree of invention.

The story for this revisionist fairy tale, which promotes contemporary attitudes about parenting and gender equality, is less inspired than usual for Pixar, but the movie upholds the studio's high standard of computer animation.
If you dislike child actors, you might derive a perverse satisfaction from seeing dozens of them look so unhappy to be onscreen.
Privileged thirtysomethings whine about their romantic problems in this indie rom-com from writer-director Sam Neave.

This plush, mawkish period drama, adapted from Markus Zusak's 2005 best-seller, might be useful as a means of introducing the Holocaust to small children, but it's indefensible on almost any other terms.

This independent drama effectively captures the spirit of much contemporary fiction: the tone is at once precious and stark, and the narrative drifts from one episode to another (and from realism to fantasy) as though it were playing out in a dream.
All we learn is that this happened and then this and then this -- the movie is like a multimillion-dollar grade-school play.
Reeves gets plenty of mileage from this premise, using it to comment on globalization, cinema in the Internet age, and the moral cost of selling out.

This sense of childlike wonder, and the respect accorded everyone involved in prolonging the bus's usefulness, are all the more impressive given that Kendall concludes with a sobering assessment of widespread civilian violence in Central America.
movie_title: La Camioneta: The Journey of One American School Bus (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This is gripping as an adventure story even if doesn't achieve the profundity to which it aspires.
This maintains a bright, cartoonish tone no matter how outlandish or gruesome the story gets, with the growing disparity between form and content providing some of the better laughs.
This wrenching documentary, profiling the four doctors who still provide third-trimester abortions in the U.S., is remarkable for being so level-headed.
[An] uplifting underdog story, complete with dance numbers and a sweet romantic subplot.
There's something unsettling about a real-life tragedy presented as an action film; that the filmmakers never acknowledge this is more unsettling yet.
The mannered speech is fun, the players are charismatic, and director Brad Furman maintains an agreeably brisk pace.
The original was nothing special, but at least it had a sense of humor and a modicum of social insight.
Writer-director Richard Curtis (Love Actually) papers over any disturbing subtext with wall-to-wall cuteness -- even the sex jokes sound as if they were lifted from greeting cards.
The lawyers are supposed to be former lovers, but the film doesn't allow the leads to display any chemistry; likewise, it doesn't generate any suspense from its tried-and-true conspiracy premise.
The movie's a mess, but a unique and provocative one.

This fast and loose independent production is enjoyable as a home movie, but not much more.
Nellis demonstrates sympathy for her upper-middle-class characters without seeming complacent about their materialist lifestyle.

movie_review_blurb: Director Tomas Rehorek maintains the same toneless, naturalistic approach throughout, which flattens the more ambitious ideas in Marek Epstein's script.
This animated adaptation qualifies as an epic in its own right.

The psychosexual drama plays out beneath the surface -- the movie is so understated it sometimes feels inert.
When the filmmakers try to flesh out the terrorists, they fall back on the conservative cliche that they're spoiled rich kids, mad at their parents.

Much of Will's dialogue consists of life lessons imparted to the boy, and they sound like a motivational seminar.
The dialogue and editing are zippy and generally charming, combining with the tart observations of 20-something culture to create a nice frisson.
