The new Adam Sandler comedy has all the charm of a home movie that does not star your own family, which means it's overly sentimental, filled with you-had-to-be-there moments, bad jokes and even worse camera angles.
Just how close the filmmakers were to the action, and the risks they took with the project, filter into virtually every scene. We hear the bullets whizzing past, breaking branches in nearby trees.
Little more than torture porn tricked out in art-house finery.
Swinton is one of the finest actresses working in contemporary cinema, but Guadagnino, who developed the project with her in mind, has created a film that literally luxuriates in her talents.

In the comic book tradition, the story weaves between the real and the mythical, but it's a very boozy trip. Brolin's intermittent voice-over narration proves to be the most powerful stuff, with the rest curiously sputtering.

The Karate Kid is a kung fu kick of a film that hits more than it misses, with its fresh prince of Beijing in Jaden Smith, its scene-stealing grand master flash, Jackie Chan, and a shiny-happy China travelogue thrown in for good measure...
As satisfying as The Girl Who Played With Fire is, it leaves you longing for more.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: She is by turns blue, bitter, hilarious, unbroken; a Hollywood-style portrait in infinite ambition. In that role, Rivers is unforgettable.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There is enough saving grace on these craggy shores to let the mists and the legends roll in and envelop you for a while.
Stoller ... apparently has major trust issues with his odd-couple stars, women and the audience. Did I forget anybody?
It's like two hours of July 4th fireworks, only with flying swords and sandstorms, and raging battles and mystical palaces rising out of the desert.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In this second screen incarnation of the fabulous HBO series, the satire is sagging, the irony's atrophied and the funny is flabby.

Cantona, whose five-year run with United ended with his unexpected retirement in 1997, plays himself with a self-deprecating charm that is hard to resist, and Evets, a hardscrabble actor who's knocked around for years, is unforgettable...

Just how deep inside Jandal's world Poitras goes is all the more striking given the inherent cultural barriers and danger she faced as a female filmmaker shooting a former Al Qaeda operative in Yemen.

For the most part the screenwriters never lose sight of the moral of this story: Whatever else gets tossed into the mix, Shrek must be the heart and soul. In this, Myers is a master; he makes it seem easy being green.
A film that unsettles as often as it seduces, though it does very well with both.

A whimsical whirligig of a movie filled with salvaged metal and salvaged lives, where a bullet to the brain brings insight and a bunch of clever misfits bring a couple of weapons-making giants to their knees. What fun.
The good news is that Efron continues to get better with each film; he just hasn't gotten a role yet that will finally put his acting potential to the test.
A taut and tantalizing mix of salty bites and lazy blanks...
The plot doesn't always hold water and it has a tendency to ramble, but they don't seem to care. And honestly, neither should you.
This is a disappointing turn coming from Phillips, particularly since "The Hangover" was such a fresh, bracing brew of black comic fun.
Since irony is so often director Jonathan Lynn's weapon of choice, Wild Target should have been a good fit. It's not quite.
An extremely satisfying ending to the story of Lisbeth Salander, the tough Swedish cyber punk that actress Noomi Rapace has turned into an iconic New Age heroine.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Like a quiet conversation about despair and hope.

It's a story of faith expressed with simple grace and the small deeds of a pardoned sinner still searching for forgiveness. It is like a minimalist stage play -- three acts, two characters, quietly redemptive.
movie_title: Letters to Father Jacob (Postia pappi Jaakobille) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The film falls short of delivering the outrage and uplift that should have come easy for this true-life fight against justice denied.
[A] hypnotic and sprawling five-hour-plus piece of cinematic genius from master French filmmaker Olivier Assayas...
Above all, Fleck and Boden break the fourth wall brilliantly and frequently, and that inventiveness is one of the film's great charms.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: What you may not expect is quite how satisfying much of the film is, with Duhamel turning out to be a very good sparring partner for Heigl, whose lush, soft exterior conceals a very spiky interior that tends to wilt her co-stars.
The animation itself is startlingly beautiful, as is the ancient owl world it imagines. The battles are complex and, in true Snyder tradition, heavy on the action.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This kinder, gentler Allen is still clever, still amusing, and the film itself is a confection tempting enough to consider a taste. Yet there is that empty-calorie letdown after it's over. Maybe it's time to book another trip to Spain.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's almost impossible not to be swept up by the exuberant fun of this singing, dancing, irony-laced ode to the repression, reeducation and resistance of Australia's indigenous tribal peoples circa 1969.
By turns heroic, fearsome, funny, fateful and, oh, so brutal, with swords hacking off heads at every turn.
Even with all of the action, and with a few plot twists that are kinda cool, there's really not enough to Takers to make it worth your time.
More his journey than hers, more satire than slapstick, the film is that rare example of rom-com about men, which turns out to be a nice switch indeed.
[Tries] so hard for the laughs and the allusions amid all the gore, and endless bloodbath of bare naked ladies, that it completely forgets to frighten anyone.
It helps that Roberts rides all the turbulent waves with such ease and such grace, that Jenkins knows exactly what to do with his internal churn, and that Bardem can do no wrong.
The fun is not so much in who wins or loses the girl -- it's the playing that matters, and Scott Pilgrim vs. the World definitely has game.
Flipped is the kind of small, special movie that wraps you up in so much warmth, humor and humanity that it will leave you wishing that stories like this weren't so rare.
A sugary paean to quixotic clich√©s and a film destined to be a guilty pleasure for some (me included, sigh) and the painful price of a relationship for others (so steel yourselves).

More impressive than the multi-dimensions is "Megamind's" minimalist, modernist look. It creates a crispness that feels more contemporary than retro, which not only is very aesthetically pleasing but makes it easier to savor the film's many sight gags.
I don't know that we actually need Agent OSS 117, but the world is a slightly better place with him around. And the film itself is a harmless trifle -- make that truffle, chocolate of course.
movie_title: OSS 117: Rio ne r√©pond plus (Lost in Rio) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In the joyous and buoyant new documentary Babies, the filmmakers keep the baby -- and the bathwater -- and everything else about infants that makes them so appealing that the rest of us keep making more of them.
In Shutter Island, director Martin Scorsese has created a divinely dark and devious brain tease of a movie in the best noir tradition.
When the beast is finally revealed, he's fearsome. Too bad the story's not.
The stars mostly shine, the story snippets mostly amuse and you'll barely notice all the empty spots where a plot used to be.
There's no real depth or texture to the characters of any sort, sentimental or otherwise, and I say that as someone who can be brought to tears by a Hallmark commercial.
The brilliant power of the film comes from the gritty reality Arnold creates.
The story is poignant and compelling, but ultimately the film doesn't have the heft it needs to fill out the big screen.
Like Fisher, the film is lovely, if flawed.
movie_title: The Loss of a Teardrop Diamond (2009)

movie_review_blurb: [Meyers has] given us her thinnest slice of comic relationship angst yet, proving, I guess, that you actually can be too thin.

Drawing on his stint at a Chicago investment firm, DePietro creates characters, dialogue and situations that feel authentic, which makes the film relevant in unexpected ways, though not as deeply as you hope he'll do in the future.
Thomas brings a light campy touch as she did in 1995's The Brady Bunch Movie.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps Zero would have been a better name.
What filmmaker Jean-Marc Vall√©e has done in this delicious historical romance is capture that hot blush of pure emotion that comes before kisses, sex, heartbreak and the rest can dilute it.
The writer-director is up to his old tricks, creating an onion of an experience -- a movie within a movie within a movie, irony in each layer, poignancy that stings and whimsy that bites.
We're always looking for those performances that truly define an actor, where we can sit back and simply watch the talent soar. For Colin Firth, A Single Man is that film.
Serious Moonlight has its flaws, but then what marriage doesn't?
Sheridan seems as conflicted as the Cahills about their virtues and failings.
The dialogue is fresh-prince clever, the themes are ageless, the rhythms are riotous and the return to a primal animation style is beautifully executed.

As in life, the presence of Welles never fails to overtake things and McKay's command of the subject is so Welles-ian that when he's in a scene everyone else fades a little. And neither [Linklater] nor the film ever quite recover from that.
Grant has never been less charming and Parker never less fashionable or more grating than they are as Paul and Meryl Morgan.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An old-style potboiler about desperate cops in dire straits that overcooks both its story and its stars, with Ethan Hawke, Don Cheadle and Richard Gere the main ingredients left stewing.
Instead of invitations, they should be sending out apologies for Our Family Wedding, a cake-and-kisses comedy that has disaster written all over it and not for the right reasons.
Somewhere the heart that must anchor a romantic drama has gone missing. We don't so much feel the relationships as see them.
If you're in the mood for a splash of dark drama, a bit of humor, very dry, on the rocks, with a twist, this will come close to satisfying.
It's a strong directing debut for Barber, who uses the poignant power of Harry's experience to take a universal cut at decaying communities and the poverty of soul as well as pocket.
The film has a remarkably exuberant spirit that is impossible to resist...
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: White and director of photography Scott Kevan, who collaborated on Stomp the Yard, have some seriously inventive visuals, which at times are smash-cut fabulous.
No matter how many times director Alan Poul tries lighting the fire, nothing ignites.

Destined to be little more than a footnote in the anthology of extraordinary films to come out of the long creative collaboration between producer Merchant, director James Ivory and screenwriter Ruth Prawer Jhabvala.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Like the murder at the heart of this tale, Secret is bound to linger in the memory for years.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Comes knocking at the door like a wolf in sheep's clothing, draping reality in a fictional romantic comedy about a twentysomething NYC couple named Daryl and Zoe whose relationship is coming apart.

Neither horrific enough to scare, nor psychologically thrilling enough to even register a pulse. And whatever fun there is to be found, and there were hoots aplenty, it's of the "laughing at, not with" variety.

It is the rising friction between the blood brothers that holds the story together. The arguments about loyalty and larger missions that tear at their alliance feel both age old and completely current.
An intense and intriguing, if at times uneven, film with Italian director Marco Bellocchio wringing every drop of emotion out of his actors and his audience before it is over.

Envisioned as a psychosexual thriller about a woman scorned, director Atom Egoyan's latest puzzle is just puzzling, little more than a messy affair with mood lighting, sexy lingerie, heavy breathing and swelling, um, music.

There are times the action lags, and when the dialogue falls back on pop cultural references it feels contrived and forced but, mostly, like the mythical creatures at the heart of this tale, the movie soars.
A sort of over-heated alternative universe where a funny-again Chevy Chase shows up as the hot tub repair man, the band Poison is all the rage and the '80s kitsch is outstanding.
When it comes to Aniston, maybe it's simply time to settle and stop asking her to be The Good Girl anymore -- perky just might be as good as it gets.

Everyone has secrets in the The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, a mind-bending and mesmerizing thriller that takes its time unlocking one mystery only to uncover another, all to chilling and immensely satisfying effect.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Shannon infuses manic life and libido into the crazy, controlling genius in caftans and in the process makes real the ego-destroying realities and unforgiving odds of making it as a band. But every time things get interesting, like the Jett-Currie relati
In Greenberg it's sometimes difficult to figure out whether it's Roger or Baumbach who has lost his way.
Nothing would work, though, without the appealing Baruchel.
Multiple Sarcasms is Woody Allen lite -- there's a lot of introspective fumbling around and intellectual foreplay. But in the end, instead of a satisfying climax, it feels like someone is faking it.
An extraordinary new drama whose fierceness, like its 6-year-old heroine Hushpuppy, grabs on and won't let go.
A tale of heart-wrenching tragedy and uplifting triumph that never quite hits its stride.
To fully appreciate "Ted," it's best to simply forgive its bad behavior upfront and save any apologies for liking it until later. Sorry.

What sustains the film through the rockier times are its challenging themes, offering real issues for the young protagonists to wrestle with, rather than whether anyone will be carded trying to buy beer.
What happens when a seemingly righteous operation goes wrong and anxiety threatens to overtake ideals? It is the question "Night Moves" asks and answers in chilling ways.
This is Jolie's film because of the Maleficent she makes. Everyone else, even Aurora, fades in her presence.
MacFarlane is a very funny dude, and there are times "A Million Ways to Die" is indeed funny. But too often the movie feels half-baked.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: That the couple have any charm is thanks to Owen and Binoche. In fact, it is hard not to hope that they'll get another chance at romance some day - the actors, that is.
A tangled tale of crime and punishment that mines the Lone Star lore of guns and killing.
Time travel, Peter Dinklage and 1970s kitsch top a very long list of what makes "X-Men: Days of Future Past" such a blast.
One of those prickly period pieces about hard times that gets under your skin and leaves you unsettled long after.
Life is awkward, emotions are unfiltered, it all unfolds with a raw, R-rated edge.
"The Retrieval" comes at you like a haunting slip of a memory, one that writer-director Chris Eska retrieves from a mostly forgotten era in unforgettable ways.
This raunchy unrooting of a settled suburban idyll exposes the considerable angst of emerging adulthood with a kind of scatological fervor designed to elicit oodles of inappropriate laughs.
A darkly ironic and skillfully surreal examination of an unrealized life.
The script, written by director John Slattery and Alex Metcalf, drifts too quickly into blue-collar cliches, leaving its interesting collection of characters only half-drawn at best.
The beauty and ugliness of "Desert Riders" will haunt you. The boys and the world Sarin takes us into linger long after the final frame.

"Belle" is greatly buoyed by Mbatha-Raw's performance. She infuses Dido with a confident and intelligent grace that keeps you engaged long after the tangled story has let both the actress and audience down.
This modest indie with major ambitions is directed by veteran cinematographer Steven Bernstein, making a solid feature debut.
The bond between Spidey and the fearful and fleeing masses, which should be emotional and strong, has lost its personal touch.
My advice to guys? Step away from the vehicle, because "The Other Woman" is out of control and intent on running down a certain kind of male.
Ironically this big, lumbering movie could have used more, not less. More Godzilla without question, and more emotional content for its very good cast too.
"Blue Ruin" is an uneven film, and there are slip-ups along the way, but the tension that settles in slowly like a low-grade fever keeps you with it.

With the ever-expanding number of adults able to stay alive longer because of medical advancements, quality-of-life issues are top of mind for many folks. It's the way the filmmaker makes the point that is the problem.
It's a rip-roaring ride.
You come for the conversation, and in that, "The Trip to Italy" rarely disappoints.
All in all, "Happy Christmas" is a good deal like cartoon Charlie Brown's classic tree - scraggly, plenty of heart and much to enjoy, especially if you prefer your presents homemade.
As to whether "Moonlight" is magical - it is, but ever, ever so slightly.

Fernandez is astute in the way he fills the empty hours on screen. He sets a slow steady rhythm and embraces lingering shots and long silences to catch the way the days are lazy about unfolding, especially for Sebastian.
There are occasional flashes of the exceptional, but the film's dodgy story can't sustain them.
Since it's a comedy, much could be forgiven if the film was consistent in generating laughs, but the comedy is as erratic as the couple's sex life.
Make no mistake, a good "Purge" does not equal a good movie, but the post-apocalyptic thriller is slightly more interesting because it takes itself, and its menace, more seriously.
Joe Berlinger's densely detailed new documentary about the legendary Boston mobster is disturbing on so many levels it's hard not to wonder why Bulger was the only one on trial.
movie_title: Whitey: United States of America v. James J. Bulger (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This sequel's spoof of its predecessor's riff on the original 1980s-era buddy-cop TV show coalesces into a raucous, raunchy, irreverent, imperfect riot.
An extraordinarily intimate portrait of a life unfolding and an exceptional, unconventional film in which not much else occurs. Never has so little meant more.
Casting Marion-Rivard in the title role was a risk that paid off, giving the film its authenticity, also its imperfections, which are easy enough to live with.
"Venus in Fur," a whip-smart dissection of gender politics via some teasing S&M, is arch. So arch in fact that it is surprising it's a Roman Polanski film.
There are some laughs and, at least on screen, more than a few tears. But it doesn't come together with the kind of satisfying punch a comedy should deliver.
In "Snowpiercer," Bong's first English-language film, nothing gets lost in translation.
It's still not a great movie, but it is, most definitely, full-metal Bay.
"Third Person" maddens far more than it intrigues. Indeed, more curious than anything about the movie itself is how such an artistic stumble happened.
"The Moment" is a psychological thriller more muddled than the mind and the maze it is caught up in.
Hart hits such adrenaline-fueled extremes it's exhausting.

But don't be misled by its simple premise. "Land Ho!" is full of surprises, rich in the way it noses around the rocky terrain of aging in an indifferent world through the engaging performances of its two stars.
Artful, insightful and at times very, very funny, much of its wry humor is due to Allen, who co-stars opposite Turturro.
Don't let the title of this indie gem fool you, "Small Time" has humor and heart big time.
Rather than sifting through the emotional layers of a surprisingly determined young woman, more often the scenes feel drained of life.
French filmmaker Alain Guiraudie's tantalizingly erotic fable of love, passion and death.
What "Awkward" is actually about, albeit unintentionally, is how passing off misogyny for comedy has gotten so terribly pass√©, as insulting to the guys as to the young women.

Garcia and Farmiga have such an easy, natural chemistry that their on-screen sparkle helps mitigate the film's weaknesses. At others times, it serves to underscore what might have been. It's a feckless conundrum.
Chilean director Sebastian Lelio's near-perfect film about the very imperfect world of a divorced woman of a certain age.
Filled with very good intentions, very bad dialogue and a surprisingly affecting turn by its star Vanessa Hudgens.
Cube is solid as the impenetrable brick wall that Hart's comic barrage bounces off. Their odd-couple shtick delivers laughs. But more often than not "Ride Along" chokes on its own fumes.
If you can get past the past, which I recommend, what is left is a lovely, intimate film about longing and love.
What makes "Lone Survivor" work as well as it does are the human exchanges. Whether friend or foe, the moments feel all too real.
"The Lego Movie" is a massive collision of subversive humor, hyper-kinetic energy, mind-jangling design, spinning colors and about 15 million Legos, no exaggeration.
Man, does this movie have a savage bite.
Peter Jackson's newest installment of the Tolkien trilogy is set afire by the scorching roar of a dragon.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating new documentary about art, obsessions, ideas and answers.
The most hopeful - and the best - of this solid and unsettling series.
"Out of the Furnace" is rich in talent used wisely. Woody Harrelson, Zoe Saldana, Willem Dafoe, Forest Whitaker and Sam Shepard help to create a sinewy portrait of a dying way of life.
These Birds Walk serves as a reminder of the resilience of children and how little it takes to keep hope alive.
"Black Nativity" struggles mightily.
There is a brashness in the risks taken, the very imperfections revealing an artist finding new inspiration. For Lee, this weird, brutal film seems to have freed him.

With a cool, contemporary spin on a fairy-tale classic, a dramatic Nordic landscape animated in splendid storybook style and Broadway vets belting out power ballads, Frozen is an icy blast of fun from the very first flake.
While I'm glad "Anchorman" is back - we need a little levity in this year of heavy films - I do wish it were better.
The excellent new drama In Bloom, Georgia's Oscar entry in the foreign-language category, has the heartbreak and hope of a country slipped inside a coming-of age-story of two 14-year-old girls.
No matter what the title says, there is no welcome waiting for you.

The re-imagined crime, action, sci-fi thriller isn't going for the biting satire of Paul Verhoeven's 1987 original, or its extreme violence. The sci-fi side hasn't evolved much. And the thrill? Well, most of the thrill is gone.

It is the rapport between Kinnear and the boy that really holds the film together. They make the father-son relationship believable in a way that grounds "Heaven" and gives it some of its best moments.
Wonderfully animated and well-voiced, "Rio 2" is nevertheless too much. Too much plot, too many issues, too many characters.
Though "Joe" occasionally slips and falters, the filmmakers and actors get all the hard-luck details right. Besides, it's nice to see its star out of the cage for a change.
Watching this film feels like a genesis moment - of sci-fi fable, of filmmaking, of performance - with all the ambiguity and excitement that implies.
"Alan Partridge" plays to all of Coogan's strengths and all of the character's foibles.
Almost every line is delivered with such overwrought bombast, just inches at times from the camera, you may feel a need to dodge the spittle.
As you might guess, this is not a film for everyone's taste. But for fans of the martial arts genre, Evans has created a scintillating, if sometimes imperfect, new chapter.

As a filmmaker, Luna is still finding his voice. For all he effectively puts on screen in "Cesar Chavez," Luna never gets past his respect for the accomplishments to give us a true measure of the man.
The only thing better than one Kermit is two. And the only thing better than two Kermits is one with a Russian accent.
In trying for the vicarious varoom of the street-racing video game that inspired it, and no doubt dreaming of "Fast" success, "Speed" clocks in at a long two-plus hours and falls painfully short.
Ties up a lot of loose ends and opens up a new can of worms.
For all the ways the film reflects its earlier TV incarnation, the shadings have been softened. "Mr. Peabody" could use a bit more bite.
The spectacularly brutal fighting is the film's main calling card, and in that "Rise of an Empire" doesn't disappoint.
Marked as outsiders by their respective societies, an unlikely friendship is forged, an ill-tempered uproar unleashed, and a delightful movie is the result.
There are so many good reasons to bag "The Bag Man." Where to begin?
It is difficult to figure out which is the film's more pressing theme - the power of love to change the course of a life, or the political and social realities of living in occupied territory.
The result is a little like baby bear's porridge, neither all bad nor all good, though not quite right yet either.
For all of Paulson's intelligent calm in front of the camera, he is telling an American horror story of massive proportions.
movie_title: Hank: Five Years From the Brink (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Wilde has one of those faces cameras love, thus her other career as a model. There are suggestions in "Endless" that she might have acting talent too. But the director rarely asks.

The greatest sin of "Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame To Kill For" is the way its high style is brought low -- visually stunning, but emotionally vapid, unrelentingly violent, its splendiferous comic book cast mostly squandered.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Let's just say, whatever your mood going in, you will likely feel a good deal better coming out.
Without Molina and Lithgow, the film might feel like little more than a light experiment in social dynamics. But nearly everything about "Love Is Strange" suits it ...
You're left with that empty feeling of a surface barely scratched, when the legend that was Cantinflas deserves much more.
A mash-up of social media shortcomings and Shakespearean tragedy that becomes as much a tale of cinematic ambition gone awry as anything the Bard intended.
As pure of heart as its heroine, "Cinderella" floats across the screen like a gossamer confection, full of elegant beauty and quiet grace.
The Hollywood stakes for Smith are as high as they are for the con man he plays. As it stands, "Focus" just might be a game changer.
The story drifts and the pacing drags, failing to gather much steam until the final moments.
"All the Wilderness" seems tailor-made to play to the actor's strengths - Johnson's script is as lean as Smit-McPhee, both proving adept at doing more with less.
Romance, or the desire to find someone special, isn't a bad thing - if it's not the only thing. But as it stands in "DUFF," the denouement at prom has clich√© written all over it.
The divorce-centered drama is so provocative it's become a lightning rod for debate inside the country. Even watching from a distance is unnerving.
movie_title: GETT: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem (2015)

movie_review_blurb: If you're not going to break out of the box when you move mediums with a musical, it is critical to use the box very, very well. Unfortunately, "The Last Five Years" does neither.
Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter is a moody comic allegory about desperation, disconnection and dreams that uses Fargo, the Coen brothers classic, as a touchstone to examine modern life.
If you can forgive the failings for at least some of the two-plus-hour running time, "Kingsman" serves up its share of entertaining froth.
I know it's early, but "Seventh Son" may actually be the worst movie of the year. It will most certainly be a contender.
A provocative, sometimes satiric drama about the sort of Islamic extremists who make life, especially in the outer reaches, so treacherous these days.
Sadly, "Wild Card" is no royal flush, no full house, no three of a kind. A bust is I think the term I'm searching for.
"Winter" feels very much like an epic novel, mirroring the pacing and themes of Chekov, whose work was its inspiration.
"Strange Magic," the new animated musical fairy tale from the mind and the mixtape of George Lucas, is indeed strange. What's missing is the magic.

Artfully and cleverly, the sweet spirit of that young bear from darkest Peru and his many London misadventures materializes brilliantly on screen in the very good hands of writer-director-conjurer Paul King.
To her credit, the writer-director tries for complexity. Now if she can just get the storytelling to match the quality of the filmmaking, I suspect there will be fewer little accidents.
Too often the filmmakers go for cheap shots.
All of the strangely charming cartoony undersea nonsense of SpongeBob that's delighted kids and stoners for year comes to the surface in "The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water." Prepare to giggle.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "Taken 3" is so unintentionally hilarious I couldn't help but wonder - do movie contracts carry a humiliation bonus clause these days?
Part of the contract that movies of this sort forge with moviegoers is that the reasons for all the running and gunning won't get in the way of the action. "The Gunman" doesn't play by those rules.
Tension is one of "Home's" biggest issues. There just isn't nearly enough of it. Story is another. Even a kids' movie needs more complexity and more invention.

There is pain and empowerment in The Secrets as difficult choices are made. There are also gaps, but emotionally moving performances by Ardant, Bukstein and Shtamler in particular, keep you with this small but provocative film until the end.

Zandvliet and Steen create an unvarnished saga of a recovering alcoholic whose acting career makes all that teetering on the edge of one-day-at-a-time very public. It is a singular performance and a deeply affecting if imperfect film.
It is an impressive feature directing debut, with Banks handling the high-octane chaos of "Pitch" with almost perfect aplomb.
The kind of heartwarming, sentimental tale of a gentle soul that the PBS show's iconic character would love.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: What "I'll See You" does particularly well is get at how any relationship - whatever your age - comes with a limited, rather than a lifetime, warranty.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: So bad you'd think it was directed by the worst sort of male chauvinist director.

The plot is lean, the dialogue is spare and there are some intriguing stabs at intellectual and emotional terrain. But the pacing is deadly, so slow there might be time for a catnap or two without missing anything important.
It's a hoot and a half.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: With Ferrell and Hart involved, it's probably impossible for anyone to completely resist their baser instincts to be amused by the patently offensive. Though it's hard not to wish more moviegoers would.

Director Catherine Hardwicke pays attention to details about simple things like clothes, food and activities that make 'The Nativity Story' seem so real.
The time travel in 'Deja Vu' boggled my mind completely, and I'm still scratching my head trying to figure the whole thing out.
As an avid movie musical fan, I became enchanted with those spectacular singing and dancing sequences in 'Happy Feet.' Way to go, penguins!
This creative film presents a whimsical story that entertains us while also making us think about our own mortality and what's important in life.
Despite Martin Short's highly entertaining turn as Jack Frost, this second sequel lacks the charm of the first two 'Santa Clause' movies.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: 'Catch a Fire' gets off to a slow start, but once the suspense kicks in, it's a riveting movie with superb performances by Robbins and Luke.
Although not without flaws, 'Flags of Our Fathers' is an enlightening and thought-provoking tribute to the heroes of Iwo Jima.
Too much blurry cinematography and indecipherable whispering made 'Marie Antoinette' the most annoying film I've seen since 'Miami Vice.'
Sweet Land, a beautiful and poignant film, impressed me with its charming simplicity and convincing sense of place.
The most amazing acting in The Departed comes from Mark Wahlberg, who completely transforms himself into the angry police sergeant he portrays.
Perfectly cast, but too mean spirited for me.
Daring rescues during wild storms at sea? Yes, but 'The Guardian' also features strong performances by Kevin Costner and Ashton Kutcher.
Instead of maintaining a mysterious tone to follow its suspenseful opening scenes, 'The Wicker Man' soon turns into something almost laughable.
Sequels are often disappointing, but 'Brother Bear 2' is a keeper, mostly because of its charming story and extraordinary background music.
'The Fountain' is a stunning, elegant movie. I found it hypnotic and almost painfully beautiful.
Joshua Jackson becomes a major screen presence with his sensitive and charismatic performance in 'Aurora Borealis,' a rare and memorable film.
Hugh Grant and Drew Barrymore, who generate great chemistry together, display impeccable comic timing in 'Music and Lyrics.'
Although extremely slow moving and hard to sit through, 'Catch and Release' focuses on characters who genuinely care about each other.
What could have been a fun movie falls victim to Mandy Moore's unfortunate miscasting.
'Underdog' features some amusing antics by a very cute Beagle in the title role, but it's not quite the treat I expected.
I feel extremely disappointed with a thriller when I can tell 'who done it' before the main suspense kicks in. 'I Know Who Killed Me' is that kind of movie."
For a movie musical fan like me, 'Hairspray' has it all --rousing song-and-dance routines, talented performers, a feel-good story, and timeless appeal.
Projecting great emotional depth, Daniel Radcliffe shows his growth as an actor in this most serious Harry Potter adventure so far.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: 'License To Wed' is a comedy fiasco.
'In Search of Mozart' shines the brightest when it showcases individual musicians playing Mozart. It's obvious how much this beautiful music means to them.
Remy, the rodent hero of Ratatouille, may not be as cute as Mickey Mouse, but he grows on you -- blue fur and all.
'Silver Surfer' features more eye-popping special effects than the first Fantastic 4 movie, but the story comes across like a Saturday morning kiddie cartoon.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Clooney and Pitt provide plenty of eye candy in 'Ocean's Thirteen,' but this third Ocean's adventure often seems incoherent and listless.
Some guest stars relate to Muppets better than others, but this second season sparkles with great music, funny skits and lovably bizarre characters.
One of the funniest movies ever made, 'Waiting for Guffman' spoofs everything from documentaries and talent shows to local politics and alien abductions.
Although 10 MPH ends up being a tribute to the dedication and resourcefulness of Weeks and Caldwell, its major charm comes from the individuals they meet in various communities during the trip.
Unexpected romance, amusing pratfalls and comic performances combine to make 'Wild Hogs' a rollicking good time at the movies.
As psychological thrillers go, 'Mr. Brooks' ranks above average because of Kevin Costner's riveting performance.
Incredible special effects and astonishing set pieces fill the screen in 'At World's End,' but it's Captain Jack Sparrow who steals the show again.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Yikes! '28 Weeks Later' is a very, very scary movie.
Unfortunately, the chemistry between Eric Bana and Drew Barrymore seems suprisingly bland in 'Lucky You.'
'ShowBusiness,' a fascinating behind-the-scenes documentary about Broadway, is a special treat for people who love musicals, whether live or onscreen.
Despite fine acting by Justin Chatwin and Margarita Levieva, 'The Invisible' ends up making no sense at all.
Watching Anthony Hopkins in 'Fracture' is like observing a master painter create a work of art.
Cavorting on the ice in their elaborate figure skating costumes, Will Ferrell and Jon Heder made me laugh so much my stomach ached.
Prone to migraine headaches, I wish the frenzied pace of 'Meet the Robinsons' had been toned down. Still, youngsters will probably love the ride.
'Disturbia' is a tight, suspenseful, well-acted thriller.
'Firehouse Dog' is sure to please most youngsters despite its silly scenes showing an Irish terrier's pampered life as a movie star.
While not boasting a very original plot, 'Shooter' provides a showcase for Mark Wahlberg's versatility as an actor.
Unfortunately, not even Sandra Bullock's ability to make us almost forget the ridiculous plot forced upon her can save 'Premonition.'
Abigail Breslin matches her Oscar-nominated work in Little Miss Sunshine with another brilliant performance in The Ultimate Gift.
If movies were only about acting, 'Bug' would win a high recommendation from me. Unfortunately, it contains too much talk and too little action.
What I expect from a thriller is that it keep me guessing while scaring the socks off me -- and 'Flightplan' passes this test with flying colors.
Some adults may not enjoy 'How To Eat Fried Worms.' But that doesn't matter: this one is strictly for the kids -- who will no doubt eat it up.
While the terrific closing number is something to cheer about, I wanted more dancing and less melodrama from 'Step Up.'
Despite 'bending it a little,' Steve Martin manages to capture the humorous essence of Inspector Clouseau's character.
A quirky, artistic triumph.
I don't like movies about bratty children, but 'Nanny McPhee' won me over completely.
Because 'Brokeback Mountain' has made such a profound impact on so many viewers, I almost feel guilty that I can't rave about it.
Not very exciting, but unexpected humor adds a couple of nice touches to this dysfunctional family/gender-bender/road trip movie.
'End of the Spear' features some intensely violent scenes, but this thought-provoking movie never falters in emphasizing the power of forgiveness.
Although Brosnan is terrific, the rest of this dark comedy fails to reach the level of his tour-de-force performance.
Intensely romantic and artistically photographed, 'Tristan & Isolde' is a welcome quality release during the January movie doldrums.
A clever animated film using 'Little Red Riding Hood' to poke fun at modern police dramas and mysteries.
What are acclaimed veteran actresses Doris Roberts, Shirley Jones and Shirley Knight doing in a movie like Grandma's Boy? They deserve better.
Three hours of magnificent escapist entertainment.
Finally, a Broadway gem made into a film that old-time movie musical fans like me can cheer about!
A movie with no heart or soul.
I wish 'Eight Below' had spent more time showing those wonderful dogs instead of including so many uninspired segments with human actors.
Jim Carrey is hilarious as a man who slowly goes insane when his American Dream turns into a nightmare.
Overly ambitious and too complicated.
Ironically, this film moves along rather slowly. But its leisurely pace gives us time to enjoy one of Anthony Hopkins' finest performances, so who's complaining?
Despite impressive sets, a fine cast and some eye-popping special effects, this sci-fi action movie doesn't always work -- mostly because visual gimmicks overcome plot and character development.
Sumptuously filmed and brilliantly acted, this new "Pride & Prejudice' is a cinematic gem.
Billed as a dark comedy, 'The Ice Harvest' contains little to laugh at. But it's packed with the elements fans of film noir enjoy -- sex, violence, money and betrayal
A surefire crowd pleaser.
Performances and images from 'Jarhead' will stay with you long after the houselights dim.
Although filled with amazing set pieces and a strong sense of adventure, 'Zathura' soon becomes annoying to watch because of almost continuous shouting by its young co-stars.
Not since 'Leaving Las Vegas' has a movie put me in such a deep funk.
A delightful screwball comedy about romance, mistaken identities -- and bingo.
The plot may be predictable, but 'Dreamer' is utterly irresisitible and definitely worth seeing.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Because I couldn't understand how the betting advisory business depicted in 'Two for the Money" operates, the movie didn't always work for me.
Just the sight of Susan Sarandon tap dancing at a hilarious memorial for her character's dead husband made 'Elizabethtown' worth seeing for me.
Ultra-contrived, but delivers an important message about tolerance.
With the exception of Anjelica Huston's regal supporting turn, 'Material Girls' is an immaterial movie.
Charming and nostalgic.
A harmless fantasy with obvious appeal to its target audience -- tween girls.
With his fearless comic approach, Will Ferrell manages to make Ricky Bobby one of his funniest film characters.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This one suffers from a bad case of predictability. It's also hard to believe, mostly because cast members look too old to be high school students.
A haunted house that's alive, uproots itself, and storms down the street on a rampage seems a bit over-stimulating for young children.
Uma Thurman is quite funny as she channels the anger from her 'Kill Bill' character and turns it into hilarious outbursts of superhero rage.
Forget those awful previews. 'You, Me and Dupree' is a rather sweet little movie focusing on friendship, love, life goals, and being true to oneself.
Johnny Depp's Jack Sparrow proves that an actor's awesome talent can make incredible special effects and funny action sequences pale in comparison.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Although inhabiting her character as seriously as humanly possible, Meryl Streep ends up being extremely amusing as haughty Miranda Priestly.
This is definitely not one of Sandler's best films -- no 'Wedding Singer' romantic sensitivity or 'Waterboy' innocent appeal emerges here.
It's a pleasure to watch James Franco and Tyrese Gibson square off against each other as two men heading for a showdown.
Jack Black's physical humor, poses and grimaces are showcased to the max in 'Nacho Libre,' and almost everything pays off.
Moving along like a turtle crossing the road, 'The Lake House' gave me a drowsy feeling that lasted all day. It was a real downer for me.
'A Prairie Home Companion' makes us laugh and care and cry with characters who never say die.
With its colorful circus setting and quirky characters, this short Disney movie is easy to like, but it's Dumbo himself who steals your heart.
While offering children a valuable lesson about friendship, 'Doogal' will probably be viewed by some adults as an opportunity for a little nap.
Although the twist ending surprised me, it makes perfect sense. But why this excellent thriller went straight to DVD makes no sense at all.
Filmmakers were lucky to pick the perfect co-stars for 'Just My Luck.'
Great scary atmosphere, but the film's loud sound effects, repetitive thrashing-about scenes, and overpowering music just about drove me nuts.
Jeff Bridges has never been better than he is here as a coach who uses authority, patience and humor to motivate the gymnasts in his charge.
Keke Palmer, Laurence Fishburne and Angela Bassett are absolutely fabulous in 'Akeelah and the Bee.' And so is this movie.
I could identify the mole in 'The Sentinel' the first time he appeared on camera. Don't you hate it when that happens in a movie?
Impressive animation, but too much d√©j√† vu here.
Savor the surprises.
Oozing old-school gentility and charm, Banderas fits the role of ballroom dance instructor Pierre Dulaine as if he were born to play it.
This gorgeous movie takes your breath away with its spectacular visual storytelling, but Tilda Swinton and Georgie Henley steal the show.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's all too predictable, so where's the suspense?
The immensely talented Amanda Bynes makes this updating of 'Twelfth Night' fun to watch.
Coal, the Bearded Collie playing Shaggy, upstages everyone in this amusing update of a Disney classic.
Features another stellar Johnny Depp performance, but stagy dialogue and dreary cinematography mar the effectiveness of this murky period drama.
The film's grungy setting promises more suspense and thrills than actually materialize on screen.
This is a terrific romantic comedy -- funny, tender and filled with sparkling performances.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Ben Affleck as Jack Ryan, Tom Clancy's intrepid hero? Ridiculous. What's next? D.J. Qualls as Indiana Jones? Or Tom Green as Han Solo?
I applaud the emphasis 'Cheaper by the Dozen' places on listening to your children -- no matter how busy you are with your personal goals.
It should provide a welcome fix for many horror film addicts.
Instead of quitting while he's way ahead, Costner takes on For Love of the Game, a melodramatic film version of Michael Shaara's novel.
Not since Mel Brooks' hilarious Blazing Saddles has there been such an outrageous Western as Shanghai Noon.
In addition to Hanks' superb acting, amazing cinematography by Don Burgess helps lift this movie above the ordinary.
It's just plain bewildering.
Like bread without yeast, 'Angela's Ashes' minus the author's wit can't rise to meet expectations.
Jolie enlivens every scene she's in --- so much so that whenever she's not on screen, many viewers go into a state of suspended animation waiting for her to come back.
It's a sin to miss 'The Apostle.'
This movie is filled with such nonsense.
Definitely worth seeing because of exciting scenes with Smith and Voight sparring verbally as Ali and Cossell.
A creative, amusing treat for the whole family.
Here's a sure-fire recipe for a bad movie.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Exuding a self-deprecating charm that's hard to resist, Grant captivates the audience immediately as the film's narrator.
Filled with heroism, humor and heart, this wonderful film is a treat for the entire family.
One of the most amusing satires of the year.
Displaying the same powerful charisma that won him rave reviews as Wolverine in X-Men, Jackman simply ignites the screen in all his scenes.
How lucky can moviegoers get? Three Brendan Fraser movies this year!
Although Pitt's acting brilliance comes through loud and clear in his most unsympathetic role to date, Fight Club belongs to Norton.
I couldn't help wishing I were watching that obscure little children's fantasy instead. As I recall, it's a lot funnier and more frightening than Scary Movie.
The Cell is not just another serial killer flick. Despite its horrific theme and graphic violence, it's a stunning work of art.
Scott's cinematic fiction captivated me as completely as its title character won the soul of Rome.

Although Bay's 45-minute sequence showing continuous bombing, strafing, torpedoing, and exploding of the U.S. Pacific fleet packs a devastating wallop of sight and sound, the rest of the movie fails to ignite similar excitement.
It's another movie where teenage girls look like a bunch of unfeeling idiots or worse.
Gadzooks! Methinks I witnessed the World Series of Jousting in A Knight's Tale and actually enjoyed every minute of it.
Never has so much talent been wasted in such cinematic chaos.
Farfetched as it seems, Little Nicky emerges as a comic tribute to filial loyality.
A subversive, wickedly funny film.
One of Spielberg's most thought-provoking efforts.
A timely comedy that pokes fun at all things Hollywood.
It's obvious there's enough material here for several movies.
First-time director J. B. Rogers and new screenwriters Peter Gualke and Jerry Swallow appear determined to include as many gross-out scenes as possible at the expense of telling a believable story.
With "O Brother,' the Coens have reached near perfection again, and that's something to sing about.
Get a good night's rest and take plenty of vitamins before seeing 'U-571.' Otherwise, you'll be wiped out by the end of this superb action thriller.
Those dreaded Raptors are back with a vengeance in Jurassic Park III. More bad news -- they've brought along even more deadly friends.
As a result of its breathtaking visual effects, Dinosaur is a landmark film.
A ho-hum heist film.
Relentless yelling by two usually fine actors spoils this timely crime drama.
A movie whose few imperfections never detract from its elegant characters and intriguing plot.
The movie's visual artstry amazed me.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: An enduring masterpiece -- one of the best films ever made.
Almost gags on its own gore.
Features gruesome scenes that go too far, even for a horror movie. And I missed Jodie Foster!
Just when you thought it was safe to see another Adam Sandler movie, along comes Big Daddy.
It's Travolta who provides the movie's special treat.
A remarkable study of obsessive filmmaking that ranks as one of the best movies of the year.
Shrouded in ugliness despite brilliant performances by Bening and Spacey.
Although the action movie is the last bastion of the male star, Charlie's Angels should change all that.
What could be more amusing than a bunch of sex-obsessed teenagers? Almost anything.
An impressive and original bit of storytelling.
Josie and the Pussycats urges teenagers to be individuals instead of herd-like consumers. Ironically, in doing so, it contains more product placements than any movie I've ever seen.
The stunning look of this film took my breath away and overcame its shortcomings for me.
Billed as a comedy, Wonder Boys is about as amusing as a driver's license exam.
In another compelling performance, Billy Crudup projects the charisma of a rock star -- combining egotism with flashes of humanity.
This new Jack the Ripper film arrives just in time for Halloween.
Inspired pairing of Susan Sarandon and Natalie Portman as an outrageous mother and her more practical daughter.
Is it too much to ask for reasonable explanations of human behavior in a psychological thriller?
Call me sacrilegious, but I believe most of the story changes worked very well here.
I was disappointed with its overly sentimental tone and rather questionable message. Are married men with children actually more deserving of happiness than single guys? According to this movie, yes.
Director Ron Howard's movie version of the popular Dr. Seuss classic creates a world of wonder and enchantment for kids of all ages. I found myself captivated by everything about it.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Although gadgets galore almost overwhelm the film's characters and plot, this whimsical spoof of spy thrillers offers plenty of fun for the whole family.
I'm eagerly awaiting a sequel.
Its visual thrills and solid performances combine to make it an above average film treat.
The franchise cometh.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, Elliott's latest effort contained too many blanks for me to fill in.
Opulent Parisian mansions, gorgeous Napoleonic era costumes, and artistic cinematography wowed me almost as much as those dynamic performances by Jim Caviezel and Guy Pearce.
Wonder of wonders -- a teen movie with a humanistic message.
Chris Rock stoops to a feet-don't-fail-me-now acting level reminiscent of stereotypical African-American portrayals in films of the 30s and 40s.
Hard to top for pure shock value and raw human emotion depicted on screen.
Jason Lee looks almost beatific as the shaggy, homeless Puggy. This movie is just as hilarious as Dave Barry's quirky book.
What puzzles me is the lack of emphasis on music in Britney Spears' first movie.
It's a hoot watching The Rock chomp on jumbo ants, pull an arrow out of his back, and leap unscathed through raging fire!
That sound you hear is me -- still applauding Frank Darabont's nostalgic look at movies, patriotism, and the human condition.
Gets better after Foster leaves that little room.
A new type of role here for the great Morgan Freeman, who plays Grimes like a senior Hell's Angel on valium.
Most of the action (and I use the term loosely) is seen from the eyes of the servants, then discussed ad nauseam.
This jumbled mess drove me to therapy.
Sadness engulfs the people in this provocative drama like a dense fog, leaving them with little sense of direction or purpose except trying to get by each day. Stunning performances!
Supporting cast members Chris Cooper, Brian Cox, and Clive Owen manage to convince me of their villainy without pulling out all the stops like 007's adversaries.
Although technically superb, this film left me exhausted, confused, and angry.

Leave it to John Sayles to take on developers, the Chamber of Commerce, tourism, historical pageants, and commercialism all in the same movie . . . without neglecting character development for even one minute.
Unlike most films about the supernatural, this spellbinding psychological thriller creates suspense through character-development and atmosphere, not by relying on creepy special effects.
Oo la la! Sheer cinematic artistry . . . an outrageously creative film.
Manfred, Sid, and Diego demonstrate the old Ice Age adage that a friend is someone who knows all your faults and likes you just the same.
Practically everything about Sam's friends comes across as too cute and condescending.
Raunchy dialogue and sexually explicit sequences overshadow the film's slight hint that factors other than sex might also be important in human relationships.
This whimsical film offers compelling proof that magic and movies go together like ABRA and CADABRA.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Anyone who wants to join my newly formed Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Iris Murdoch's Memory (SPCIMM), please contact me immediately.
I fear viewers who usually avoid action/fantasy flicks might pass up this terrific film without knowing it has so much other neat stuff going on.
Ewan McGregor simply oozes wisdom and integrity as Obi-Wan Kenobi.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: With its splendid combination of comedy, drama and sense of place, 'The Mystic Masseur' charmed me completely. I didn't want this film to end.
J-Lo strikes back in a tense and thrilling revenge flick with the best fight scene so far this year. But I couldn't help feeling guilty over my delight at the brutal way 'Enough' ended.
I particularly enjoyed the mystery presented in 'Decaying Orbit,' a sci-fi film that plays like an Agatha Christie story set in outer space.
An amusing time-travel theme plus Hugh Jackman in his dashing Duke's uniform and Meg Ryan looking as perky as ever -- what more could incurable romantics ask for?
Those horses are as attractive as promised, but the film's snail-like plot caused me to lose interest early on.
Pretentious camera tricks and confusing flashbacks overshadow fine performances.
'The Rookie' charmed me with its old-fashioned family values, down-to-earth-characters, and nostalgic small town atmosphere.
Unfortunately, dear grown-ups, no end to the Pok√©mon invasion seems imminent.
movie_title: Pokemon the First Movie - Mewtwo vs. Mew (1999)

movie_review_blurb: [Minghella] certainly deserves kudos for including those stunning location shots as well as such incredibly haunting background music. And, of course, for casting the talented Mr. Damon.
Three cheers for Bring It On.
Cleese may only be in a few scenes, but he adds his unique humor to the film, giving moviegoers something to look forward to in the next Bond adventure.
The film's glorification of auto theft is a bit disturbing.
movie_title: Gone in 60 Seconds (Gone in Sixty Seconds) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: A chilling indictment of the eighties.
Lack of a sympathetic main character is only one of the film's many faults.
The importance of friendship and true love are explored with unusual sensitivity in scenes between Shrek and Fiona and between Donkey and Shrek.
The Blair Witch Project taps into primitive beliefs about the supenatural in a way not tried before by traditional filmmakers.
If you enjoy ghost stories, don't miss this one.
I probably should stay away from any movie with a video game as its source.
It contains too many repetitive scenes.
'Tortilla Soup' gives Hector Elizondo the right recipe for his first starring role in a feature film.

As John Nash, Russell Crowe projects the 'warts-and-all' persona of a genius trying to conquer mental illness. But I can't help reacting negatively to most biopics. I never know what's real and what's made-up -- kinda like Nash himself.
The universal theme of becoming a better person through love has never been filmed more irresistibly than in 'Baran.'
'Dragonfly' dwells on crossing-over mumbo jumbo, manipulative sentimentality, and sappy dialogue.
Harrison Ford's strong performance is sabotaged by the film's unnecessary political gibes and a schmaltzy tacked-on ending.
I love the opening scenes of a wintry New York City in 1899. Cinematic poetry showcases the city's old-world charm before machines change nearly everything.
Steve Irwin is an outrageous combination of St. Francis of Assisi and Indiana Jones -- with a touch of Dr. Dolittle thrown in for good measure.
'Ah-nuld' finally shows his age -- and brings maturity to the role of a man reeling from personal tragedy.
A ROYAL pain. It made me squirm instead of laugh.
Plot assumes little importance here. It's those amazing creatures that count!
Bow Wow wows 'em.
No comedy classic, but the Farrelly Brothers are on the right track here by bringing heart into their filmmaking. 'Shallow Hal's' deep message surprised me.
What would I do if I inherited forty billion dollars? First of all, buy out Adam Sandler's contract and put him in more movies like 'The Wedding Singer.'
Is there a group of more self-absorbed women than the mother and daughters featured in this film? I don't think so. Nothing wrong with performances here, but the whiney characters bugged me.
With his big sad eyes, Andrej Chalimon pulls us lovingly and completely into Kolya's life. He's simply perfect as a little Russian refugee in this poignant movie treasure.
For his first attempt at film noir, Spielberg presents a fascinating but flawed look at the near future.
This third Austin Powers adventure deserves to be his last.
'Big Fish,' my top-ranked film of 2003, not only charmed me completely with its humanity and whimsical humor -- it also surprised me with its wisdom.
Football ends racism? Yeah, right.
Although it's difficult to imagine writing as a dramatic activity, Connery makes it seem so in the challenging role of a reclusive novelist mentoring a gifted student.
With her dynamic dancing and singing, Catherine Zeta-Jones emerges as a force of nature in this killer musical.
Because of movies like this, nostalgia just ain't what it used to be.
How sad to hear Oscar winners Hopkins and Gooding,Jr. utter melodramatic dialogue during most of their scenes together.
Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan have a ball portraying a mother and daughter who are forced to swap bodies in this surprisingly entertaining remake.
Those incredible animals steal the show here -- just like in 'Babe.'
This Lara Croft sequel really surprised me. It's the most exciting action/adventure flick I've seen since 'The Mummy.'
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of the ultra-sophisticated John Steed and Emma Peel, we get Ralph Fiennes and Uma Thurman, who come across more like contestants in a "cutest couple" contest.
A cross between 'Eyes Wide Shut' and 'A Beautiful Mind' -- but more compelling than either.
Although not an easy film to follow, I found 'Ararat' worthy of close attention.
A thinking person's romantic comedy -- but, hey, don't let that frighten you away. It's also lots of fun.
Boasts enough originality and excellent performances to merit a look-see, especially from fans who love 'heist-gone-bad' flicks.
It's a mishmash -- but at times wonderful to behold.
Although Ford and Hartnett share some amusing moments as mismatched partners, that's not enough to save this disappointing buddy/cop flick.
Brittany Murphy pulls off a few slapstick sight gags here, but nothing to compare with her hilarious pratfalls in 'Just Married.'
A suspenseful and inspiring documentary.
Visually stunning? Absolutely! But I found the film's plodding pace relentlessly annoying.
Jim Carrey gets the chance to shine in funny and serious scenes as he cavorts through 'Bruce Almighty'-- and he's got the power to do both.
Kudos to Eddie Murphy for adopting a more low-key approach in 'Daddy Day Care' and for letting his fine supporting cast get most of the laughs.
A visual triumph for filmmaker Emanuele Crialese. And why not? Who could go wrong with a movie featuring gorgeous Valeria Golino on a sun-drenched island?
This clever mockumentary pokes fun at performance art, media frenzy, criminal investigation techniques, and celebrity cults -- and I loved every minute of it!
Although the first part of 'Identity' overflows with delicious suspense and creepy atmosphere, the film's plot soon becomes one of its helpless victims.
Alive with a sense of place, 'Off the Map' evoked for me the same wondrous feelings I had while watching 'To Kill a Mockingbird' and 'Shane.'
Unconvincing and dull -- two adjectives I never expected to use in connection with any movie from Neil LaBute, who usually lives up to his reputation as 'film's shock jock.'
I couldn't stop laughing and tapping my feet throughout most of this hilarious mockumentary.
Unlike so many recent movies, 'Returning Mickey Stern' doesn't telegraph how things are going to turn out -- and that's refreshing.
'Equilibrium' succeeds primarily because of Christian Bale's uncanny ability to project the awakening soul of the character he portrays.
Choppy editing and too many repetitive scenes spoil what could have been an important documentary about stand-up comedy.
Because Amanda Bynes and Colin Firth portray the rambunctious daughter and stuffy father so engagingly, this romantic fairy tale charmed me completely.
It's not often a young actress takes over the screen as forcefully as Keisha Castle-Hughes does in this compelling New Zealand drama.
With its twists and turns almost spinning out of control, 'Basic' kept me guessing about whodunit until the very last second.
Hugh Grant's witty delivery of throwaway lines and Sandra Bullock's clumsy sincerity appeal to me. I hope their first on-screen pairing isn't their last.
Religious thrillers usually leave me cold, but 'The Order's' moral dilemmas -- highlighted by Ledger's intense performance -- really got to me.
In 'Dirty Pretty Things,' filmmakers weave complex story threads into a cinematic tapestry of fear, suspense and compassion.
The film's social-issue exaggeration, numerous stereotypes, and unfinished sub-plots prove insurmountable for its talented cast.
Paul Giamatti seems to crawl into Harvey Pekar's skin. While not resembling Pekar physically, he's got that curmudgeonly attitude down pat.
If you've seen the previews, you've already watched the best parts of 'Something's Gotta Give.'
Charlotte Rampling's superb performance and the film's artistic, enigmatic ending will haunt me for a long time to come.
A little gem of a movie.
Based on the novel by Tracy Chevalier, 'Girl with a Pearl Earring' may not be a true story, but it emerges as true cinematic art.
At the end of 'Bad Santa,' redemption comes for its foul-mouthed main character -- but not for the movie itself.
Gavin Heffernan's 'Expiration' boasts a unique cinematic style and introduces an impressive new filmmaker.
'Gothika' drove me back to therapy.
Much like rhythm and melody complement each other in a fine composition, artistry and history come together in this splendid documentary about the great Armenian composer.
movie_title: Khachaturian: A Musician and His Fatherland (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Ferrell's uncanny ability to project an all-consuming Christmas joy carries the day.
Johnny Depp's roguish Jack Sparrow is every bit as unforgettable as his squeamish Ichabod Crane in 'Sleepy Hollow.'
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Raunchy musical numbers and demeaning stereotypes overwhelm the film's feeble attempts at social satire about censorship and cultural diversity.
With Love Actually, first-time director Richard Curtis has given adult moviegoers a joyous Holiday treat.
An ambitious and moving film.
Blanchett's brilliant performance captures the essence of this brave, brash Irish icon.
Clooney is as watchable here as Cary Grant or Clark Gable in their prime, and Zeta-Jones exudes a glamour-gal sexiness reminiscent of Rita Hayworth.
Do I feel cheated by having to buy another movie ticket to see how 'Kill Bill' ends? You betcha.
My only complaint? 'Down with Love' should have been a musical.
With a performance of such depth and beauty it overshadows the film's gorgeous Italian scenery, Diane Lane owns the screen in 'Under the Tuscan Sun.'
That sound you hear is me -- still applauding Jack Black's wildly hilarious tour de force in School of Rock.
I found this movie fascinating -- but not an easy one to sit through. It's seems excruciatingly real.
A bungle in the jungle.
Kate Hudson's impressive comic flair almost saves this implausible romantic comedy.
movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The first movie this year to deliver sheer musical pleasure from beginning to end.
Schmaltzy? Absolutely. But in the hands of three exceptional actors, Secondhand Lions is totally entertaining and heartwarming. I'm adding it to my best-of-year list.
Antonio Banderas took my breath away again. Sleek and swift as a panther, he projects the charisma and magnetism of an old-time movie star.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Smothered in jumpy camera work, out-of-focus scenes and excessively lurid material, 'In the Cut' ends up being as lifeless as the victims of its easy-to-spot serial killer.
Plot and performances are buried beneath special effects in 'Tomb Raider.'
Not everything about this movie worked for me, but I loved its colorful costumes as well as Paltrow's appealing performance.
A worthy story marred by too much dark cinematography and sketchy character development.
Interacting eyeball-to-eyeball and toe-to-toe, Hopkins and Norton are a winning combination -- but Fiennes steals 'Red Dragon' right from under their noses.
Despite a few distracting cinematic touches, Oliver Parker's 'Earnest' effort is a joy to watch -- and to hear.
As an avid Jackie Chan fan, I always look forward to watching his unique martial arts comedy. Sadly, in this case it's more Kung Phooey than Kung Fu.
I'm in a deep funk after watching this offensive, unfunny comedy starring two of my favorite actresses.
Not as visually awesome as 'Princess Mononoke,' but more appealing to youngsters. A wonderful combination of simplicity and spectacle.
'Stealing Harvard' robbed me of 82 valuable minutes I'll never get back.
Because of an unnecessary and clumsy last scene, 'Swimfan' left me with a very bad feeling.
A film of pure delight from beginning to end.
Cedric the Entertainer is absolutely hilarious as a frustrated boss.
Intriguing Old-West-meets-Space-Age atmosphere, but lame attempts at humor mount up and lie there, unappreciated, like a plate of overcooked spaghetti.
It's not difficult to spot the culprit early-on in this predictable thriller.
A witty coming-of-middle-age comedy with hilarious performances by first-time director Tony Shalhoub and wife Brooke Adams.
Incredible creatures and gadgets steal this show. I felt like a kid again while watching it!
movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: I'm shocked at the depth of cruelty Pfeiffer projects here as a manipulative mother. She actually frightened me!
Reminiscent of Alfred Hitchcock's thrillers, most of the scary parts in 'Signs' occur while waiting for things to happen.
A charming romantic fantasy with delicious performances by the entire cast.
Watching Michael Caine and Sandra Bullock interact testily with each other is this film's special treat.
Devilishly funny.
A steamy, dreamy bit of filmmaking.
Magical realism spins out of control in 'Woman on Top.'
After a promising opening, the film meanders so much I thought it would never end.
A contrived script and lackluster performances are the worst sins of this uninspired comedy.
A unique Australian comedy that puts big budget films to shame.
Nothing prepared me for the painful experience of watching 'Monkeybone.'
Surprisingly, Wahlberg's 'Rock Star' mesmerized me right along with all those screaming fans and sexy groupies depicted in the film.
'Moonlight Mile' is a film of considerable substance. Sarandon, Hoffman, and Gyllenhaal give brilliant performances as people grieving over the loss of a loved one.
Although Lopez projects her usual charisma here, McConaughey seems as out of place as Will Rogers playing Rhett Butler.
Ethan Steifel's unforgettable dancing seems to defy the laws of gravity -- and without computerized special effects.
Duchovny and Jones play off each other with excellent comic timing.

Susan Sarandon finally came into her own as a first-rate actress in this poignant 1981 Louis Malle film. She and Burt Lancaster create movie magic together. Well-deserved Oscar nominations (her first, his last) resulted from their outstanding work here.
Morality takes a beating in 'Auto Focus,' a film more suitable for stag parties than for multiplexes.
With 'Bowling for Columbine,' Michael Moore gives us the perfect starting point for a national conversation about guns, violence, and fear.
Kurt Russell will be tough to beat during the next Oscar race. He's at the top of his game in 'Dark Blue.'
Will Ferrell is as funny as ever here, but this 'don't-act-your-age' comedy would be almost a total disaster without him.
'Final Destination 2' exploits the universal fear of death -- but it does so with a creepy, creative flair.
Hooray for Jackie Chan and Owen Wilson! In Shanghai Knights, they emerge again as one of filmdom's most watchable duos.
There's a lot of noise and blurry action in 'Darkness Falls' -- like the start of my worst migraines.
One of the most fascinating documentaries a movie fan could ever hope to see.
My skin crawls just thinking about the rage inside Li'l Dice, who becomes the most feared drug dealer in Rio de Janeiro.
I have nightmares about being forced to sit through 'Mary Reilly' one more time.
Clumsily funny!
Even Pinocchio himself would pan this flick.
A provocative thriller filmed with unique visual flair. Bravo!
Humorous and heartfelt, Douglas McGrath's version of 'Nicholas Nickleby' left me feeling refreshed and hopeful. Not many movies have that kind of impact on me these days.
Truth is stranger than fiction, so the old saying goes. In 'Catch Me If You Can,' it's also more entertaining.
Anyone who gets chills from movies with giant plot holes will find plenty to shake and shiver about in 'The Ring.'
Awesome creatures, breathtaking scenery, and epic battle scenes add up to another 'spectacular spectacle.'
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: 'Dear God' commits the worst sin of all for a comedy -- it evokes very few laughs.
Provides the kind of 'laugh therapy' I need from movie comedies -- offbeat humor, amusing characters, and a happy ending. After seeing 'Analyze That,' I feel better already.
'They' begins and ends with scenes so terrifying I'm still stunned. And I've decided to leave a light on every night from now on.
There's a visual freshness to 007's latest outing. Those gorgeous Iceland sequences blew me away.
The film offered Jolie her first opportunity to star in a comedic role, and it proves she should stick to drama.
Almost operatic in its execution, 'Talk to Her' packs quite an emotional wallop.
The casting of Raymond J. Barry as the 'assassin' greatly enhances the quality of Neil Burger's impressive fake documentary.
De Palma's new thriller almost ends up as a parody -- largely because of a miscast female lead.
Young Everlyn Sampi, as the courageous Molly Craig, simply radiates star-power potential in this remarkable and memorable film.
My all-time favorite film -- I never get tired of watching Gene, Debbie, and Donald perform those incredibly exuberant musical numbers! A true classic.
Visually, 'Santa Clause 2' is wondrously creative.
The chemistry between Mark Wahlberg and Thandie Newton generates a mere tingle -- not even close to those exciting sparks between Cary Grant and Audrey Hepburn.
Using her exceptional talent for creating stunning images, director Julie Taymor has put together a cinematic experience with the power to match Frida Kahlo's colorful life.
Brosnan's finest non-Bondish performance yet fails to overcome the film's manipulative sentimentality and annoying stereotypes.
Most of the time while watching 'Rush Hour 3,' I couldn't help longing for another one of those hilarious Jackie Chan/Owen Wilson 'Shanghai' movies.
The clich√© 'edge of your seat' seems too mild for this exciting outer space thriller that combines technical magic with strong emotional pull.
Humorously narrated by cult filmmaker John Waters, Plagues & Pleasures on the Salton Sea evokes both laughter and tears.
movie_title: Plagues & Pleasures on the Salton Sea (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An inspiring and powerful documentary urging women to 'accept the rise of feminine energy' in to order solve the many crises facing our modern world.
Like Disney's 'Mary Poppins,' 'Saving Mr. Banks' is pure movie magic. It's the most captivating film of 2013 for me.
'Her' offers a mind-bending look at love and loneliness in the near future.
A very long three hours of scenery-chewing performances plus repetitive sequences emphasizing drugs, sex and greed.
Thanks to director Jon Turtletaub, 'Last Vegas' moves along briskly and to writer Don Fogelman for an amusing screenplay that challenges those dreadful 'senior citizen' stereotypes.
To me, a film about Las Vegas should never be boring. And that's what disappoints me most about 'Paradise.'
A poignant drama about loss, friendship, family and true love. It's a slow-moving -- but beautiful -- film with performances that go straight to your heart.
An excellent cast and the film's authentic period look help transport us back to 1880s New Mexico while watching a very angry woman out for revenge.
This incredible documentary about rescuing 25 abused African lions and transporting them from Bolivia to Colorado is the feel-good movie of the year for me!
This sci-fi thriller makes us almost feel the frosty cold in our bones, thanks to cinematographer Pierce Gill's magic touch.
'Mr. Nobody' jumps around in a rather haphazard way, so it seems too chaotic most of the time. It's creative, but quite perplexing.
Although the ending of 'Prisoners' may leave some viewers cold, I think it's a clever way to make us keep talking about this thriller for a long time to come.
The chemistry between Josh Pais and Allison Janney is something wonderful to behold in each of their scenes together here. Too bad they had so few of them.
Although both lead actresses deserve praise for their stunning performances in 'Passion,' the film itself doesn't do them justice.
A chilling thriller with first-rate performances by John Cusack, Nicolas Cage and Vanessa Hudgens.
The characters may seem real, yet they're not very interesting. And worst of all, the beer flows but the movie doesn't.
Paul Bettany turns in a stellar performance as a modern day Raskolnikov in this gritty psychological drama about the downfall of a British police family.
'Elysium' goes overboard with loud, jerky, repetitive action sequences.
This Wolverine outing includes one of the most exciting sequences of the year -- a villain and Wolverine fighting on top of Japan's high-speed bullet train. How cool is that!
By trying too hard to be profound about the evils of television, this implausible sci-fi morality tale stretches this theme beyond the breaking point.
'Living Out Loud' presents the delightful surprise of Danny DeVito as a romantic lead. And he also sings!
Johnny Depp and Armie Hammer project a humorous chemistry with each other while portraying Tonto and the Lone Ranger. But Silver runs away with this rollicking Western action comedy.
With its suspenseful plot and a dream cast starring five fascinating actresses (plus Eric Roberts in a deliciously unsympathetic role), this unusual comedy is irresistible.
With its sluggish pace and awkward continuity, 'Crazy in Alabama' emerged as one of the most disappointing films released in 1999.
Although a bit too gory for me and difficult to follow at times, the film also boasts some gorgeous visuals as well as intriguing characters played by Ethan Juan and Xiaoming Huang.
A timely and important movie...I've enjoyed Norman Reedus' excellent work in TV's THE WALKING DEAD, but I think he's even better here.
So many situations and plot points seem too sketchy here, but the two main characters manage to intrigue us, thanks to Andrea Riseborough and Clive Owen.
Gorgeous scenes along the Cornish coast are impressive, but the film lacks the dynamic chemistry between lovers that's so important in a romance-themed movie.
