Both Chris Pine and Kevin Costner shine in their interaction scenes as mentor and mentee. The initial meeting of their characters is especially well done.
With such a promising theme and a funny lead actor like Simon Pegg, this movie should be a big hit. So what went wrong? I think the film just got out of control.
'Winter's Tale' may not be the easiest film to follow, but it's one of the most visually stunning.
Top-notch performances, exceptional cinematography, and masterful direction combine to make this film something special indeed.
Although inspirational and thought-provoking, 'Wild' is gruellng to watch. But powerful performances by Reese Witherspoon and Laura Dern won me over completely.
A stunning look at the beauty and challenges of Earth's most mysterious continent.
Ghosts, nightmares and Voodoo -- that's horrortainment to me, and 'Jessabelle' passes the test.
Although starting with a titillating concept and intriguing opening scenes, the story then goes downhill, and those silly looking horns don't help.
Too slow-moving for a thriller, but the film's shocking twist ending makes it almost worth waiting for.
Without even one fast-paced car chase or explosive special effects scene, this elegant thriller fills the screen with exquisite suspense.
Crazy, colorful costumes and art direction plus some exciting special effects make a few scenes notable, but too much of the movie seems repetitive and ultra-confusing.
Just like Kevin Kline's recent 'The Last of Robin Hood,' this well-made dramedy boasts a perfect acting trifecta.
Kevin Kline doesn't just play Errol Flynn here. He becomes Flynn. Not the early heartthrob, but Flynn in his later years after the booze and legendary philandering have taken their toll.
Susan Sarandon delivers a splendid performance as a world-weary detective in this mysterious, suspenseful thriller.
Despite too much jerky camera work, 'Ironclad 2' boasts lots of action and a stirring background score. Plus, its cup runneth over with medieval blood and gore.
Although the actors and setting seem believable here, 'Beneath' ends up being much too predictable for a horror movie.
This unusual coming-of-age comedy boasts excellent character development and involving performances. It's a promising feature movie debut for filmmaker Kate Melville.
'Rage' ends up as a bloody cautionary tale about how revenge served hot can backfire. It also reminds us that violence breeds violence. Not a bad message in today's world.
Each of the players comes across as a one-note stereotype with the same kind of behavior going on in practically every scene.
The most impressive thing about this wonderful film involves its creative presentation. Practically every scene comes across like an intriguing work of art.
Wolverine gets lots of camera time, visual effects look stunning, the time-travel theme is intriguing -- though sometimes confusing - and HOPE emerges as the film's appealing message.
This new Godzilla is definitely worth waiting for! His looks, roars and stomps seem incredibly real, which helps make 'Godzilla' (2014) a thrilling film ride.
Firth demonstrates flawless comic timing and a knack for gentle slapstick during many sequences that might have bombed with another actor playing Harry Deane.
Kristen Wiig delivers a splendid dramatic performance here. She simply becomes a plain, unobtrusive woman with immense inner strength.
Although slow-moving and confusing at times, 'Transcendence' impressed me as a haunting, thought-provoking film.
Predictability stands out as the most horrific thing about 'Stage Fright.' Still, there's lots of blood for horror fans and a couple of musical numbers that are fun to watch.
Full of clever surprises, '13 Sins' entertains and horrifies. Well-done!
One of the few films I regret seeing. But it definitely lives up to the title -- and gives viewers an ending we'll never forget.
This latest Muppet movie comes across as one of the best. Happily, that special Muppet magic is still going strong!
Thanks to director Arie Posin and cinematographer Antonio Riestra, the camera lingers on Annette Bening's expressive face, which draws viewers into her character's emotional journey.
With its wonderful songs, spectacular animation, and heartwarming story, 'Frozen' ranks right up there with 'Beauty and the Beast and 'The Little Mermaid' in the Disney pantheon.
An extraordinary documentary about a man of great talent and courage who used his love of movies and way with words to become one of our most beloved and influential film critics.
Julianne Moore excels in this amusing comedy about a flawed heroine who loses all sense of perspective but deserves a happy ending anyway.
'Erased' has excellent thriller potential -- but those dysfunctional father/daughter interactions interfere with what I expect from this genre.

John Cusack's usual clipped way of talking serves him well in the role of a disillusioned black ops agent. He's also convincing in the film's gunplay sequences and in his guarded interaction with others.
I recommend 'Breathless' for non-squeamish thriller fans, but the amount of blood and gore on display may be way beyond what even those brave viewers can imagine.
A talky 'culture-clash' comedy that's more annoying than funny.
Will Ferrell and Zach Galifianakis commit funny political mayhem in this outrageous comedy.
Enormously entertaining!
Some fine performances here, but the film seems too jumbled and pointless.
John Cleese upstages everyone as an arrogant New York hotel manager. His zany dancing in women's clothes brings back memories of those Monty Python silly walks sketches.
'The Magic of Belle Isle' may not be magical, but many Morgan Freeman fans will probably enjoy his droll, loquacious performance in this uneven offering.
Michelle Williams appears to put her heart and soul into her portrayal of a restless wife who falls for a handsome neighbor and feels tremendous guilt about it.
Princess Merida comes across as quite fascinating to watch. It would be fun to see a sequel about how she matures as a leader.
A promising cast fails to save this period downer.
A treasure chest of information about the early days of filmmaking and the contributions of 'America's Sweetheart' to the history of cinema.
movie_title: Mary Pickford: The Muse of the Movies (2008)

movie_review_blurb: 'A Necessary Death' treats the topic of sucide in a disturbing yet creative way. This is a shocking, emotionally powerful film.
A must-see documentary for anyone interested in becoming a Major League baseball player.
Leaving behind any trace of her eye-candy image, Jessica Biel delivers the performance of her career in 'The Tall Man.'
I'm still in a state of shock over being bored while watching a Johnny Depp flick.
An overdose of sentimentality that ends up being painful to watch.
Jenna Fischer and Chris Messina generate sweet chemistry together as two lonely people who find each other during stressful times in their lives.
Bill Murray projects a seriocomic intensity here comparable to Charlie Chaplin's classic Little Tramp.
Despite impressive performances by three young actresses, 'The Moth Diaries' lacks sufficient scare power.
In a movie like this, almost everything depends on the lead actor -- and Stephen Dorff does not disappoint. He turns in a splended 'confined' performance here.
Worry, worry and watch the clock, for 'In Time' wastes what time you've got.
What fools these mortals be -- especially anyone who passes up Michael Hoffman's highly entertaining version of Shakespeare's famous comedy.
You know a film must be special when it stays with you for days after seeing it. 'The Hunter' is one of those movies for me.
A disappointing thriller with some key scenes too dark to decipher. Still, Halle Berry and Olivier Martinez make an intriguing couple on screen, and they both look great.
Adrien Brody has never been better. He makes the most of his role as a man afraid of emotional entanglements and yet drawn into them during his latest teaching assignment.
Walter Matthau makes a captivating and very funny Albert Einstein in this romantic comedy about the iconic scientist playing Cupid for his niece.
Poor Woody Harrelson. Here he is with a great role in 'Rampart,' and the movie turns out to be about as messy as one can get, through no fault of his own.
Three fun stars seem to be enjoying the ride in this fast-paced romantic romp.
A clever comedy filled with satirical humor and perceptive social commentary.
Unfortunately, the miscasting of a key role in 'Big Eyes' makes many scenes appear unreal.
Don't worry, 'Bridesmaids.' This latest wedding hijinks comedy ends up as a silly rip-off that tries to capitalize on your success. But you're still Number One!
This hard-hitting documentary issues a wake-up call for safety improvements in all sports where head injuries are common.
Gorgeous cinematography by Emmanuel Lubezki almost makes 'To the Wonder' worth seeing. Unfortunately, director/writer Terrence Malick fails to flesh out this drama with a plot we can follow.
Romance, comedy, adventure and charm come through loud and clear in this highly entertaining remake.
Despite its great cast, this murky thriller disappoints because of a lack of cohesiveness and less than stellar production values.
Although not perfect, 'Hunky Dory' offers much to admire. For example, the film's glorious finale almost took my breath away.
Imagine my surprise at feeling some of the same thrills while watching this 3D prequel as I do every time I see 'The Wizard of Oz,' one of filmdom's masterpieces.
This ambitious desert epic may be a bit slow and confusing at the beginning, but I found the exciting second half of the movie worth waiting for.
Interesting settings and costumes plus plus weird ghostly stuff can't save this fantasy romance. Still, Alden Ehrenreich and Alice Englert seem sincere and committed to their co-starring roles here.
The predictability of this romantic comedy co-starring Julia Roberts and Richard Gere in no way detracts from its humorous charm.
'A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III' is billed as a comedy, but I think that must be a mistake. I kept waiting for the laughs to come - and no luck.
movie_title: A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The chemistry between Sandler and Barrymore is something special to see here, and I think 'The Wedding Singer' ends up being Sandler's best movie.
At a time when big screens reek with violence, explosions, and torture, it's refreshing to see 'Quartet' deliver a message about the value of friends, music and love -- at any age.
After the lengthy torture scenes, procedural repetition takes over until the murkily-filmed Seal Team 6 raid. But Jessica Chastain is quite convincing as a CIA operative dedicated to her job.
This eco-thriller's message is an important one, but there are too many slow-moving scenes and too much screen time with characters just staring at each other.
'Butter' took me by surprise. I wasn't expecting much, but it turned out to be a movie filled with humor, heart and art. It's one of my favorites this year.
The first half of 'Django Unchained' boasts some of the most entertaining filmmaking of 2012 -- or perhaps of any year.
Pretty soapy -- and not even a very exciting soap opera. But perhaps a less-than-stellar Masterpiece Theatre production would be a better comparison.
'Things I Don't Understand' comes across as a creative, thoughtful offering about the important things in life as well as what comes after.
No film this year has moved me as much as 'The Impossible.' Everything about this powerful movie comes together to make it one of the best and most touching viewing experiences of 2012.
Despite its creativity and originality, this 'Anna Karenina' fails to pack the emotional wallop of previous film adaptations starring Greta Garbo and Vivien Leigh.
A fascinating and impressive historical drama with first-rate performances and splendid production values.
Rachel Weisz performs a superb star turn here, but I'm still in a deep funk after watching this gloomy drama.
A unique and inspirational baseball documentary. It helps viewers understand that sometimes winning is not the most important thing - even in baseball.
Imagine the marital turbulence depicted in 'Revolutionary Road' multiplied by ten and treated as a dark comedy. That gives you some idea of what you're in for with this disturbingly funny film.
Having been a dancer for a good part of my life, I found 'Musical Chairs' quite inspiring.
Watching 'Seven Psychopaths' is like having a surrealistic nightmare you can't help enjoying.
'Nobody Walks' is like Martine's experimental film. There's sound and movement -- but no soul shining through.
If you want a fly-on-the-wall view into the private lives of theatre royalty, 'Just 45 Minutes from Broadway' is the movie for you.
Even with its super cast, the slow-moving 'Mystery Men' falters in its attempt to spoof comic book heroes.
An impressive feature film debut for filmmaker Lavinia Currier. With the exception of one scene that crosses the line, her work here shows intelligence, sensitivity, artistry, and courage.
Simplistic and repetitive, but Bradley Cooper delivers another very watchable Oscar-nominated performance.
I couldn't help falling in love with 'Strange Magic.' It's one of the most delightful animated musicals I've ever seen. Great songs , a fun story and fascinating animation. Yay!
This is a movie you cannot forget. No wonder the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences nominated the film for Oscars in five categories.
'Mean Dreams' follows two depressed teens -- and overflows with dismal scenes. But fine acting by everyone wins us over before it's done.
Writer/director E. B. Hughes offers viewers an intriguing 'danse macabre' between two old friends who get together one night after not seeing each other for fifteen years.
Gruesome and dark as it can be. But could I stop watching? Not me!
While 'Wolves' boasts exciting basketball scenes plus excellent performances, it's also too predictable and contains a very strange ending.
This unusual romantic comedy offers some entertaining moments while keeping us guessing if Eligio and Susana will ever get back together again.
movie_title: You're Killing Me Susana (Me est√°s matando Susana) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The movie boasts excellent production values, realistic performances, and a haunting story that keeps you thinking about the main character long after the end credits roll.
Despite Ricky Gervais' unique comic talents, this David Brent rock star adventure soon becomes too repetitive.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Shahab Hosseini and Taraneh Alidoosti are mesmerizing in this riveting drama about obsession and revenge.
Although difficult to watch at times because of Debbie and Carrie's recent passing, this unusual documentary emerges as a marvelous tribute to its wonderful subjects.
movie_title: Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Too bad there's no Oscar given out for "Best Voiced By Character." Liam Neeson as the Tree Monster would win the 2016 honor, hands -- or limbs -- down.
'20th Century Women' demonstrates how skillful writing and outstanding performances can transform a simple bittersweet story into something very special indeed.
A modern love story filmed in a style reminiscent of glorious classic musicals, 'La La Land' emerges as a bittersweet treat for the eyes, the ears and the heart.
The many nonlinear flashbacks in 'Jackie' made me feel like I was lost in a crazy time machine.
Although slow moving most of the time, this unusual movie gives viewers some profound subjects to think about .
'The Eyes of My Mother' just might be the gloomiest horror movie ever made.
Many amusing scenes are included in this unusual comedy, yet something seems missing. I think the main character rates low on likability. But watch for John Corbett's hilarious musical routine!
Polly Bergen's splendid performance almost overcomes the many silly scenes and ridiculous ending of 'Kisses for My President.'
'The Handmaiden' delivers a spellbinding tale of love, betrayal and revenge.
Filled with remarkable performances, 'The Great Gilly Hopkins' pulls no punches. It is not a sickly sweet movie -- but hope and humanity shine through.
'Off the Rails' is a compelling, important documentary. Watching this film can break your heart. What things will help - and where to start?
Suspense-filled scenes come near the end, but senseless acts this does not mend.
Clips of Sergei Polunin's magnificent ballet performances make this documentary worth watching. But I wish the film included more of those -- and less emphasis on personal/family problems.
'Finding Altamira' excels at showing the joys and sorrows that can come from a historic discovery. It also paints a beautiful picture of a tender father/daughter relationship.
'Skiptrace' shows Chan's amusing side and takes us for a fun wild ride.
Despite its dark subject matter, this contemporary film noir offering emerges as a thought-provoking movie about such important concerns as principles, autonomy, betrayal, and sacrifice.
Helping us suspend disbelief here is Ripley Sobo, one of the most talented little girls I've seen on screen in a long time.
A jaw-dropping look at the white supremacy culture in the U.S.A.
Matthias Schoenearts's Vincent ends up as one of the most fascinating film characters so far this year.
Everything about this animated movie delighted me, but especially the cute song and dance numbers.
Too many frequent loud noises and overpowering background music come across as distracting -- not scary.
This live-action 'Beauty and the Beast' is a special gift to movie musical fans. As old as time this tale may be. Now 'Evermore' will stay with me.
'Voice from the Stone' offers suspense. Though some parts fail to make good sense, gothic romance and mystery add much to this film's strange beauty.
'The Last Legion' is a wonderful adventure/fantasy with great characters portrayed by actors who know how to grab our attention.
Frame by frame, 'Counterfeiters' is a riveting movie. Filmmaker Bryce Hirschberg, who also plays the lead role, gives it all his heart and soul.
Rosamund Pike gives her best performance ever playing a character who changes from an extremely frightened victim to one of the strongest women I've seen on screen during the past decade.
Although disappointed with 'The Polka King," I appreciate the way the film depicts how Jan Lewan's positive attitude influenced people who unwisely invested their money with him.
As someone who lived through this crisis while it played out in reality, I am surprised at how suspenseful 'The Post' was for me to watch.
James Franco -- as we've never seen him before -- steals the show playing Tommy Wiseau in 'The Disaster Artist,' based on a true story.
A fantasy thriller for the ages!
Dan Stevens oozes energy and purpose as Charles Dickens in this creative offering about the writing of an iconic Christmas story.
A great way to introduce A Christmas Carol to the little ones.
Ten vignettes deal with love and lust. But most of them end up a bust. Still, Audra is a real standout. Her moon song bit deserves a shout!
A nephew and his famous aunt take us on an intriguing journey through the remarkable life and work of an iconic American writer.
movie_title: Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold (2017)

movie_review_blurb: 'Our Souls at Night' - a sweet movie. Fonda and Redford work for me. They play their roles with style and grace in this romance not rushed for pace.
Watching Carla Gugino's character try to survive a terrifying situation may be exhausting for some viewers, but Gugino's extraordinary acting is their reward.
'Tramps' wisely capitalizes on the intriguing chemistry between the film's young co-stars, Callum Turner and Grace Van Patten. The result? A romantic treat.
One of the most poignant and intimate documentaries I've ever seen. This compelling personal story also takes on institutional racism and the justice system in a way that can't be ignored.
'Little Evil' combines comedy and horror in a clever offering with plenty of chuckles and scary sights for fans of both genres.
The first half promises so much -- but last half loses the right touch. Scary in parts, I must admit. So some horror fans might like it.
A thought-provoking sci-fi action thriller starring Noomi Rapace, who delivers a splendid performance bringing seven sisters to life on screen. Brava!
Bryan Fogel's revealing documentary plays almost like a spy thriller. And what a fascinating real-life character shows up to hold our interest!
Chadwick Boseman reveals impressive star power in this suspenseful action thriller.
'Brave New Jersey' is so much fun. You'll chuckle lots before it's done. It's based on facts about a prank that we have Orson Welles to thank.
I applaud everyone connected with 'To the Bone' for their courage in bringing attention to eating disorders in such a powerful way. But be prepared: this is not a film that's easy to watch.
Outrageous as the 'Okja' plot may seem, it deals with important issues and makes us think-- not simply enjoy. It ends up being a movie that matters.
I still can't stop smiling and thinking about the unusual and entertaining performances of Bruce Willis, John Goodman and Jason Momoa in 'Once Upon a Time in Venice.'
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Venice (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For Wonder Woman girls can cheer without feeling a hint of fear. And guys can also shout'Hooray' when Wonder Woman saves the day!
'Black Butterfly' offers thrills and nerve-wracking excitement as well as strong performances by its excellent co-stars.
Be sure to stay to see the artistic staging of the movie's final musical number. It ends up being a wonderful scene to remember, despite the heartache that comes before.
'Burden' gave me my first exposure to Chris Burden's artistic accomplishments. While shocked by some of his disturbing early work, I am now a fan of his incredible art installations.
Directed with great care by Gurinda Chadha, this splendid motion picture should be shown in all World History classes.
The impact of 'Disclosure' is weakened significantly by depiction of the female boss as a totally evil person.
This drama works almost throughout, but toward the end it fizzles out.
What a treat to watch a remake that's almost as good as the original movie! And who knew Chris Hemsworth could be so funny?
Deals with universal themes like survival, compassion, the importance of intelligence, scientific/technological know-how, cooperation, persistence and hope. It's truly a movie that matters.
'Pay the Ghost' looks good and creepy, but some scenes just made me sleepy.
Johnny Depp proves again that he can take on any role and make us believe he IS that character.
Epic in scope is 'Dragon Blade' -- but not the best film Chan has made.
An entertaining nostalgia boost from filmmaker Peter Bogdanovich.
Too bloody and violent for me, but this thriller proves Abigail Breslin is all grown up now and still ready for her close ups.
Meryl Streep's amazing rock-and-roll performance makes this movie something very special indeed.
Backing up all the funny Minions antics is one of the best soundtracks ever and some very cute musical numbers.
Al Pacino and Annette Bening create a fun chemistry together in this splendid film about a man's fearless search for redemption.
Fine performances, but things go terribly wrong with the storytelling in 'Strangerland.'
A special period movie treat with many lovely scenes and outstanding performances.
Pacino makes us feel his character's misery. We see it in his eyes, in his gloomy facial expression, in the way he stands and walks. And we want him to cheer up, for gosh sakes!
Very funny things happen in practically every scene. I can hardly wait to see the sequel!
Although not without problems, 'Pan' is worth seeing because of its amazing special effects, impressive cinematography, and imaginative production design.
Kristen Wiig's tour de force performance makes Alice Klieg one of her best roles to date. She proves her skill at both comedy and drama in this timely, creative dramedy.
'Playing It Cool' gave me a bad case of the rom-com blues. I was expecting '500 Days of Summer' and got 'Fool's Gold' instead.
If you want to be a comedian, see this Kevin Pollak documentary first. However, although amusing and enlightening, it's also a bit scary and incoherent at times.
Some movies deserve to be treasured, and 'Adult Beginners' is high on my list.
Although based on a true story, 'Closer to the Moon' comes across on screen as artificial and befuddling. However, quality production values make it easy on the eyes.
'The Squeeze' boasts an opening sequence with the wildest golf action I've ever seen on screen, and the last part of the film offers lots of suspense. One of my favorite golf movies.
An entertaining but slow-paced thriller about fraud and murder in a small town.
'Serena' may be an overwrought and sometimes jumbled melodrama, but it's also a visual treat.
'Ever After' presents a plucky Cinderella for today's women and beyond.
Production values are outstanding, the actors give very watchable performances, and the glorious royal ball sequence simply takes your breath away.
If the mission given to cast members involved depicting the worst of human nature, then mission accomplished, for sure.
Sorry I'm a party pooper for a film most think is super.
Actor James Wilder excels as a washed up screenwriter in this fascinating psychological thriller. He takes charge of the screen and never lets go.
Filmed in Colombia, 'Out of the Dark' boasts splendid location shots by cinematographer Isaac Vila, and the color palette he chose adds to the atmospheric nature of this unusual ghost story.
Exquisite chemistry between Blythe Danner and Sam Elliott make this dramedy for grown-ups something special indeed.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Style and substance come together perfectly in this unique psychological thriller.
An atmospheric visual treat from Guillermo del Toro. Too bad the plot is so very predictable.
Gregg Turkington delivers a spot-on performance as a down-in-the-dumps comic in this gloomy offering. Too bad the film left me me in a deep funk too.
There are no car chases, super heroes or explosions in 'Fathers & Daughters.' Just lots of bravery, tenderness and tears.
Woody Harrelson and Liam Hemsworth try their best to save this very slow-moving Western.
A timely contemporary mystery with top-notch performances!
A warm, heart-tugging drama laced with amusing situations that Sally Field and Max Greenfield play to the hilt.

Ray Liotta pushes the bad-guy envelope almost to the cartoon villain category, but it definitely works in this suspenseful thriller. You might even have nightmares about Liotta after seeing 'Blackway.'
Mark Strong's work in 'Approaching the Unknown' deserves high praise. He shows the ability to carry an entire movie almost alone!
Lots of thriller potential here, but out-of-character actions interfere with suspension of disbelief.
Highlights of this terrific motion picture include perfect background music, appealing characters, and a story that touches the heart.
Elijah Wood surprised me completely here. He looks better than ever and projects so many emotions in a very difficult role.
This creative documentary cast a spell on me! Everything is done so well, especially those electrifying, sensual tango dances.
A fascinating film with eerie background music, a believable cast, and creepy atmosphere. This dark contemporary version of a Grimm fairy tale is very intense and not for kids.
Boasts dazzling special effects -- but those icy ones become too repetitive. Still, the gorgeous costumes worn by Emily Blunt and Charlize Theron are almost worth the ticket price..
With 'The Invitation,' director Karyn Kusama and her crew have created a little gem of a thriller. The last scene left me aghast!
This unusual, well-acted drama disappointed me with its shocking turn to the dark side during the last part of the movie.
Nobody's here to care about, so all we want is to get out.
'Spotlight' has increased my admiration for journalists who work diligently to find the truth behind serious problems, even if it involves powerful institutions like the Catholic Church.
Because of its intriguing emphasis on the strained father/son relationship, 'Forsaken' ends up being a compelling drama as well as a wonderful addition to the Western genre.
All the watchable performances make this uneven Coen Brothers movie worth seeing.
Michael Moore's humor turns this humanity lesson into an entertaining as well as eye-opening documentary.
'Exposed' is confusing and very difficult to follow. It ends up being a downer mess -- despite interesting turns by Keanu Reeves and Ana de Armas.
Richard Gere gives an annoying performance in 'The Benefactor' -- and it works!
Although 'The Revenant' tells a tale of violence and hardship, gorgeous vistas and cinematic artistry fill the screen -- thanks to Oscar-winning cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki.
'Joy' should please Jennifer Lawrence fans as well as viewers who enjoy movies with a strong female lead and viewpoint.
The Force is with filmmaker J.J. Abrams, who makes sure this Star Wars adventure contains thrilling action scenes, exciting special effects, and colorful characters.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Jumping back and forth among so many characters makes this important film very hard to follow.
An exciting revenge thriller enhanced by 'Pulp Fiction' vibes and a fascinating -- but quirky -- performance by Dan Stevens (as you've never seen him before).
Projecting so much love and pain, Eddie Redmayne and Alicia Vikander take us on a worthwhile journey toward better understanding of transgender transformation.
A film of quiet beauty, 'Brooklyn' reminds me of classic movie gems from the past. It also imparts a sense of place and loving hearts.
Too many flashbacks and repetitive fight scenes almost overpower Eddie Peng's fine performance.
movie_title: Rise of the Legend (Huang feihong zhi yingxiong you meng ) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: From the opening shot of a champagne bottle floating in space to the pulsating ribbon of an engulfing Nexus, the film's images dazzled me.
Stephen Dorff makes Wheeler quite real. His great performance seals the deal.
Star Glenn Close's appearance comes across as too distracting, and the film's tedious pacing doesn't help matters either.
Canine charmers fill the screen in 'Hotel for Dogs,' but the heartwarming relationship between a brother and sister gives this movie its greatest appeal
Clint Eastwood delivers a stunning performance as an angry old man who begins to question his negative opinion about his Hmong neighbors.
Most viewers who love dogs will probably sob their hearts out while watching 'Marley & Me.' I know I did.
Boasts a great idea about bedtime stories that come to life the next day, so it's a shame this film fails to be enjoyable for all age groups.
Falling in love can happen at any age. 'Last Chance Harvey' emphasizes this romantic theme while having a bit of fun doing it.
Don't expect this movie to make you feel cheerful. It's definitely a downer. I get gloomy just thinking about it.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: 'Yes Man' serves as a showcase for Jim Carrey's comedy skills. It's designed strictly for laughs -- and there are plenty of them here.
I'm still shaking my head over the implausible way this film ends.
'Wendy and Lucy' is the best feel-bad movie of the year.
'Australia' runs out of steam along its lengthy journey, but it boasts gorgeous cinematography, a passionate romance, and more than a few thrilling scenes.
With its fascinating combination of forbidden love and a seductive vampire theme, 'Twilight" may be the beginning of a very successful film franchise.
Blurred, not stirred.
An emotional roller-coaster of a movie, one that touches your heart and brings you to tears in some scenes, then enrages you in others.
movie_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Although the animated characters are sometimes fun to watch here, they're not given much of a story to work with. Musical numbers would've helped.
A totally charming story enhanced by beautiful CG animation.
'The Haunting of Molly Hartley' left me as disappointed as a youngster who receives a box of raisins at every house on his/her trick-or-treat route.
Director/choreographer Kenny Ortega takes advantage of the big screen by filling it with eye-popping colors and highly entertaining dance routines.
Although dialogue may be less than stimulating in 'Max Payne,' its powerful images relate what needs to be said -- and this approach worked for me.
'Body of Lies' ends up being a mostly chaotic movie featuring lead characters it's hard to care about.
Delgado (voiced by Andy Garcia), a reluctantly heroic German Shepherd, definitely deserves a movie of his own! Eat your heart out, Rin Tin Tin.
'Nights in Rodanthe' serves up too much manipulated sentimentality for my taste, even though I admit being incurably romantic most of the time.
Playing off each other brilliantly, Ricky Gervais and Greg Kinnear make their extreme-opposite characters quite believable here.
'The Women' entertained me much more than I expected it would, especially after seeing those dreadful previews.
Predictable as a snowstorm in December -- but visually exciting. Plus Charlie Yeung fills the screen with charm and grace.
Having to watch and review 'Disaster Movie' must be payback for the juvenile pranks I took part in as a teenager.
While watching 'Ballet Shoes,' I felt like a time machine had transported me to London in the 1930s, then set me in the midst of this wonderful humanistic story.
While Anna Faris looks gorgeous and nails her "dumb blonde with a heart of gold" persona in most scenes, the rest of 'The House Bunny' hops limply along.
I understand this is the first offering in an 'Inkheart' trilogy. If so, color me hooked.
I found this four-hours-plus movie sheer torture to watch during most of its long running time. 'Che' seems more like a guerilla handbook than a film.

This low-budget comedy shines because of its impressive character-driven plot. It's not Remember the Titans or Friday Night Lights, but it boasts humorous performances and some almost hysterically funny scenes.
Mostly because of a lead character as unbelievable as Renee Zellweger's ambitious Lucy Hill, it's not easy to warm up to this romantic comedy.
Robert Hoffman shows off his exceptional ability for physical comedy during hilarious mind-control sequences here. In fact, he's very funny in all his scenes.
Most youngsters at the screening I attended were not amused -- not even by the usually giggle-evoking flatulence scenes.
The film's marvelous visuals are what I admire most about it -- and I couldn't help going deeper and deeper under the spell of such cinematic wizardry.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Among the most troubling elements of 'Knowing' are its dark cinematography, outlandish plot, and a less-than-memorable performance by Nicolas Cage.
Another intriguing performance by Johnny Depp is the highlight of 'Public Enemies,' a film not always easy to follow.
'Captain Abu Raed' could be the beginning of a beautiful friendship between new filmmaker Amin Matalqa and discerning moviegoers everywhere.
Filled with speeded-up camera work, which makes the movie pratically unwatchable for migraine sufferers like me.
Tanna Frederick's charismatic appeal reaches out from the screen, drawing us deeper into 'Irene's world' with each successive scene.
Asks viewers to take off their thinking caps and put on their dunce hats. Comic rewards await for those who agree to do just that.
'Wake,' a short independent film, touched me more deeply than most big budget mainstream dramas.
With the exception of Amy Adams' performance and some excellent special effects, this sequel fails to live up to the first 'Night at the Museum' romp.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: 'Dance Flick' may be offensive to dancers and other living things, but it's also very funny.
Some parts of this movie come across as totally unbelievable, but it contains enough excitement and stunning cinematography to make it worth seeing.
I can't help admiring the enthusiasm and musicality Miley Cyrus brings to her routines -- both as Hannah Montana and herself.
movie_title: Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert Tour (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A thought-provoking but uneven comedy.
Hugh Jackman displays considerable animal magnetism again in 'Origins,' which includes many great sequences showing him in all his Wolverine glory.
Blessed with superb performances by Robert Downey Jr. and Jamie Foxx, 'The Soloist' deserves consideration during this year's awards season.
It's gory, campy and scary -- three important elements to fans of this genre.
'O & R' focuses on characters instead of plot, which may bother some viewers. However, the movie worked for me because of its excellent performances.
For me, the other characters in 'Monsters Vs. Aliens' fail to measure up to B.O.B.-- who's voiced to amusing perfection by Seth Rogen.
This first-ever musical docu-tragi-comedy is a highly creative piece of filmmaking. Opinionated? Yes, but it's also a lot of fun and quite provocative.
One of the most inspirational and powerful documentaries I've ever seen.
This thriller's flashback scenes interrupted the story's flow too much for me. But Julia Roberts and Clive Owen are fun to watch.
Sarah Roemer stands out in 'Fired Up!' I found her to be the only cast member who comes across as a real human being.
'Slumdog Millionaire' is a unique and memorable film -- one that's practically impossible to resist.
Visually exciting, includes outstanding acting by a fine cast, and tells a compelling tale about ambition, betrayal and revenge.
Boasts great location shots and an incredible gunfight at the Guggenheim Museum, but it's Clive Owen who earmed my most rapt attention here.
'Push' suffers from a baffling script, but Dakota Fanning delivers a very watchable performance in this sci-fi thriller.
Most love scenes seem forced in 'At First Sight,' and the background music manipulates emotions without a trace of restraint.
It's too bad that other elements of 'Mirrors" lack the brilliance of its visual artistry.
Prepare yourself for a sledgehammer skewering aimed at some of Hollywood's most offensive practices, including phoniness and those awful trailers.
Dennis Quaid and Ellen Page stand out here as a father and daughter who may have high IQ's -- but rate below zero in terms of their human relations skills.
Stallone still looks terrrific, but 'Rambo' spends too much time showing how much carnage the big screen can take.
'27 Dresses' may not be the best romantic comedy ever filmed, but it boasts extremely watchable performances by its likable co-stars.
This thought-provoking exploration of forgiveness and redemption features award-worthy performance by Jim Broadbent and Samantha Morton.
Will probably bring more tiny buccaneers into the VeggieTales fold, but some adult viewers may feel like walking the plank before the film is over.
movie_title: The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Although it's a fantasy, 'The Water Horse' makes us believe we're actually seeing 1940s Scotland on the big screen.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Why, after realizing how deadly these calls can be, does every victim still insist on listening to them? Perhaps only the screenwriters know for sure.
While watching Phil Hall talk about being a writer in this enlightening documentary, you almost believe he's sitting across from you in your living room.
Morgan Freeman and Jack Nicholson work their usual acting magic in The Bucket List, making it more entertaining than I expected.
Mirren and Voight provide much of the fun here as their characters argue about who's responsible for their divorce and longtime estrangement.
Unfortunately, this movie relies too much on its human actors, who are no match for Alvin, Simon and Theodore.
With her intelligent and energetic performance, newcomer Dakota Blue Richards captures our interest as the spunky young heroine in The Golden Compass.
Seldom have betrayal and greed been presented in such a sloppy manner on film.
While exploring the frustrations of middle-aged siblings dealing with an ailing father, 'The Savages' also spotlights moments of humor, warmth and tenderness.
Bluesy background music plus a rainy Portland setting enhance the gloomy feel of 'Spiral' and help draw us into the world of its disturbed lead character.
Although the film's theme holds great potential, 'Margot at the Wedding' falters considerably in its presentation.
Overly sentimental it may be, but August Rush took me quite willingly to a cinematic world full of music and hope.
Santa's mother, who obviously never heard of Dr. Spock, violates important childrearing advice in 'Fred Claus.' Amusing holiday chaos ensues.
Seinfeld's droll, witty observations add to the adult appeal of 'Bee Movie,' and youngsters will probably enjoy its eye-popping colors.
'Things We Lost in the Fire' deserves praise for its top-notch performances and its humanistic treatment of such serious subject matter as grief and addiction.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Gone are filmdom's traditional seductive vampires, but '30 Days of Night' still contains chills and thrills galore.
Powerful drug dealers may be evil, but I doubt they're as stupid and oblivious as depicted in 'We Own the Night.'
I've always believed certain films should never be re-made, but 'The Heartbreak Kid' wasn't one of them. After seeing this new version, it's on my list.
Although 'The Game Plan' disappointed me, I wouldn't be surprised if teeny-bopper girls -- and fans of "The Rock" -- get a kick out of it.
Billy Bob Thornton simply couldn't be better as the rude, tyrannical P.E. teacher whose answer to everything is '10 laps.'
Jeff Goldblum's willingness to take a chance on something different and the way he sticks to it is the real charm of 'Pittsburgh.'
Kudos to director James Mangold for not letting anything stand in the way of splendid performances in this impressive remake.
Some of the scenes in 'Death Sentence' reminded me of old B-movie Westerns where the bad guys shoot and shoot and shoot yet always miss their targets.
'The Artist' offers a unique cinematic experience in an age when extremely loud sound effects attack our eardrums while watching so many current movies.
With its buoyant combination of romance, music and fun, 'Enchanted' emerges as one of the most entertaining films of the year.
If you enjoyed Timothy Olyphant as the determined sheriff in HBO's 'Deadwood,' you'll be surprised at how good he is playing a very different type of role here.
Move over, 'One Missed Call.' You now face stiff competition for worst movie of the year from 'Over Her Dead Body.'
Nostalgic, warm, bittersweet, and thoroughly entertaining, 'Definitely Maybe' earns a place on my list of favorite contemporary romantic comedies.
America Ferrera projects such star power here that I felt cheated when the camera moved to other characters. The rest of the film seemed to drag for me.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The "wow" factor in 'Swing Vote' is Madeline Carroll's impressive screen presence. She's a power to be reckoned with, so watch your back, Abigail Breslin!
While Duchovny, Anderson & Connolly deliver riveting performances here, the story fails to provide them with material to match their talents.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Amanda Seyfried wows us with her lovely voice, and Meryl Streep belts out showstoppers as if she were born to be a musical star.
Even without 3D at the screening I attended, some scenes in 'Journey to the Center of the Earth' caused audience members to squeal with excitement.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: 'Kit Kittredge' presents a wonderful role model for pre-teen girls -- and a humanistic history lesson about the Great Depression for all viewers.
WALL-E and EVE project more humanity and genuine emotion than most human characters I've seen in films lately.
Guru Pitka, as portrayed by Mike Myers, stoops about as low as any movie character I've ever seen in order to get laughs.
'The Happening' may not be M. Night Shyamalan's best movie, but it's his most provocative one.
Although this film could've been hilarious, almost every scene ends up as crude or just plain silly. But Adam Sandler looks terrific as Zohan!
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As someone who failed to appreciate the 'Sex and the City' TV series, I'm surprised at how much I enjoyed this movie celebration of friendship.
From its exciting opening sequence to its clever closing scene, 'Crystal Skull' made me grateful to Steven Spielberg for deciding to film another Indy adventure.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Despite a casting flaw and uncomfortable pacing, 'Prince Caspian' is an epic adventure with brave characters, amazing creatures and incredible special effects.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Too crude in spots, 'Wild West Comedy Show' is still an amusing and revealing documentary about the daring art of stand-up comedy.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Lucky for viewers, it's easy to laugh while watching this romantic comedy, mostly because of the comic skills Kutcher and Diaz bring to their performances.
'Deception' ends up as a splendid illustration of how acting skill can sometimes overcome a number of cinematic sins.
'88 Minutes' is a muddled, low-quality thriller.
With its screwball comedy approach to how football changed from a no-holds-barred sport to one with strict rules, 'Leatherheads" is a nostalgic treat.
Despite its welcome emphasis on the heroism of two female characters, 'Nim's Island' is one of the most disappointing and disjointed films so far this year.
All the most hilarious scenes from 'Superhero Movie' show up in the film's trailer, but there's still a lot to laugh about in this silly parody.
Rowan Atkinson's operatic lip-synching in 'Mr. Bean's Holiday' is one of the funniest things I've seen in a movie so far this year.
The only thrills in 'Shutter' come from watching Joshua Jackson in a couple of appealing close-ups.
Watch your back, Dumbo. You have heavy competition now from Horton!
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As in all his splendid documentaries, Mark Bussler packs the enlightening 'Westinghouse' with fascinating rare footage and photographs.
An amusing and heartfelt exploration of the ups and downs involved when adopting a child -- in this case, one who insists he's from another planet.
For the first time ever, Will Ferrell's performance failed to make me laugh even once.
During the last part of this wacky comedy, it loses the amusing push-pull intimacy between its 'odd-couple' protagonists.
It's always a pleasure to watch Highmore, one of the best child actors working today, and this time that pleasure is doubled because he plays a dual role.
I admit the need for a frequent romantic-comedy fix, but 'Made of Honor' left me totally unsatisfied.
I can't remember when I've had such a hard time becoming emotionally involved in a love story on film.
'Maurice Jarre: A Tribute to David Lean' is as much a tribute to its immensely talented composer as it is to the remarkable film director being honored.
movie_title: Maurice Jarre - A Tribute to David Lean (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Provides food for thought about fate and our own mortality as well as exciting scenes for viewers who enjoy seeing blood and guts on screen.
The film's ending sets things up for another sequel, and that worries me. Do you realize how many fairy tales can be Hoodwinked?!!!
Sometimes while watching 'Water for Elephants,' I actually felt as gritty as the circus workers or as spellbound as the spectators inside the Big Top.
Sitting through this crude fantasy comedy may be challenging for certain viewers, but it helps to remember that funny is in the eye of the beholder.
Kudos to producer/director Michael Webber for delivering such an emotional, enlightening and gripping documentary about the dangers of keeping wild animals as pets.
movie_title: The Elephant In The Living Room (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This inspiring movie about courage and faith offers a wonderful role model for everyone -- not just teenage girls.
Jake Gyllenhaal delivers one of his best performances to date in this extremely suspenseful sci-fi thriller.
My husband insists that 'Red Riding Hood' is a 'Lifetime' flick set in Medieval times. He could be right.
Farfetched? Yes, but Matt Damon and Emily Blunt convinced me their characters belong together in this romantic sci-fi thriller.
Christoph Waltz delivers one of the most brilliant portrayals of a villain I've seen since Anthony Hopkins transformed himself into Hannibal Lecter.
'Magic in the Water' will probably appeal mostly to viewers who crave unsophisticated family-oriented entertainment, not matter how hokey it is.
A spirited documentary highlighting the natural talents and show biz success of a youngster who was born to perform.
Ben Foster knows how to simmer as well as go berserk on camera with the best of them, and his performance here gives him plenty of opportunity to show off those acting chops.
Although a bit short on laughs for a romcom, 'No Strings Attached' has its heart in the right place.
Although 'Something Borrowed' deals with serious love vs. friendship issues, Kate Hudson's performance is over-the-top funny.
Seth Rogen, Jay Chou, Cameron Diaz and Christoph Waltz try to bring their characters to life in this campy action flick -- but the results end up uneven at best.
Powerful and spellbinding, but not for the squeamish or the incurably romantic or people who don't want to know how difficult it can be to keep love alive.
Jack Black's amazing comic energy, as seen in films like 'School of Rock' and 'Nacho Libre,' seems a bit muted in 'Gulliver's Travels.' I expected more from him here.
Ensemble acting at its finest. Stars Mark Wahlberg, Christian Bale, Amy Adams and Melissa Leo deliver knock-out performances here, as does everyone else in this outstanding film.
Don't believe this film's title.
An entertaining showcase for Christina Aguilera's amazing vocal talent. Plus glitzy showgirl routines liven things up with sexy, amusing, energetic fun.
This wonderful character-driven film about a young woman who, with every fiber of her being, wants to be famous is funny, touching and oh-so romantic.
Robert Downey Jr. and Zach Galifianakis try to make the most of a film devoted more to a series of silly situations than to believable interactions and plot.
Director Antonia Bird and screenwriter Ted Griffin stir up an extremely unsavory concoction about cannibalism here.
Contains moments of exceptional beauty as well as scenes of intense emotional anguish. I admire Eastwood for taking on another difficult theme and handling it so well.
Marwencol is truly a wonderful town. Because Mark Hogancamp puts incredible detail into the appearance of each doll, everything seems so real!
Excitement mounts with every hoof beat in 'Secretariat,' a real crowd pleaser.
'Let Me In' is bloody, gory and scary. But it is also smartly written and directed, heartbreakingly acted, and artistically photographed.
'You Again' goes to extremes while trying to make us laugh at the same thing over and over again.
Misconceptions concerning show biz, rehab and addiction abound in this disappointing melodrama about a country megastar on a downward spiral. But its fine cast is not to blame.
Those expecting 'The American' to be an 'action' thriller may be in for a disappointment.
'Gun Hill Road' is a gritty and heart-wrenching drama with fearless performances by an impressive cast.
One of the most exciting sequences in the 'Pirates' franchise features a spectacular pirates/mermaid clash that makes 'On Stranger Tides' something special.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A grim film to watch, but an unforgettable one. Because of Swinton's marvelous acting, we believe every emotion she displays as her character experiences grief, guilt, loneliness and despair.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Darn you, Steven Spielberg! You made me cry again. 'War Horse' is a wonderful film, but I wish you had toned it down a bit. I'm still teary eyed just thinking about Joey.
Whether you're male or female, going through a mid-life crisis is no picnic. But watching the way it's depicted in 'I Melt with You' may be even worse.
'Hugo' was an amazing cinematic experience for me, even though I'm not a 3-D fan.
This delightful film boasts catchy songs, funny dialogue and nostalgic sequences -- as well as human characters almost as lovable as the Muppets themselves.
A film dealing with vampires, werewolves and forbidden love should be exciting to watch, yet this one moves along slower than a snail's pace.
After starting out with a very slow pace, this heist film makes up for it during an exciting and unusual robbery caper.
Finally, a fun animated movie that treats Puss in Boots like the star he was meant to be.
Although featuring a splendid Edward Norton performance, 'Rounders' comes across as too unbelievable, often straying beyond the bounds of rationality.
With his delightful learning-how-to-dance sequence, Miles Teller almost steals 'Footloose' from fantastic dancers Kenny Wormald and Julianne Hough.
This uneven thriller alternates between fast-paced action and confusing plot situations, but Taylor Lautner takes his shirt off again to please his fans.
Those robot boxing bouts are exciting to watch, but it's the impressive performances by Hugh Jackman and Dakota Goyo that make 'Real Steel" something special.
'Wag the Dog,' a movie that's fun to see more than once, comes across as a bitingly funny satire of politics, the media and show business.
'Mighty Aphrodite' only occasionally sparkles with witty dialogue reminiscent of Allen's earlier films, and that's not enough to resurrect the old Woody Allen magic.
Fascinating cinematography and a riveting performance by Ryan Gosling elevate 'Drive' above many other heist-gone-wrong movies.
Fine performances, a wonderful gothic look, and frightening creatures contribute to the scare factor of this quality horror movie.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most painfully unromantic 'romance dramas' I've ever seen.
This latest 'FD' outing boasts some of the best visual effects ever, especially the bridge-crumbling sequence at the beginning of the film.
Unfortunately, the film's sets and special effects overwhelm its plot and cast.
'I want the apes to win!' my husband whispered to me during the last battle sequence -- and I felt the same way. Still, I hope no humans were hurt during the filming of this exciting movie.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Mystery, suspense, sci-fi shenanigans, gunplay and horsemanship fill the screen in one of my favorite summer offerings to date.
Although sometimes amusing, 'Three to Tango' relies on a one-joke emphasis that wears thin early on.
This splendid final HP film uses special effects to full advantage, thereby increasing the thrill of watching Harry and his friends try to defeat the evil Lord Voldemort.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Exciting battle sequences, intriguing period costumes, fascinating cinematography, and stirring background music contribute to the epic nature of 'The 13th Warrior.'
To me, the highlight of 'Larry Crowne' is the way Larry (Tom Hanks), Mercedes (Julia Roberts), and the community college students impact each other's lives.
Hhandsome Pierce Brosnan and elegant Rene Russo look fabulous here, but they fail to ignite an exciting on-screen chemistry.
Just when you think penguin mania is over, here comes 'Mr. Popper's Penguins' starring Jim Carrey plus the cutest bunch of penguins ever to waddle across the screen and steal your heart.
'Super 8' is not flawless, but I think it contains the most memorable film sequence so far this year.
'Contagion' is an ambitious and well-meaning film. However, despite some fine performances, it fails to deliver the type of thrills and suspense promised in those exciting previews.
Emma Stone delivers a star-making performance here, but memorable scenes with veteran actors Stanley Tucci and Patricia Clarkson make the film something special.
An over emphasis on 'raunchy' at the expense of humor takes its toll on this disappointing raunch-com from the Farrelly brothers.
Everything seems terribly bleak at first, but Nanny McPhee soon makes delightful, magical sights appear while she goes about 'fixing' things.
Despite a few good moments, 'Youth in Revolt' turns out to be a hodgepodge of dysfunctional family scenes, drug sequences, lustful teens and cartoon inserts.
Who knew Michelle Monaghan could pull-off one of the most fearless and edgy female roles of the year? And do it so convincingly.
Playing members of an unusual love triangle, Meryl Streep, Alec Baldwin, and Steve Martin mine every possible comic nuance in Nancy Meyers' amusing film.
It's great fun watching Robert Downey Jr. sink his teeth -- and everything else -- into the role of a brainy, brawny Sherlock Holmes.
The Chipmunks are as cute as ever here, but the plot is almost insultingly predictable, even for the youngest of viewers.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: 'The Young Victoria' is at heart a love story -- and, for me, it hits all the right notes on that score.
While the actors deliver fine performances in 'The Lovely Bones,' they can't save this overblown film.
This inspiring film is a dramatic history lesson about quality leadership and the power of forgiveness.
Tobey Maguire surprised me with the depth and maturity of his acting in this well-made but disturbing Jim Sheridan film.
Provides the little ones with a wonderful introduction to Charles Dickens' classic holiday tale. Three other animated short films add to the fun.
Wes Anderson's first animated movie turns out to be one of 2009's best films.
Travolta and Williams have been around long enough to know that when doing comedy, sometimes 'less is more.'
For me, nothing in 'New Moon' matches the visual excitement of the vampire baseball game in 'Twilight.'
This is not one of Jackie Chan's best films, but it's still fun to watch Chan pull out all the stops to entertain us at an age when many actors have stopped trying.
Outlandish embellishments serve as annoying distractions to a perfectly good premise in this disappointing thriller.
Like the character he plays here, Albert Brooks needed someone or something to re-inspire him while working on this plodding comedy.
John C. Reilly excels in a role I thought couldn't possibly be appropriate for him. It's a nice change of pace for this fine actor.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Helen Mirren's acting stands out in this mean-spirited dark comedy like an original Picasso in a paint-by-numbers art show.
I didn't think anyone could match Terry O'Quinn's riveting performance in the 1987 film, but Dylan Walsh nails the title role in this remake.
It's quite refreshing to see a horror movie with high-quality performances like Patrick Fabian and Ashley Bell deliver here.
The secret to a happy marriage involves falling in love over and over again with the same person. 'Couples Retreat' offers an amusing illustration of that old saying.
Like 'Life of Brian,' 'The Invention of Lying' pokes fun at religious beliefs. Too bad it fails to emphasize the fun.
Jesse Eisenberg and Woody Harrelson do a great job playing off each other in 'Zombieland,' one of the funniest zombie movies I've ever seen.
To me, this updating of the original 'Fame' beautifully highlights the joys and heartbreaks that come with dedication to the performing arts.
Because it's easy to spot the culprit, suspense gets short shrift here. That's surprising, for Jonathan Mostow delivered uber-suspense in 'Breakdown.'
Aaron Eckhart surprised me with the depth of his performance as a self-help guru who needs help himself.
Angela Lansbury shows off her singing, dancing and comic skills -- which I think even overshadow the film's Oscar-winning special effects.
Although I laughed at a couple of slapstick gags, the rest of this comedy didn't seem very funny to me.
Amazing special effects assume the starring role here, but cast members also deserve recognition for adding a humanistic touch to this over-the-top disaster movie.
Films with angels as characters usually fascinate me, but 'Legion' is not one of them. Its story makes no sense, and the movie's religious theme rings false.
Moving this exciting thriller along at just the right pace, director Jason Connery builds considerable suspense concerning how it will end.
Although John Travolta and Jonathan Rhys Meyers make an unlikely duo, they perform their roles with gusto. And the fast-paced action here is exciting to watch.
Despite the appeal of its co-stars, this romantic comedy is undermined by over-the-top performances from some of its actors as well as the movie's frantic pace.
Julia Roberts continues to be one of our finest actresses, and she makes this film less tedious than it could have been.
I haven't laughed this hard in a movie since the last time I watched 'Waiting for Guffman.'
At the screening I attended, most of the laughs from youngsters came during the end credits while clips of animals not even in the movie were being shown.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Angelina Jolie is a marvel to watch as Evelyn Salt. In her many exciting action sequences AND in her few quiet moments on camera, she simply owns the screen.
A more lovable animated villain than Gru would be hard to find. It's a treat to watch three adorable orphans draw him into their web.
My disappointment with this 'PG' fantasy relates to its ponderous nature and lack of any comic relief.
'Dying is easy; comedy is hard,' said a famous actor on his death bed. Films like 'Grown Ups' prove his point.
What a triumph this incredible new 'Toy Story' adventure is! It does a terrific job emphasizing the relationship between toys and a child's imagination.
'The Karate Kid' is a visually appealing and highly engaging remake. Yay!
I found 'Killers' mostly fun and suspenseful to watch, despite its intermittent blah dialogue and schmaltzy ending.
It's a never-ending sequel.
Filled with colorful small-town characters who definitely grow on you as the movie progresses, 'The Mini' reminds me of 'Napoleon Dynamite,' another indie gem.
My mind kept wandering from what was happening on screen, which never occurred during the previous and highly entertaining Shrek adventures.
This excellent documentary evokes considerable empathy for two amazing, dedicated youngsters who prove that ballet is not only for the elite.
Contains enough great action sequences, impressive special effects and splendid performances to hold your interest most of the time. Excellent way to start summer movie season.
'Valentine's Day' sometimes misses the mark because of its uneven pacing, but it managed to hold my interest despite skipping around to so many characters.
Martin Scorsese's atmospheric thriller deserves high marks for its fine performances and outstanding production values.
Amid all the battle hubbub and archery antics, Russell Crowe manages to make us believe this Robin Hood is a man of thought as well as action.
If you enjoy hide-and-seek horror films, this one isn't bad. Viewers who prefer more sophisticated plots may not agree with me.
While Matt Damon's performance as a hero on an important mission evokes suspense and empathy, 'Green Zone' suffers from the chaotic way it's filmed.
'The Bounty Hunter' is a fast-paced, action-packed romantic comedy. I'm surprised at how much I enjoyed it, especially after seeing those underwhelming previews.
Hooray! Tim Burton's amazingly bizarre 'Alice in Wonderland' helped snap me out of my 2010 movie doldrums.
'Clash of the Titans' emphasizes its incredible creatures instead of the human actors, and they are fantastic.
Although played strictly for laughs, this entertaining comedy also boasts plenty of action, thrills and suspense.
Chris Rock and Martin Lawrence wisely leave the funniest parts of this farcical comedy to its strong supporting cast.
Although this romantic comedy suffers from predictability and includes a couple of crude scenes, it's also quite heartwarming and amusing.
It's hard to watch Brendan Fraser do the slapstick required for a role better suited to someone like Jim Carrey or Will Ferrell.
There's not one believable character in this fantasy comedy.
Southland Tales really is a guy movie, right down to all the sci-fi, comic book and porn references...
... one of the best loved films in cinema history.
Andre Techine is a master at taking life experiences and stripping them of sentimentality, leaving us with only the bare-bones honesty of relationships and desire.
This is no experimental tale, but a gripping yarn, and the issues it confronts are complicated ones, with many sides.
It's another beautiful, sensual film, and another homage to what makes life enjoyable.
This is Frank Langella's movie. He's been given a plum of role, and he bites into it with amazing grace and precision.
The Savages, writer/director Tamara Jenkins's second film, is easily the best comedy of the year.
Caramel is a warm, funny and compassionate movie that examines five women who are at very different stages in their lives, each one with a particular problem to work out.
As a black comedy, In Bruges is a work of comic genius.

No End is Sight is the product of a calmly systematic desire for knowledge, and as such, does not offer solutions, only profound insight.
After watching this movie, I felt like every nerve ending in my body was shooting sparks. No wonder these boys dedicate their lives to this dance. It's electrifying.
Those who find Rumi's wisdom as unknowable as desert sand constantly reshaped by the wind that blows it, will have the same reaction to Bab'Aziz.
movie_title: Bab'Aziz: The Prince Who Contemplated His Own Soul (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If it is the objective of a work of art to hold up a mirror to our own lives, then 51 Birch Street, in all its makeshift craftsmanship, is a great work of art.
... a stirring narrative, a movie of epic dramatic force that holds its own with the best of any major work of cinema.
... at times humorous, at times touching, and unfortunately, at times tedious and distancing.
Somewhere along the line, the movie version of Sex and the City got too much Botox injected into the script, and all the life was ironed out of it.
[Savage Grace] is like a Vanity Fair article; it's eye candy, with ... a creepy dysfunctional family drama thrown in to give it added value.
Bella is a (...) parable of remorse and redemption, a tale of two damaged souls who end up helping each other find release from their tragic pasts.
This is Werner Herzog at his best -- a cynic with a big heart, and a nasty wit.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Jean-Jacques Beniex's bold experiment is worth a place of importance in cinematic history.
Klimt is a feast for the eyes and the mind.
This movie is another sign of a growing tendency in contemporary cinema towards conspicuous imitation. It seems that originality is no longer something to aspire to.
Luckily, there is Hartley's immense wit to carry it through, but wit can be a dangerous gift, especially when the capacity to be clever overwhelms all else.
It feels like an American movie, dubbed in French ... Or perhaps, better put, it feels like a bunch of French people trying to act like Americans.

movie_review_blurb: Someone should have figured out what this movie was really about before they even started.
Jasmila Zbanic also deserves our admiration for casting Karanovic, and for making a film of great power about the fate of that ultimate contradiction -- a child born out of hatred.
A film of impeccable style, with every note hit to perfection, but without much soul.
movie_title: The Page Turner (La Tourneuse de pages) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: But Verhoeven's films are not meant to offer profound moral insights. And "Black Book" does not aspire to historical accuracy. Instead, "Black Book" is pure entertainment, of the hollow variety. Verhoeven gives you your money's worth of titillation...
The American military comes across as bungling and ineffective as protectors. If people thought we didn't know what we were doing in Iraq before, this is yet more evidence of our incompetence.
movie_title: The Prisoner Or: How I Planned to Kill Tony Blair (2007)

movie_review_blurb: If the filmmakers are telling us that Diane's artistic creativity was unleashed by the love of a good freak, then it's a shame. To turn a story so full of good intentions at the beginning into another movie about a woman who is liberated from the chains
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: ...I don't have a problem with you guys making my gender the propagator of evil...But if you're going to go around blaming a woman for everything, the least you could do is give her character some depth, instead of making her into some cardboard cut-out..
Let us hope that Noyce's influence in Hollywood will help give this film the attention it deserves, and that his newfound activism will have some effect.
The movie is at its best as a collage of environments representing states of mind.

Globalization is here to stay, and it presents us with yet another set of problems that we must address. China Blue does not offer solutions, but it might help get us to stop ignoring the problems. It is the little elephant that roared.

...Exiled is compromised by the feeling one gets that Johnnie To has been watching too many westerns. Like in a Sergio Leone movie, all the characters try to strike iconic poses, clad with shades, munching on cigars, tilted gun in hand.
Hugh Grant is a genius at romantic comedy. He has just the right blend of good looks, sex appeal, wit, sensitivity, self-awareness, and even more endearing, self-mockery.

"Pan's Labyrinth" is impeccable filmmaking; it alone might be enough to seal del Toro's reputation as a master of cinema.
Someone should have figured out what this movie was really about before they even started. Sometimes it is better to begin at the very beginning.
It is like a duet in which both men work together to achieve a kind of cinematic harmony, and out of it comes a beautiful recording of the universal struggle that is life.
Much like Rinpoche has let go of what others expect a Buddhist leader to be like, Patten's documentary is her own way of letting go of what others expect a documentary about Buddhism to be like.

Flanders is relentlessly bleak, but as it works its way into your bloodstream, the aftertaste is somewhat akin to relief...For those who allow it, Flanders offers the comfort of recognition, and acceptance, of what it means to be human.
It's too bad it took so long for the film to get here, because it's not only the best part, it's also the very end.

As the mother of a preteen daughter who has dragged me to a number of teen movies, I was captivated by this strange mutant of a movie. There is skill here, and some poignant scenes that stayed with me, including a first kiss scene that's one of the bette
... a beautifully directed and passionate homage to the dignity of one man against the indignity of the times.

[History Boys] is most potently about the love of teaching, and how the best teachers can help give meaning to existence; and if not meaning in the grand sense, at least an appreciation of what it means to be human.

You will laugh, you will be moved to tears, and you may even come away thinking the human race might actually survive without killing each other off, because there are stories like [this] to remind us that, deep down, we're all pretty much the same.

movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If John Keats is the catalyst who inspired Miss Campion to make this film, and us to go see it, it is Fanny Brawne, the bright star of the film's title, who makes it worthwhile.
Antichrist is a kind of exorcism for von Trier, an exorcism that involves no less than the destruction of the genitals of both sexes.
Frazer Bradshaw's debut feature reeks of a need to do something grand, and its attempt to reach high art makes its failure that much more obvious.
Just as The Twilight Saga: New Moon taps into to the sexual yearnings and psychic disturbances of pubescent girls, so does The Private Lives of Pippa Lee for the perimenopausal crowd.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Fish Tank could easily have turned into a maudlin and overly heart-wrenching tale, but it's gritty and tough instead, just like its heroine.
A painfully incisive portrait of a young German couple whose seemingly passionate union gets sorely tested while on holiday in Sardinia.
French actor Vincent Cassel, as Mesrine, delivers in spades.
movie_title: Mesrine: Part 1 (Killer Instinct) and Part 2 (Public Enemy #1) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Meryl Streep's performance brings Julia Child to vivid life ... As Nora Ephron herself has said: "She plays all of us better than we play ourselves."
...a nearly perfect film."
... an excoriating indictment of the investment banking industry.
With nothing more than a teensy camera and a big talent, Miss Dunham has made a great little movie. This young filmmaker is the real thing.

Nicholas Philibert's film is a heartfelt and wondrously respectful homage to this magnificent species.

French director Michel Gondry takes a select group of Bronx teenagers, puts them on a bus, and lets them loose. For some of us, it's a scary ride.

I was so depressed after leaving the theater, I had to crawl to the nearest video store and rent a Marx Brothers movie in order to revive myself.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its rather well worn premise of a prodigal son returning to his family home, this charming French film actually feels quite fresh and original.

... a revelation, an enlightening analysis of a man whose devotion to a political movement defined his life.

movie_review_blurb: Steve Buscemi and Michael Pitt are easily the best odd couple the movies have seen since Walter Matthau and Jack Lemmon.
Elle Fanning, the ten-year-old sister of Dakota, can act like nobody's business, and it is her remarkable ability that carries an otherwise artistic mess of a movie.

Tate Taylor's film cares less about narrative clarity and more about portraying a life lived between the extremes of sin and grace, between the abject and the sublime. It's lively, stylized, and genuinely surprising.

The film seems content to be the class clown of the Marvel Universe, which is all well and good. But like most class clowns, sometimes you wish it would apply itself - because it seems capable of being so much more.
Hercules has no right to be as entertaining as it is.
An elaborate, endless clown-car of whirligig contraptions and unreal images, with little bursts of romantic melancholy peeking out here and there.
It is, in almost all respects, a better movie. It's still not particularly good, though.

Wish I Was Here, not unlike its predecessor Garden State, captures a certain generational drift. It just doesn't know what to do with it. So it beats the damned thing into the ground until it's dead.

A comic-tragic-sentimental genre hodgepodge that wants to make you feel all the feelings amid all that action spectacle. It doesn't entirely deliver, but at times you can't help but admire its strangeness.
More fun than any civilization's fiery extinction should ever be, Paul W.S. Anderson's Pompeii 3-D is gloriously exciting kitsch - a poor man's Titanic crossed with an even poorer man's Gladiator.
