Visitors is far from the master's best film, but I know I'll be haunted by it for a while.

The kind of film that outfits a potentially compelling story with politically convenient signposts - not understanding that sometimes, getting out of the way of a good tale is the best kind of polemical strategy.
So much of this beguiling film's beauty is in how it sneaks up on you, the way genre elements quietly insinuate their way into the story.
The Nut Job is a delightfully goofy slapstick cartoon with a surprisingly dark heart.
An Ice Cube and Kevin Hart comedy that will probably be in a Rite-Aid discount bin in about six months.
The directors stay close on their characters and let scenes play out in handheld long takes, so that the miseries inflicted never feel distant or clinical, but immediate.
Everybody seems to have been cast based on their ability to either stare blankly, or to scream, often at the heavens.
Part of the pleasure in watching The Best Offer is the elegant, unassumingly suspenseful way it unfolds.

Mr. Peabody & Sherman is slight, but it's exceedingly charming, making good use of a talented voice cast that includes Stephen Colbert, Leslie Mann, Mel Brooks as Freud, and Stanley Tucci as Leonardo Da Vinci.
The Quiet Ones is uninspired even by contemporary horror standards - which comes as a bit of a shock, given its pedigree.
Don't be surprised if, two weeks from now, you forget it ever existed.
Stupidity and incompetence are two very different things, and this movie isn't smart enough to be as stupid as it wants.
A Haunted House 2 is not a movie. It is a nervous breakdown.
As a human tragedy of man and monster, of beauty and beast, it has just enough genuine pathos that you wish it were better.
As a theatrical experience, Manakamana is spellbinding. But it's a complex spell ...
What's supposed to be guileless and unformed starts to feel like shtick.
Cuban Fury has a surprising amount of fun with these acknowledged clich√©s. At times, the movie has the energy of an Anchorman-style spoof ...
It's funny stuff, to be sure, but don't be surprised if you find yourself checking the time whenever the actual plot kicks in.
Dom Hemingway is an uneven movie, to be sure ... but it's still hard to resist.
Sabotage starts off as a fun, nasty, occasionally surprising little piece of genre filmmaking. But it gradually loses the thread.
Cesar Chavez makes for a fine history lesson, but as drama, it leaves something to be desired.
If Cheap Thrills ultimately does carry us along, it's due largely to Healy's performance and presence.
You could say (and some will) that the gratuitousness of the violence in The Raid 2 is a problem. But it all functions as part of the surreal dance of death ...

Pavich is clearly in awe of Jodorowsky (who wouldn't be?), but he still treads a fine line between buying the director's notions of a spiritual quest at face value and soberly detailing said journey's particulars.
A romance about two down-and-outers that reveals the workings of a whole citywide ecosystem of crime and punishment.
The songs are catchy, the cameos are okay, and some of the jokes work fine. Set your expectations super-low, and you'll probably be fine.
It has things to say about the world, but it does so gracefully, without hitting you over the head with them.

These are some great actresses, and with writer-director-producer Perry displaying some rare focus, you're intrigued at first by the possibility of watching them interact for a couple of hours. It doesn't last.
The film is at its best when it's hovering aimlessly without any apparent purpose in the world of this embittered, misanthropic little man.
Journey to the West works so well because Chow has a flair for grand comic-action set pieces, and his imagination seems to actually draw energy from these rapid-fire tonal shifts.
A movie that plays like a low-rent Logan's Run crossed with a UNICEF commercial.
The melodrama feels so hurried and half-baked that the end result isn't just disappointing. It's borderline infuriating.
As playful as it is, Lenny Abrahamson's film is mostly a surprisingly earnest story about the compromises and conflicts of art, stardom, and mental illness.
Kingsman is not a film for gentlemen. It's for us, the great unwashed, bloodthirsty audience. It's an immaculately engineered, laugh-out-loud appeal to our own depravity.
It's the most likable Ryan Reynolds has been in a film in, well, forever, basically. He's not necessarily good, mind you.
A strange movie that manages to be both ridiculous and bland, its chief point of interest is the spectacle of a great actor caught in career decline.
Black or White isn't so much an offensive movie as it is a pointless one.
The world it presents seems at times so slippery and uncertain that being lost seems like the only natural response.
An absurdist, melancholy coming-of-age tale that jumps from odd comedy to striking violence to stirring reflection.
Strange Magic isn't very magical, but it sure is strange.
Paddington is absolutely, positively delightful.
A mostly disposable, occasionally quite funny bromance distinguished at times by its earnestness.
The concept is lame, and the execution is lame, too. The more the film advances, the less we care about the plot - or anything that happens to anybody, really.
We may find ourselves both frustrated and riveted. Something tells me Bruno Dumont wouldn't want it any other way.

It's not a particularly brilliant conceit, but, not unlike Stevens's beautifully one-note performance, it's evocative nevertheless -- lending the whole movie an aura of pop inevitability, turning its blunt predictability into something of a virtue.
It's a dour, drab, dark movie, enlivened by some moderately effective chills in the first half but ultimately undone by its downbeat aimlessness.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: As The Gambler becomes less about its protagonist's dashed intellectualism and more about the gathering danger of his predicament, the film gains power.
Filled with a desolate beauty.
It's all dumb, but fun.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film's tone remains playful -- there are even some broad, laugh-out-loud moments involving a sex toy -- but poignant little moments sneak in, hinting at darker, more troubling themes.
The Rewrite wants to be a film about the messiness of life but it only has Hollywood clich√©s to work with.

This third installment of The Hobbit trilogy is allegedly the shortest of all of Peter Jackson's Tolkien films, but my theater must have been orbiting a black hole because I could swear it swallowed up 20 years of my life.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Results feels so free-form, so liberated from the shackles of genre, that it becomes its own wonderfully alive and unpredictable thing.
Why is it so wonderful? Because wit and charm matter, and The DUFF has a good deal of both. The cast will be stars, the gags will be immortal, and you'll still be watching this movie years from now.
Given this fractured-three-ways perspective, it's surprising how smoothly The Salt of the Earth moves, how gracefully it switches back and forth between the personal and the objective.
A surprisingly moving tale of friendship and family, dressed up as an adorably frivolous sci-fi comedy.
It feels like a bunch of off-color jokes the filmmakers have been trying to tell for years, and they've crammed them all into one film - with tiresome results.
Accidental Love is an utter mess, which is understandable given its troubled provenance. It's also fascinating.
It's beautifully tense and well-acted - the kind of modest genre picture we don't see enough of these days.
I never once doubted that I was in the hands of a master filmmaker.
Throughout The Cobbler, Sandler himself seems more invested than he's been for a long time. But the rest of this ghastly movie lets him down.
A romantic drama with the sensibility of a thriller, Beno√Æt Jacquot's 3 Hearts is a good example of how a talented director and cast can elevate the most tired of concepts.
The cult is right to be scared. Going Clear is spectacular stuff. Literally.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It'll be easy for some to dismiss this as a familiar story told all too coolly, but look closer and you'll see it has a raging heart.
Chances are, if you liked The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel, you'll like the second best one as well.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There's plenty to like in Unfinished Business, even though viewers expecting the debauchery of a Wedding Crashers will likely leave disappointed.

The Salvation is visually beautiful, morally down and dirty, and simplistic. But it's marked by two haunted, quiet performances from stars Mads Mikkelsen and Eva Green, who make [an] otherwise predictable slog worthwhile.
A grimy, dopey, confused thriller that wastes a very likable cast.
'71 doesn't always work, but when it does, it's a blistering, gripping tale of a boy lost in a war gone horribly wrong.
Hot Tub Time Machine 2 is so bad it might make you question your allegiance to the original Hot Tub Time Machine.
Here's a movie that should be disposable at best, and racially condescending at worst, and yet it sticks with you. It comes by its emotions honestly and wins you over.
Da Sweet Blood of Jesus is a mess, but it's the kind of mess only one of our greatest filmmakers could make.
Those first two movies look like Seven Samurai next to The Expendables 3, a sad, bad, parade of uninspired cameos and listless violence.

Exodus: Gods and Kings is as uneven as Ridley Scott's career; at times, it seems to be a journey through the director's greatest strengths and weaknesses. The good news is that his strengths eventually win out ...
You have to respect a kids' cartoon that kicks off with a Werner Herzog joke - even one so willfully, wondrously stupid and lighthearted as Penguins of Madagascar.
I don't want to oversell this film. But in an era in which we've seen a lot of failed attempts to reinvent classic fantasy tales as CGI-action spectacles, it feels remarkably assured.
The film is so enamored of its own facile ironies that it fails to go anywhere with its observations.

What we mostly get in Annabelle is what we've gotten from so many other horror films: creaking floors, funky white-robed figures, home appliances that go off on their own, mysterious writing that shows up in mysterious places.
Left Behind is biblical in its silliness.
Gorgeous, occasionally evocative, but, in the end, mostly dull.
You can sense the movie's desire to break free of the demands of the rock biopic, but you can also sense it constantly being pulled back.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Certainly for any fan of Cave's, 20,000 Days on Earth makes for a creative, enthralling journey through the man's world.
Tusk is not a particularly good movie, but the vivid anxiety dream at its heart makes it one of the most personal films this writer-director has ever made.
I was quite riveted.
In a world full of cheapened, bombastic entertainment aimed at children, this modest, honest little movie feels special in its own way.
It's certainly not good. But it's not entirely dire.
It's stocked with clich√©s, but they're arranged in such weird ways that the end result is both predictable and certifiable. If only any of it actually went somewhere.
It doesn't quite transcend its own haphazard, impoverished story.
If it doesn't transcend its genre origins, I suspect it's because it doesn't want to.
This could have easily been a platitudinous, self-important mess, but Kroot does a couple of very savvy things here.
You want these people to have real challenges and messiness. But their lives don't quite feel lived in; they feel exemplary.
The real-life story behind When the Game Stands Tall sounds amazing. But for all its exciting sports scenes, the movie version falls flat as drama.

It's hard to judge films like this: The destination is often familiar and not always particularly interesting, but the ride itself isn't always so bad, especially when you've got Bill Murray along for company.
On a basic level, The King and the Mockingbird is a fun fantasy. But to the two poets who first imagined it, it must have felt like a repository for all the madness of a still-smoldering world.
It's funny, fast, and charming.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Such a crowded, colorful, more-is-not-nearly-enough aesthetic could easily have felt garish and confusing. But for some reason, it doesn't.

It's not really about bosses or office politics. Its only allegiance seems to be to the law of the sequel: It puts the same characters into a vaguely familiar situation, with diminishing, tepid returns. They should have just called it 2.
It may not be deep. But dear lord, is this movie gorgeous.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: I was impressed with how Jones's uncomfortable mixing of tones in the first half of the film gave way to something more elegiac and evocative by the end.

The mercurial Fetisov is the kind of interview subject filmmakers dream about, and Polsky knows it; the director lets their charmingly offhand relationship bleed onto the screen, flipped birds and all.
How bracing today to have a film that's at once fun, patient, romantic, and real.
As the film racks up incidents and characters and explanations, the mystery dissipates. It's a strange spectacle: a horror film that spends as much time dismantling suspense as it does building it.
One of the greatest documentaries I've ever seen.
It's fun, action-packed, and adorable.
A film you need to see again should be a film you want to see again, and the oblique beauty of Goodbye to Language, shot in 3-D, has a tractor-beam-like pull.
Laggies is far from perfect, but it gives us a world we like spending time in. And that's kind of its point.
Horns juggles a lot of balls, and admirably keeps them in the air for longer than you might expect. But it doesn't know how to bring them down gently.
[An] evocative, gorgeous, occasionally maddening film.
Ouija isn't going to redefine the horror genre, but sometimes, it's just nice to have a movie that knows what it's doing and does it well.
It's a beautiful coffee-table action movie.
The film is called Dear White People, but it might as well be called Dear Everybody. It's hilarious, and just about everyone will wince with recognition at some point in the film.
As Cole, Kristen Stewart is a good fit. In some of her more notable past roles, her tense, clipped delivery has read like disassociation from the material. But here, we get it.
Does anybody really find this crap scary anymore?
Based on an old, popular Japanese legend, it starts off like an odd little fable, but then its expansive sadness sneaks up on you.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Believe it or not, for all its additions, it's too respectful. You want it to be funnier, crazier.
Try not to think too hard about it, and Escape Plan is stupid, stupid fun.
Exquisitely produced, immaculately acted, and thoroughly uninvolving, The Secret Life of Walter Mitty is a perfect nothing of a movie.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Raid, about as pure an action film as you're ever likely to see, wants to have its cake and eat it, too. It does.
Even as it settles a bit more comfortably into its story of romantic disillusionment, The Deep Blue Sea is marked by a kind of profound stasis of choice.
Does Eddie Murphy actually have any range, or is it just an illusion created by a few early edgy roles and, later, a lot of CGI makeup and fat suits?

One wonders how the movie might have played as pure, unceasing battle scenes, allowing the combat to define the characters; with real soldiers doing the onscreen fighting, something special may well have emerged.
The bad news is that this sequel, which wants to wow us with its unrestrained, hyper-stylized, WTF-ness, is way too disposable for its own good.
It may not entirely work as a movie, but The Muppets shines as a piece of touching pop nostalgia.

Having made his name as a ferocious, self-hating Jewish skinhead in The Believer, 22-year-old Ryan Gosling gives another memorable performance as a lonely, world-hating fatherless quarterback in The Slaughter Rule.
Edgerton, a former stuntman, has genuine filmmaking chops. He can build tension up to almost comical levels, but he also has an eye for more offbeat moments.
An exhilarating experience.
Their incessant, obscene banter is meant to be endearing; their total lack of presence makes it simply annoying.

Some may sniff at director Rodrigo Pl√°'s deliberately exaggerated style, but it makes no pretensions to authenticity. Indeed, it's just audacious enough to work -- like Crash reimagined by Rod Serling.
The Argentine writer-director downplays the clinical angle and avoids easy melodramatic pitfalls.
What begins as a run-of-the-mill urban drama about two guys from Brooklyn turns into something more epic and resonant.
In the stacked-deck world of Robert Eisele's script, this team has an uncanny ability to grab the hindsight-friendly side of every issue.
Full Grown Men is a lovely, bewitching film with a lot on its mind.
A surprising little charmer, overcoming the rough edges of its low-budget origins with sharp writing and a genuinely sweet sensibility.

This is not the kind of material for a stately biopic or a political drama. This is nasty, strange business - perfect for Ferrara, whose work often hovers between art and exploitation, between angst and sleaze.

He's still a young guy, but all throughout Witness Protection I imagined Perry sitting glumly at a dressing-room mirror, like the aging Chaplin in Limelight, forlornly rubbing makeup in his face -- a tired, old clown stuck in a tired, old routine.
An immersive meditation on the unsettling power of nature, creating a world in which its human characters are but one link in a tangled natural order.
It is one of the director's better movies of recent years, even if it is occasionally maddening.
It's all strictly one-note stuff. But it's a funny note, and the film has a grand old time giving us the same type of gag over and over again.
As Charles Swan seems to become more aware of his loneliness, Charlie Sheen seems to become more protective of his Charlie Sheen-ness.
movie_title: A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Warm Bodies doesn't even have the conviction to follow through on its lame ideas, let alone its good ones. It's a mostly terrible film that misses the opportunity to be a merely mediocre one.
The good news is that the actors appear to be having fun. The bad news is that we're not.
There are holes in the plot, to be sure, but somehow we don't mind, because for all the unbearable tension of Jarecki's script, the central attraction here is the man in the arena.
