As the brutality ramps up, and the story gains real consequence, for some reason, we actually laugh harder. Goon is a comedy, often a very funny one, but you might be hesitant to call it that once you've actually seen it.
It's a cool game, to be sure, but watching someone else play it gets old after a while.
Texas Chainsaw 3D isn't exactly good, but despite its many clich√©s and generic indulgences, you want to give it some points for trying.
The effect is often profoundly moving, but you can't help but feel at times like there are other stories here you're missing.
Although it's ostensibly based on true events, The Impossible is not so much an inspiring tale of survival as it is an action flick.
These are actors due a break. Unfortunately, this comedy-drama about a kids' soccer coach boinking a bunch of desperate housewives doesn't appear to be it.
This is a cool, collected, concise film - to its detriment.
If anything, this series has gotten dumber and more inert as it has progressed, with this last one finally reaching over into an extended wallow in camp.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This is utterly disposable stuff, but it does have its moments.
It's a perfect fortune cookie of a movie, full of bland life lessons for everybody; would that there were some drama or style in it somewhere along the way.
We're still seeing things through handheld devices and built-in laptop cameras, even though nobody seems interested in looking at the footage the cameras were supposedly recording.

It mixes attempts at realism and grit with transparently Hollywoodized good guys-vs.-bad guys social melodrama. That requires a deft directorial hand, but director Daniel Barnz doesn't seem to have it.
[A] haunting, melancholy relationship drama.
Identity Thief is funny enough, but it needed to be darker, raunchier, and crazier to live up to the promise of its casting.
The Treatment is not without its flaws but its sterling cast makes it a real joy to watch.
As a story, Wah-Wah is far from perfect, but its wonderful cast brings it a complexity all too rare today.
A fascinating and sexy performance from Spanish actress Victoria Abril as Lola.
Presents a smug, self-satisfied vision of its own world.
Tackles the problem of happiness in today's world with a poetic succinctness all too rare in movies today.
movie_title: The Vertical Ray of the Sun (Mua he chieu thang dung) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Brings little new to the table.
The film is an unpretentious slice of life that allows its characters to maintain their dignity.
Even the director's most ardent admirers won't be ready for the soapy goo he delivers here.
movie_title: The Road Home (Wo de fu qin mu qin) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A full-bodied, gripping film about the nature of trauma, memory and moving on.
While director Shinji Aoyama's style is understated, meditative and deliberate, he manages to grab the viewer from the very beginning, and rarely lets go.
Aided immeasurably by the acrobatic skills of its brilliant star, Once Upon A Time in China delivers the kinetic goods.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in China (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A distracted, emotionless affair.
Strange, exhilarating.
With this wide, beautiful canvas, Winterbottom may well have produced his masterpiece.
Center of the World shows much but leaves many things unsaid. Somehow, that seems perfect.
Can't help but betray its Saturday morning origins.
Full of pleasant surprises.
Jon Reiss's script has trouble finding its footing, and the plot progresses in awkward jerks.
It's the ultimate film about losing your innocence.
Kurosawa takes a reasonably engaging thriller plot and turns it into a mesmerizing masterwork.
It may not break any new aesthetic ground, but Encounter Point might just be the most optimistic film about this conflict you'll ever see.
What starts off as a sleazy melodrama with intriguing co-star chemistry quickly gets bogged down in piled-up plot twists.
Best enjoyed by not having any expectations going in, other than knowing that [Miike will] knock your socks off.
Although some viewers will not be able to stomach so much tongue-in-cheek weirdness, those who do will have found a cult favorite to enjoy for a lifetime.
The author's devotees will probably find it fascinating; others may find it baffling.
Both exuberantly romantic and serenely melancholy, What Time Is It There? may prove to be [Tsai's] masterpiece.
movie_title: Ni na bian ji dian (What Time Is It Over There?) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to argue with the stunning lead performances by Enrico Lo Verso and Francesco Giuffrida.
Much of Happenstance comes across as a cinematic parlor game. But what a fun game it is.
Chereau's unhinged, probing camerawork, combined with the intensity of Kerry Fox and Mark Rylance's performances, makes for a near-hypnotic experience.
Consisting of little more than episodes, impressions and stock misfit characters.
The result is a very believable strip club, inhabited by cardboard-thin protagonists who come across as caricatures more than actual people.
Seems designed only to shock and depress, a film devoid of much insight or humanity.
Alternately tedious and compelling.
Has a keen sense of the pace of everyday life.
Director Tim Blake Nelson brings an invigorating sense of style to this story.
A perceptive comedy, punctuated with hilarious appearances from such notable faces as Emma Thompson and Rowan Atkinson.
An astutely written and acted study of human interaction.
This comedy overdoes the lightheartedness and in-jokes so much that the audience might not care about it all that much, either.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Challenging, to be sure, but also relentlessly entertaining.
Badly acted and humorless.
Full of predictable plot machinations.
The result is maybe more interesting than we might have expected, but it's not particularly funny.
We genuinely like watching Hough and Duhamel circling around one another, and the movie has a nice sense of place. That all eventually vanishes with a doozy of a third act.

This matter-of-fact, brick-by-brick approach to building scares and tension probably won't work for audiences who just want to scream a lot, so Gass-Donnelly undercuts it all by haphazardly tossing in jump scares of the cheapest, most predictable kind.
Deeply convoluted, and at times howlingly insane. But it knows it makes no sense. In fact, it rubs our faces in it.
Kill Your Darlings wants to be a young man's movie, but it's all "cinema du papa," as the French New Wave used to call it.
Juliet should be a girl, but the story's trajectory of self-sacrifice requires her to become a woman. Steinfeld gets the girl part exactly right, but she botches the transformation.
A borderline-experimental miasma of sexual neuroses, macho angst, regressive frenzy, and fevered paranoia.
You want the movie to get outrageous, but it's too dignified to go there. Much like its central villain, it can't decide what it wants to be.
A.C.O.D. is reasonably pleasant and therapeutic and antiseptic and you just wish somebody would bring a chandelier down on somebody else at some point.
It's all very cute and awesomely disgusting, like a 9-year-old stuffing his face full of food and then pressing his cheeks to make it all explode out. (Nine-year-olds still do that, right?)
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Paula Patton is one of those actresses who seem to light up the screen whenever they appear, but even her considerable charms can't quite make Baggage Claim tolerable.
The 13-year-old me would have loved it, and I wouldn't be lying if I said that at times the movie turned me back into that 13-year-old kid.
Battle of the Year clearly features lots of brilliant dancers, and I'd be lying if I said I didn't enjoy watching them move. But you wish there were more dancing here.
Rush satisfies our lust for both grand character combat and deadly gearhead spectacle.
Jayne Mansfield's Car isn't likely to set America's theaters on fire, but it's a powerful whisper of a film.

Insidious: Chapter 2 may be somewhat uneven, but at a certain point near the end, I realized I hadn't taken any notes during the second half. For all its weirdness, the film had utterly transported me.
Adore wants it both ways. It asks not to be judged by standards of realism, but then tries to inject realism and naturalism into its absurdist narrative.

Imagine Alien, only told from the perspective of the alien, and he's played by a movie star, and at heart he's an okay dude. A cute idea, perhaps, but kind of a wash when it comes to narrative tension.
It may be the dumbest movie released this summer.
The somber tone conflicts with the far-fetched story line, sapping it of the energy it needs to effectively sell its twists and turns.
For all its flaws, it might just be the most heartwarming movie of the year.
Maybe, in another time and place, and with different actors and a better director, it might have worked. But this thing collapses right from the get-go.
None of it is offensive, some of it's funny, and you'll gently, quietly, discreetly start checking your watch over and over again.
We keep waiting for something eye-opening, and we rarely get it. By and large, The Book Thief is serviceable, sleek, and stodgy.

The Selfish Giant never feels predictable. Credit the remarkable young actors, as well as Barnard's observant style: Every moment in this film is alive with possibility, with the chance that everything will go haywire in a new way.
You'd think it'd be hard to screw up a movie about dinosaurs, and yet Hollywood keeps doing so.
While uneven, the film is uniquely involving - right down to a final shot that will break your heart into a million pieces.
This smallest of films marks a welcome return to the world of interpersonal miniature for the writer-director. I hope he stays here a while.
I don't know, maybe it worked as theater. Onscreen, it's torture.
Everything is better this time around, but you still can't help but notice all the filler, the clumsy exposition, and graceless myth-making.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The White Reindeer is a deliberately awkward little movie, and it's a hard one to shake.

Do we even want to see a movie arguing that the work of one of the greatest artists of all time could be re-created by a dude with some mirrors and no actual ability to paint? I'm not sure. But Tim's Vermeer has more on its mind than that.
By making Statham a regretful lawman, it neutralizes his main talent, effectively neutering him. It also telegraphs the kind of mostly watered-down movie we're about to see.
Frozen is one of the few recent films to capture that classic Disney spirit.
It doesn't always work as drama, but as a musical, it's often fantastic.

The Great Beauty is a subtly daring cinematic high-wire act - an entire film built around one character's unrealized, unspecified yearning. And it might just be the most unforgettable film of the year.
Nothing quite seems to fit, as if the movie's been assembled from bits and pieces of other movies.
The Best Man Holiday is an inelegant movie, but its cast is so damn likable that we're still willing to follow them - even when they're not going anywhere.
However you cut it, with all that talent, Charlie Countryman feels like a sad, wasted opportunity.
It would make a nice supplement to the real thing, maybe a bonus disc when you purchase the Calvin & Hobbes Collection or something. But it never justifies its own existence.
There's a lot left unsaid in How I Live Now - but it's unsaid with unusual force.
Don't get too hopeful for greatness, but the damned thing works.
In the end, this is a movie that lives or dies on Johnson's performance, and luckily, the actor is perfect ...
It's hard not to feel that with this, Wong's first feature since 2007's misbegotten My Blueberry Nights, a dear old friend is finally back in the room.
You watch it and, despite all the au courant techno geekery on display, you feel like you've stepped into a time capsule. It's a nice feeling at first. If only the movie were better.
Vehicle 19 sets up a fascinating conceit for itself, and then loses interest in delivering on it. It just wants to get to the cool car chase, but by the time it does, we've stopped caring.
One of those movies that milks its stars' inherent charisma for as long as it can, but it does so mainly because it has little else.
The Purge is not subtle. But why should it be? It's not a movie about class or morality, but about the need for violence -- our own. We are the audience, after all, and we must be purged, too.
For all its humor and fleeting moments of beauty, The Kings of Summer feels like a cluster of cheap narrative devices posing as a finished film.
Leterrier also tries to pack an extraordinary amount of story and twists into a fairly ordinary running time, resulting in editing so choppy that sometimes even the easy parts are hard to follow.
For all its attempts at wonder and spectacle and play, Epic is mostly a slog.
Characters we genuinely care about are lost in a movie that almost dissipates before our very eyes.
Pleasant, if inane - helped along by a likable cast that's clearly having fun.
Was Aftershock just an elaborate ruse by writer-producer-star Eli Roth to justify an extended vacation to Chile?
For all its surface amiability, The Big Wedding might be one of the more frustrating films of the year.
As Robinson, Boseman has both physical grace and sly charm.
Jurassic Park shows us a director in transition, and the film captures his transformation in its own kind of cinematic amber.
It's not stoopid anymore, but just plain stupid.
The Croods isn't particularly smart, but it has just enough wit to keep us engaged and just enough speed to keep us from feeling restless.
The true comeback story in this fictional comeback story doesn't belong to a character named Burt Wonderstone, but to an actor named Jim Carrey.

More a dark fairy tale about vengeance than the action-packed crime thriller it purports to be, the film is at times exhilarating, bold, and beautiful -- when it's not busy being ludicrous, fragmented, and just plain stupid.
In the end, 21 and Over is more exhausting - and exhausted - than funny or wild.
Horror fiends looking for cheap thrills may be disappointed. But those with a flair for the offbeat might find themselves unnerved and riveted.
City of Bones isn't the worst of its kind, but crap served with flair is still basically crap.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Execution matters. Verve, and energy, and inventiveness matter. And Monsters University is funny, fast, and likable, with occasional moments of real visual surprise and laugh-out-loud offhand gags.
Look beyond the generic shell, and this wildly imperfect movie appears to have a rare soul lurking inside it.
As Ain't Them Bodies Saints moves along, its elliptical approach to drama goes from keeping us on our toes to dulling everything down.
Jobs is the equivalent of a feature-length slow clap.
While Kick-Ass 2 does a decent job of replicating the look and feel of the original (as well as that of the Millar comics), it doesn't have the same urgency.
The movie barely seems to hold together. Could it even be called a movie? And yet, it's captivating - a bit like Gus Van Sant's Gerry, but not as conceptually hidebound.
It's not terrible, but it still feels like a waste.
Even for those missing their Harry Potter fix, this is some weak, watered-down stuff.
The result is a loose conglomeration of jokes that never really holds together: Funny in parts, but overwhelmed by the bland emptiness where its protagonist should be.
This is what some summer movies should be like - clever in a stupid way, and stupid in a clever way.

It would be too much to say that there's a good movie somewhere inside Smurfs 2 looking to get out. But it wouldn't be too much to say that sometimes, the movie we do have tries harder than we might expect.
By proudly wearing its "otherness" (a word I use ironically) on its sleeve, The To Do List feels fresh and strange and wondrously new. It shouldn't, but it does.
No movie with this much ass-kicking should feel so lifeless.
God, where do I start?
The damned thing works you so well that you may even consider leaving halfway through, for fear you'll have a heart attack.
Turbo won't set the world of animation on fire, but it's a fun movie.
A perplexing movie that does certain things so well you can mostly forgive it for the things it doesn't. Mostly.
It makes the first movie look like The Maltese Falcon.
[Despicable] Me 2, even at its weakest, is still a charmer.
The Heat is kind of a mess, but it's a funny mess.
For all the Who's flamboyance and rock-god excess, the more fascinating story behind them may well have been that of Kit Lambert and Chris Stamp ...
Wiseman loves to let his sequences go on and on. But he also knows better than anybody just how long he can keep us engaged, and as a simple viewing experience, Ex Libris is spellbinding.
movie_title: Ex Libris: New York Public Library (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The movie doesn't exactly go anywhere. Or rather, it dithers around, and then, just as things start to get interesting, it ends.
The camera moves with purpose and grace, and the lighting is always just right. By making the horror beautiful, they dare us to watch.
Maybe it's because Jessica Williams did variations on this part as a correspondent on The Daily Show, but there's an authenticity to her that keeps everything light, honest, easygoing.
Lynskey's shivering rage and Wood's Zen incompetence play off beautifully against each other, and Blair deftly juggles the suspense, humor and social overtones of his script.
movie_title: I don't feel at home in this world anymore. (2017)

movie_review_blurb: At rare moments ... An Inconvenient Sequel gains shape and suspense. The rest of the time, it feels like a rushed journey through a vital, many-pronged debate.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard not to experience Did You Wonder Who Fired the Gun? and not get shivers up your spine - from fear, from anger, and from the beauty of Wilkerson's filmmaking.
movie_title: Did You Wonder Who Fired the Gun? (2018)

movie_review_blurb: I found A Ghost Story mostly alienating, at times even annoying.
Its vision of a world where class, cowardice, and extremism circumscribe our common humanity is devastating.
There's a lot of great filmmaking in Novitiate, but there's also quite a bit still missing.
The Salesman works well on a ground level, but everything resting atop the foundational drama slowly crumbles.

Duvivier's film kicks off in a realist register, then gradually transforms into a noirish romance of deception until finally settling into a tragic allegory of wartime collaborationism and the cruel madness of rumor, fear and and spite.
You leave the movie wanting so much more of [Fisher], it hurts.
movie_title: Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Pront plays a lot of familiar notes, but with just enough verve and variation to keep things interesting.

Cameraperson draws our attention not just to what we're seeing, but to how we're seeing it. It encourages us to wonder how a camera operator negotiates personal space in tense, intimate, emotionally fraught situations.
With each step, the film gains depth. Small variations in routine start to feel monumental, and the briefest encounter can seem like a sign of something great.
You can sense the contours of an absorbing story as writer/director/star Ben Affleck's slapdash and fragmented assemblage limps along. Most of the pieces are there, but they remain pieces.
What, exactly, is this movie trying to be?
It may well be the best film I've seen this year.
Rarely on film has the sheer debilitating exhaustion of poverty been so clearly conveyed.
This might be the best performance Salma Hayek has ever given, her quiet, observant reserve eventually giving way to bewilderment and resolve.
For all the pointy-headed geekery and technical expertise on display, 78/52 never loses sight of the fact that the Psycho scene is so important because it works so damn well, even now.
Graduation is about relatively mundane occurrences, but as Romeo is pulled further and further from his moral certainty, the film becomes incredibly gripping and unsettling.
You could build a first-world economy using the critics and viewers Malick has estranged over the years. But connect with the kineticism of Song to Song, and it might just leave you breathless.
I walked out of After the Storm wanting to be a better person - and further convinced that Hirokazu Kore-eda isn't just one of the world's best filmmakers, but one of its most indispensable artists.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Suntan pulls you into this strange man's world before slyly and slowly turning the tables. You won't like the darkness you find there.
A charming, insistent trifle, a monster movie that's unafraid to be cruel while also mining the genre's inherent silliness.
Demy is best known stateside for his wondrous musical The Umbrellas of Cherbourg, but some consider this, his debut feature, to be his best work.
Catfight never gets silly enough to edge entirely into satire -- or grounded enough to pay off our emotional engagement. Still, it works a kind of dark magic.
As pure spectacle, The Great Wall is absolutely dazzling.
Fist Fight isn't there to make you think, but to make you laugh, and it mostly does.
Kedi stands as a subtle, gentle rebuke to such politico-architectural folly.
John Wick: Chapter 2 is a somewhat more distanced affair. But it's still an impressively dizzying symphony of carnage.
The LEGO Batman Movie is funnier than you might think it has any right to be. But those of us who were expecting something more can't help but feel a twinge of disappointment.
It's a subtle but important strength of S Is for Stanley that D'Alessandro's reminiscences reflect on both the bad and the good; the movie is neither hagiography nor expos√©.
Hypnotic and eye-opening.
Stanfield is exceptional, his visage a mixture of bewilderment, humiliation, and simmering rage. His performance grounds the film, and keeps it going through its less confident patches.
Truly special, especially as it moves towards its final act, in which Yance begins to wonder about his own actions before William Jr.'s death, and how they might have contributed to the situation.
Goodman offers a ground-level, you-are-there account of the bombing and its aftermath, but he also jumps back to chart the rise of the forces that directly led to this tragedy.
For all its vivid visual imagination, the film left me almost totally cold. And I say that as a man who has cried actual tears at more than one Star Wars movie.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A sick, simmering nightmare of a movie.
It's the kind of film you can send your parents or grandparents to the next time they complain that they don't make 'em like they used to.

It's funny, joyful, and sweet, and yet down below, running beneath everything, is a sad counter-narrative about how the world always throws obstacles in your way, and how you could just turn your back and retreat.
Writer/director Daniel Ragussis tries to work a weird mixture of ridiculousness and outrage. He doesn't really succeed, but you have to admire the effort.

Older viewers will tune in to its melancholy - its battles between memory and loss, its themes of filial piety and betrayal - while younger ones will dig the more basic emotions of Kubo's epic journey.
There's a lot of charm, thought and feeling in this film version. It expands on the original without dishonoring it.
Suicide Squad is the rare superhero movie in which I actually found myself wondering about the characters' inner lives.
More than anything, this is a slice-of-life tale, whisper-thin but still full of feeling and a generous sense of place. With the world's most adorable dragon at the center of it all.
There are moments of such raw, intimate anguish in this film that you can't help but turn away.
There's a greatest-hits quality to the movie, only the band is tired and its heart isn't in it.
Riccobono films it all with intelligence, sensitivity and a feel for offhand poetry; his camera captures moments of intimacy and tension without ever quite intruding.
Fanning's controlled presence is ideal for a tale of Victorian repression. But as the film becomes one of quiet liberation, it needs more than her cool reserve.
Lovely visuals, terrific performances, renewed ambition: There's enough good in Caf√© Society to make it worth your while - and also to make you wish it were better.
We keep waiting for the love story to go somewhere, for the characters' burgeoning awareness of their repression to result in...something. Anything, really.
The Secret Life of Pets is an ADD-addled mess of a movie - and that, amazingly, is its charm.
McGregor brings depth to the role. He beautifully portrays his character's thinking: His sharp, inquisitive eyes and thin lips seem forever caught between a smile and a grimace.
The writer/director has a lot to say, but this neo-grindhouse framework isn't built for complexity. Still, the film is just bonkers enough to work.
Diligent and informative but also fragmented and inert, it plays like a series of scenes and notes for a longer, more fleshed-out movie.
Central Intelligence won't blow you out of the theater, but you might be surprised at how well it works - how genuinely funny it is - given the familiarity of this concept.
Finding Dory is one of the most devastating things Pixar has made - all while often being even bouncier than Finding Nemo.
Barry's preening self-regard and its counterpart, abject self-loathing, come across as rooted in vulnerability, inadequacy, alienation. You feel bad for this lonely guy, even as you laugh at him.
Gray, even as he pushes at the edges of what is filmable, never loses his capacity for creating moments of rapturous beauty. See this thing on the biggest screen you can find.

Fatima has its heart in the right place, but there's something dehumanizing about Faucon's approach: These characters, it seems, are too important as representational objects to ever become real people.
The 9th Life of Louis Drax excels at grabbing you with a steady stream of provocative and ornate images. But to what end, I'm still not sure.
While the spectacle is certainly there, and with it a hint of the grandeur of those earlier films, there's something empty at this movie's heart.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Nocturnal Animals, for all the refinement of its storytelling, its elegantly framed settings, feels at times like the work of a wounded teenager. But that, I think, is also partly the point.
For most of its running time, Arrival is entrancing, intimate, and moving - a sci-fi movie that looks not up at the stars but rather deep within.
Often beautiful, occasionally infuriating and always fascinating.
You know you've made some poor cinematic choices when you have to make Dan Brown characters less complex.
The feel for the epic that once gave this director's films a pop grandeur is also gone. He's made a totally anonymous movie, devoid of personality or interest.
How do you reconcile trauma like this with the easy rhythms of ordinary life? You don't, Rosi's film tells us, and to do so would be obscene.
Even those of us with a soft spot for dumb, high-concept Hollywood comedies might be outraged by the limp, unfunny nothingburger that is Keeping Up with the Joneses.
You might not see a more emotionally shattering film this year.
Full of overwhelming beauty, and ready to set the curious viewer's mind aflame.
movie_title: Voyage of Time: The IMAX Experience (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The jump scares are solid, and earned. The suspense is genuine. And Under the Shadow never loses sight of the basic human reality of mother and child, trapped at home, encircled by a variety of evils, both real and imagined.
The whole film has a drab, somnambulant rhythm. Intentional or not, this is part of its genius.
Deepwater Horizon is the most entertaining Hollywood disaster movie in years. I'm sorry - is that a terrible thing to say?
Sathe's intentions are noble, and his film is not without its moments, but it loses force as it proceeds, until it pretty much fizzles out completely.
Queen of Katwe is a true-life tale transformed into an inspirational fable. That's not novel for the movies, but in this director's hands, the results are mostly enchanting.
Lily Rabe's discomfiting performance anchors the fascinatingly uneasy comedy-drama Miss Stevens.

Stone seems genuinely interested in the slow and steady process by which Edward Snowden came to distrust the government that he worked for, and the director has made a slow and steady movie to go with it.
You marvel at the precision of its filmmaking even as it spreads an atmosphere of moral unease.
For an hour and a half, this charming little movie, with its chatty talking heads and its sweet-natured subjects, offers a glimpse into the lives of two fascinating people ...
movie_title: Harold And Lillian: A Hollywood Love Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Even though Last Men in Aleppo is mostly a ground-level, you-are-there experience, the eyes of history, and maybe even of something greater, are never far.

Alien: Covenant seethes with self-importance yet is never boring or portentous. It can't come close to matching the greatness of the first two films in the series, but at least Scott seems to understand that these movies thrive on ambition.
Del Toro might have made The Shape of Water, but Sally Hawkins owns it.
Hovers between personal drama and deep political allegory.

A sense of gnawing inadequacy is a universal feeling, and The Disaster Artist certainly mines the notion that there's a little bit of the outsider in everybody - which is exactly the kind of magnanimity you'd expect.

Maybe this little movie about a kid with a facial disorder isn't really about a kid with a facial disorder at all, but about whatever you and I choose to see in it. And if that's not art, I don't know what is.
These off-kilter rhythms actually lend the film a pleasant unpredictability. As does the humor, which often sits uneasily next to the moodiness, but is somehow fast and witty enough to work.
Hong examines the turmoil of human interaction - the pain of honesty as well as the frustration of inexpressiveness.
movie_title: On the Beach at Night Alone (Bamui haebyun-eoseo honja) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Like an emo Carrie, it probes the profound underlying sadness beneath tales of possession. It makes vivid the protagonist's loneliness and despair.
It's somber and respectful, and even has a couple of genuinely powerful moments, but none of that's enough to transcend its oppressive dreariness.

In its own weird little way, Thor: Ragnarok manages to poke fun at the constant churn of myth and entertainment of which the movie itself is a part. It's a candy-colored cage of delights, but it is a cage nevertheless - and it doesn't hide that fact.
There are few directors better than Haynes at adopting varied voices and vernaculars and then blending them to create something intoxicating and new.
Only the Brave is a visually splendid, spellbinding, and surreal movie that also happens to be an emotionally shattering, over-the-top ugly-cry for the ages.
It's a beautiful movie about unthinkable things.
Una isn't ultimately a strong enough film to do justice to its incredibly disturbing subject matter.
Careful, dutiful, and beautiful, Blade Runner 2049 cannot achieve the sublime slipperiness of Scott's masterpiece. Whether it even needs to is up to you.

Doug Liman's electric film is clear-eyed about the cynicism and corruption beneath its hero's anxious grin. It voraciously breaks down both the star and the country he has symbolized for so much of his career.
Over the course of its simple, unadorned 82 minutes, Mahamat-Saleh Haroun's Hissein Habr√©: A Chadian Tragedy wrecks you in ways you might not have known were possible.
The garish violence is still there, as is the profanity. Gone, however, is much of the creativity, the unpredictable, see-what-sticks depravity.

It makes for a supremely gripping story - filled with government secrets, meetings in dark rooms, late-night shouting matches and a race against the clock, all framed against a group of dogged professionals doing their job ...
Brad's Status remains grounded in reality - it's gentle, human and unresolved. I loved it, but I don't think I'll ever be able to watch it again.
Writer-director Rian Johnson has certainly made the busiest Star Wars film of them all, but he keeps it from becoming a slog by infusing it with humor, verve, and visual charm.
The Green Fog fairly closely follows the structure of Hitchcock's film; achieving that in itself is some sort of accomplishment. However, it's not so much an assemblage as it is a conjuring.
For most of its running time, The Student is immensely compelling, a terrifying ride between hothouse realism and dreamy metaphor.

They've managed to bring just enough anarchy and wise-assery to this beloved character to infuse him with fresh life, but without draining the material of the generosity and softness that have allowed it to endure in the first place.
The narrative might be shattered, but the film's slipstream of emotion is powerful and inescapable.
Have a Nice Day has the rough contours of an early Quentin Tarantino film with the particulars of a more arty, meditative mood piece.
movie_title: Have a Nice Day (Hao Ji Le) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Festivals like Sundance offer many films about activism and politics and human rights, but Alexandria Bombach's documentary On Her Shoulders feels decidedly different.
Mandy is heartbreaking: There's one lengthy close-up right around the middle when we see the light literally go out from Cage's eyes.
It keeps threatening to become a cringe-fest, but pulls back, as Burnham opts instead for something more human and realistic. There's a lived-in wisdom in the film.
It takes a remarkably assured artist to make all this work, and Fox is savvy about how she eases us into her complicated narrative.
The film is filled with lengthy, sensuous skateboarding scenes, which feel meditative, therapeutic; we sense that these kids skated not because it was fun, but because it helped them to survive.
It's not every day that you witness a new cinematic language being born, but watching RaMell Ross's evocatively titled documentary Hale County, This Morning, This Evening qualifies.
movie_title: Hale County This Morning, This Evening (2018)

movie_review_blurb: A claustrophobic thriller that finds fascinating ways to transcend, spiritually, its confines.
Our New President merely scratches the surface, and in its own weird way, comes to embody the plague of shallow spectacle it purports to fight against.
It might not have the genre elements that helped make Winter's Bone something of a breakout, but Leave No Trace rivets and terrifies in its own way.
What Mary and the Witch's Flower lacks in dimensionality, it makes up for in wonderment.
Alternating between immediacy and reflection, fantasy and honesty, lyricism and horror, Memories of Underdevelopment feels like it's being created before our very eyes.
Aside from being a disarming, refreshing wallow in kindness, Paddington 2 also has the benefit of being well-constructed and exceedingly well-performed.
That lived-in quality to the performances and milieu serve the film well. That combined with Hamoud's unhurried, restrained visual style allows for tension, emotion, and meaning to build together.

Phantom Thread unfolds so quietly that the questions it's asking about the nature of desire and attraction, and its delicately confrontational back and forth between Alma and Reynolds, may not register immediately.

If you can get past the spectacle of British and Australian actors portraying some of the most important figures of 20th-century American literature, Genius is a good example of a prestige pic that is not only literate but surprisingly vibrant.
What exactly does it all mean? I'm not sure, but it does make for a disturbing and occasionally absorbing watch.
Even those unfamiliar with the book might wonder why this kids-only manifestation of IT feels strangely toothless on the horror front.
It feels like a transmission from a different planet.
movie_title: To Live and Die in L.A. (1985)

movie_review_blurb: Vibrant, funny, and disturbing.
This Mummy plays like a wan assemblage of underdeveloped concepts.
A film for the ages.
The more I think about it, the more I believe it might actually be one of Akin's best.

Haneke has delivered the Haneke film that Haneke-haters see in their heads when they think of a Haneke film: a series of disjointed, narratively oblique episodes showing people being inhumane to each other.
We've got Sandler plus Stiller plus Hoffman, and somehow the result is not a comic ham salad; Baumbach and his actors deserve all the credit in the world for keeping the shtickiness to a minimum.
The character dynamics transfix ... but I was most taken with the way Coppola uses style to create meaning.
I started to wonder if the director had merely written himself into a corner and was doubling down on weirdness to get himself out. And yet the film never quite loses its mythic drive.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: We start to feel like we're drowning in atmosphere, and it gets harder and harder to stay interested in what happens next.
There's a lot to chew on here, but in the end, I wish Okja simply worked better as a movie.
√ñstlund is specific and exacting as a writer and director, and within The Square's empty spaces, we're forced to confront our own values, and our own visions of ourselves.
It's the kind of story that could easily have lent itself to a shallow, made-for-cable social history, but director Robin Campillo achieves a touching and pointed mixture of styles.
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Movies that blend real life and fiction usually foreground the docu-style realism, using the poetry as grace notes or punctuation. Zhao privileges both, and in so doing creates a work of heartbreaking beauty.
Suffice it to say that the movie's mostly enjoyable, but its ending is immortal.
movie_title: Let the Sun Shine In (Un beau soleil int√©rieur) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The connections - the stuff that will turn these individual moments into something resembling a unified cinematic experience - just aren't there.
King Arthur is neither Guy Ritchie's worst film nor his best, but it might well be his most frustrating.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: fiiigjhkwetwnwwwjsahafajhwfohofoehaoowofoeoicioeciaqidjFaerlaeaffjgjlje XGRSXSsfdsmfjjjsomuchrandomstuffsomuchegjwogpjwd
It unspools with admirable discipline and verve. This is Jolie's most accomplished work yet.
I can't say I wasn't absorbed and troubled by much of this film.
If you ever wind up in a French prison, don't smuggle in a file - just bring a DVD of this movie. It's practically a guide to breaking out.

We sense the pride these people take in this work. One of the film's most beautiful passages is a montage of different townsfolk - a teacher, a woman hanging laundry, a clerk behind a desk - practicing their lines as they go about their day.
There's a whole lot of cathartic pain in Heat and Dust, if you know where to look for it.
The Villainess is entertaining enough, but it's hard to shake the feeling that we should be caring more for this character as the film goes on, not less.

The movie's true power stems from [Cameron's] ability to tap into fears not just of mechanization and dehumanization (notions that Schwarzenegger embodies in his very persona) but also of human obsession and transformation.
How the hell does a film this tonally out there, with characters this lunkheaded and at times even cruel and hateful, manage to be so indescribably moving?

Most films about relationships on the rocks center on things like betrayal and guilt and lust. Rare is the work that tackles one of the most common and corrosive sources of conflict among couples: financial instability.
It is entertaining, and often touching, even if it pulls back right when it should be going totally nuts.
The boy is but a shell; it's the men and women around him who truly come to life in this chaotic, awkward, and sporadically moving film.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Satisfying, though ultimately forgettable.

An outwardly chilly, resolutely static film that nevertheless finds poignancy in the most surprising places, Kogonada's directorial debut does a couple of important things so well that I can't help but forgive the things it doesn't.
This unreconciled and incomplete film does an unusually good job of terrifying and unsettling us, before sending us back out into a world that's more like 1967 than we'd care to admit.
The film is boldly bad, yes, but also boldly boring.
The profound disillusionment that runs through Tragedy of a Ridiculous Man, made just a few years after the visionary, flag-waving fury of 1900, is striking.
movie_title: La tragedia di un uomo ridicolo (The Tragedy of a Ridiculous Man)(Tragedy of a Ridiculous Man) (1982)

movie_review_blurb: The nerve-racking war thriller Dunkirk is the movie Christopher Nolan's entire career has been building up to, in ways that even he may not have realized.
Valerian is at times so mind-meltingly beautiful and strange that I'm still not sure I didn't just dream it all.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Pitt's ridiculous, wildly over-the-top performance somehow keeps it all together.
Wright's movie delivers action that's convincing and concrete - the cars seem real, even when the people don't.
The effects are incredible, the action is exciting, the music is great, and Andy Serkis, once again embodying a non-human character through motion-capture technology, remains terrific.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Garrulous and good-humored, De Palma presides over Paltrow and Baumbach's film, taking us through his life and career step by step, title by title, in chronological order.

While he may have seemed like a counterintuitive choice to take over a Star Trek movie, Lin is absolutely in his element whenever the film becomes about bodies and vehicles moving swiftly through space - which is often.
Holmer films the story as if it were a dance performance, one where differences in movement and posture say more than words ever could.
A game, if ultimately futile, attempt to carry on a series whose greatest asset has departed.
The lax, lame A Walk in the Woods is a road movie without a road, a journey of self-discovery without discovery, and a tale of friendship without any chemistry.
It smartly uses its little moments of humiliation to open our eyes to a world of delicate, but deep, injustice.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's all big, dumb, broad strokes, with plot points visible from miles away. But it works where it matters: The music is fantastic, and the film invests you in its central relationship.
Takes what could have easily been a mundane tale of brotherly dysfunction and turns it into something abstract and electrifying.

She's Funny That Way often displays an old-school generosity and polish, and at least one breakout performance - but just as often, its moments of inspiration are tempered by miscasting and shrill attempts at humor.
There was a real darkness there - behind the American flags and the fringed jackets and the fireworks - and Being Evel, to its credit, isn't afraid to face it.

Nobody goes to these Fatal Attraction retreads anymore for serious drama. But this one is a movie torn - too grim and self-important to go truly nuts, but too silly and slipshod to work on a more somber level.
This sequel, as rough as it is, might be more worthwhile than its 2012 original.
There's something mythic about the story unfolding before us, but the film avoids self-importance.
The mystery itself eventually becomes tiresome and shrug-worthy, even as the film breathlessly racks up the revelations.
The Gift starts out like so many other thrillers before it - with an attractive, well-to-do couple purchasing a big new house - and then beats its own, uniquely tense and twisted path from there.
The first thing to know about The Diary of a Teenage Girl is that young British actress Powley is staggeringly good in it.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Plenty of bigger, more grown-up movies could learn a thing or two from its humanity.
There's a fundamental tonal dissonance at the heart of Fantastic Four. The awkward staging, cut-rate effects, and stilted dialogue might have worked alongside a fun, ridiculous story.
Best of Enemies leaves you with an overwhelming sense of despair. It's not just a great documentary, it's a vital one.
We know these characters are going through a lot, even if we don't always see it. And so, this short, ramshackle, shrinking movie manages to stick with you.
As Lu and Feng struggle to reconnect, and find themselves settling for the oddest of dependencies, it's hard to be unmoved.
Essentially, The Scorch Trials makes up for the humdrum YApocalypse of its first half by going a little bonkers in its second.
The Cut is a haunting movie, but there are times when one wonders whether Akin should go more for the emotional jugular, rub our faces in the monstrosity he's depicting.

There's a strange power to Sion's filmmaking that goes beyond the midnight-movie oddness of the plot. He likes the silly and the strange, but he has the style of a Spielberg; he can work wonders with a camera and make the dumbest ideas work.
If only Ghost Dimension spent more time in the ghost dimension and less time in the people dimension, we might have had something.
Watching The Last Witch Hunter is like sitting by while someone else plays a game whose coolness eludes us.
It's a cheerful, nasty delight.
Crimson Peak is a fascinating conundrum of a movie. I was close to hating it as I walked out of the theater, but images and moments from it have stayed with me.
(T)error, like the punctuation in its title suggests, goes from being a tense procedural and absorbing character study to an astonishing, real-life satire about the surveillance state.
The characters are driven by convenience, not behavior, and their actions seem like they've been manhandled into place to make the plot work.
The very idea behind Pan is ill-conceived. Who wants a prequel to Peter Pan?
The streamlined elements of the first have now given way to mind-numbing clutter.
We don't know what game these people are playing or where they're ultimately going, but we enjoy the ride while it lasts.
The Intern degenerates into a series of monologues about ambition and relationships and having it all. As the speeches pile up, our goodwill dissipates, and so does the film's magic.
In 82 svelte minutes, Finders Keepers encapsulates something ineffable about the modern American experience.
Yes, every joke in the film is low-hanging fruit, but not a single one is left unpicked.
It's a self-financed passion project, from a man who might be the most financially successful out gay filmmaker ever. We should be celebrating this, but man, oh man, does he make it difficult.
Captive winds up building to a big nothing.
Unlike many mountain-disaster stories, this is the kind that makes you never want to look at a mountain again.
At its best, this is an absorbing look at how people fall under the control of sick, sadistic hucksters.
Vacation is lazy, idiotic, and gross - and I laughed my ass off at it.

It's the rare movie that can sacrifice the clean lines of fantasy and melodrama for the messiness of ordinary life - that neither burnishes nor condemns the up-down turmoil of the teenage soul, but rather lets it be.
It's hard not to look at Pixels and feel like Sandler & Co. missed a huge opportunity here.
It's a gripping little tale, to be sure, but it's more than that. Somewhere in its tangle of timelines, false starts, and red herrings is a great truth about the unsolvable mystery of the human soul.
Aloft is ultimately a movie about our need to keep moving and searching. And at times, it's quite a lovely one.
About halfway through the film, I realized I would be way more interested in a film about the making of Human Centipede 3 than I was in Human Centipede 3. But I don't want to give Six any ideas.
When Marnie Was There may start off a bit awkwardly, but it'll have you bathing in your own tears by the time it's over.
This new Poltergeist isn't anything special ... But it's not a travesty, and that feels like cause for brief celebration.
There are three reasons to see I'll See You in My Dreams. Blythe Danner is Reason No. 1. She also happens to be Reasons Nos. 2 and 3.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: You could easily imagine these two in a sharper, edgier comedy. Maybe, if Hot Pursuit is a hit, the filmmakers can take a mulligan and reunite them for a faster, funnier sequel.
The last act of The D Train becomes a hilarious, deeply weird, and ultimately touching medley of delusion, humiliation, and friendship.

What makes it work is the solemn efficiency of director David Oelhoffen's storytelling and the quiet intensity of the two leads: The rough tenderness of Mortensen's gaze plays off well against Kateb's conflicted demeanor.
I'm not even sure it can be called a movie; it feels like a setup and a character in search of a story.
It's clear that Russell Crowe has poured his heart and soul into the historical romance The Water Diviner, his first feature as a director. If only the film were better.

The Age of Adaline has a fundamental weakness: The tepid romance is supposed to structure everything else, so the film feels disjointed - a series of good, sometimes even great scenes in search of an organizing principle.
This may be an unabashed, Disneyfied version of nature. But it's also fun, touching, and expertly assembled.

It feels like a typical action movie that's been sawed off and sanded down - its blunt edges sharpened, its soft center drained out. It's not particularly original, but it is mean, relentless, and bracing.
Nobody was expecting much from Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2, but did it have to be this unimaginative and lifeless?

It may not quite have the explosive charm of some of the classics, but Black Souls is an elegant, unsettling addition to the gangster-movie canon. Get on its unique wavelength, and you may find it transfixing.

Look, it's easy to laugh at this stuff - that's part of the game, in fact. To buy into these movies, you have to buy into the silliness. But The Longest Ride, for all its ridiculousness, comes by its emotions honestly.
How do you cast Simon Pegg in a movie and then do virtually nothing with him?
Lafleur's film is a quiet trifle that sneaks up on you, like a pleasant dream you might have and then gradually forget. Its very slightness is its greatest weapon.
Bone Tomahawk is terrifying and strange, to be sure, but it's the old-fashioned veneer that makes it beautiful.
It comes at us in choppy bursts of brilliance and dopiness. That is at once its great charm and its great curse.
It's a bro-mage to itself.
It is remarkable ... that The Stanford Prison Experiment works as well as it does, and for as long as it does.
Boulevard is a sad, hesitant little movie about a sad, hesitant little man. That may be a far cry from the Robin Williams roles we knew and loved, but it's not a bad one on which to go out.
What starts out as an interesting exploration of identity soon gives way to the uninspired, generic action flick we had feared it always was.
This isn't a nuanced, sober work. It's a film that stacks the deck ideologically, but does so with such energy and freewheeling charm that you roll with it.
The film feels like an uncomfortable hodgepodge of styles and tones - gritty and realistic when it's following Ryan, awkwardly staged when it's following Jackie.
Escobar: Paradise Lost, as promising as it often is, feels like two barely connected half-movies.
Story-wise, nothing in Glass Chin will surprise you. But stylistically, the film's got something cool going on.
The trouble is, lazy, opportunistic writing can be distracting in its own way, and there's way too much of it in Ted 2 to fully ignore.
There's a powerful austerity to Manglehorn the man's tale that Manglehorn the film itself - well-acted and touching though it often is - doesn't quite match.

Infinitely Polar Bear is a good example of how a film that looks on paper like a mess of indie clich√©s can be redeemed by fantastic performances...even if, ultimately, it remains a mess of indie clich√©s.

The film does occasionally show a pulse when it tries to re-imagine the life of the victim - when it turns the tables on the mystery and tries to become a film about love and life, instead of doom and death. But it's too little, too late, and too lame.
It toys with our pity, then it toys with our outrage, then it toys with our identification. Before we know it, we've been sucked into its wicked, all-too-human drama.
For all the talk of romance, this is a Madame Bovary that's grounded in the real - in the sounds and colors of Emma's world, in its material limitations and splendors.
It's too cursory, too frivolous to make a case for the show's importance as an American institution, even though it insists on it.
For all the despair and horror on display in A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence, you walk out of it as if on a cloud, light and hopeful.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Hungry Hearts is a troubled, troubling movie. The unrest it creates looms long after the end credits have rolled.
You sort of want to give the movie a pass. But given its distinguished forebears, Insidious: Chapter 3 doesn't quite live up to expectations.
After a while, the film feels more like a cute conceit that hasn't really been developed further. It's intriguing, and very well-acted, but empty.
It's a movie with a lot of things to say, but walking out, you feel like you're still waiting for it to say them.
In 82 svelte minutes, Finders Keepers encapsulates something ineffable about the modern American experience.
The only time I've cried more during a movie than the first time I saw The Armor of Light was probably the second time I saw The Armor of Light.
Amazingly, if awkwardly, the experiment works.
A fractured film about a fractured family, Louder Than Bombs takes a potentially tired premise and reshapes it before our eyes.
Though Sing Street is much more stylized and broad than Once, it remains true to Carney's fondness for grounded fantasy.
Glassland smartly plays off Jean's unhinged disintegration against John's tense, subdued control. In that contrast lies the power of this film.

Combines several potentially tired subgenres - the inspirational-teacher drama, the mental illness drama, and the gang thriller - but, helped immeasurably by Curtis's performance, makes something new out of them.

The experience of watching this film is one of reflective exuberance. It's a movie about people who arrive sure of themselves and depart in the quiet confidence that all they know is that they know nothing.
The movie's not bad but it doubles down on its least-interesting and potent elements at the expense of those that actually work.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's a nice movie. Not a good one, or a well-made one, or a smart one, but a nice one.
The gags are mostly puerile and uninspired - like the film was dreamed up by a bunch of tired, wired 13-year-olds; it has their insistence but little of their invention.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Midnight Special is exceptionally well acted and often quite gripping and sad.
Mostly, The Brothers Grimsby simply wants to make you laugh. And it will.
Lolo is a maternal horror film in the guise of a light romantic comedy, and therein lies much of its charm.
Many will run screaming from Knight of Cups, even as some of us are enraptured. At times, Malick almost seems to welcome this polarized response.
Eddie the Eagle tries to have it both ways with its main subject, simultaneously ridiculing and ennobling him. And, amazingly, it mostly works.
If it wasn't all CGI, I would have said I hope they saved the sets for another, better movie.
For a film that could have easily become bogged down in Sunday School reverence, or culture-war opportunism, Risen presents an intriguing, oblique approach to a Bible movie.

It's amazing how distinctive and strange Mermaid manages to be, especially given the highly derivative concept - how personal it feels, amid all the absurdist, go-for-broke humor. It deserves to be seen.
If only all blockbusters could be this exciting, engrossing, and beautiful.
The Club isn't really about molestation or politics so much as it is about the mysterious netherworld of guilt, shame, fear, and righteousness, and how those things sometimes become tangled together.
Jeremy Saulnier's Green Room is an impeccably crafted cinematic torture machine - in the best possible way.

There's nothing in Huntsman to hold its pieces together. Everybody's acting up a storm, but nobody expresses any urgency or aspiration or desire - and, what's worse, none of those great actors have been given any memorable lines.
In presenting a somewhat fictionalized version of Assaf's journey, Palestinian director Hany Abu-Assad gets the most important thing right: The Idol treats this as a story, not as history.

Sheridan's script - filled with quotable zingers, telling character details, and topical anger - comes to vivid, exciting life with that cast, in particular Bridges, who seems to have finally found another gruff, down-home type worthy of his talents.

At the center of this emotional maelstrom is the 65-year-old Braga, herself a living legend and bridge to the past. In a long film of many turns, her performance - weathered, proud, sensuous, fragile - captivates and brings us into her world.
Both a film noir and a candy-colored confection, Pedro Almod√≥var's Julieta is one of the most absorbing films he's made in years.
Personal Shopper descends into fragmentation and alienation, and not always rewardingly. It also doesn't help that Stewart's fidgety, mechanical performance indulges some of her worst acting tics.

Nichols stays true to his sensibility, avoiding the melodrama or the back-patting triumphalism you expect from such movies. Loving downplays the historical significance of its subject in favor of a quiet humanity.
Weiner is about as entertaining as a film about someone destroying a life and career can be. You can't turn away from the car wreck, and Weiner himself can't stop commenting on it.
Kids may well dig it. (Hell, my kid may well dig it.) But for me, The BFG was all anticipation of a different kind, leading to a massive letdown.
Pl√° achieves a visual style that is ice-cold but also deeply human - a clever way to depict an all-powerful system that feeds on our lives and thrives on our fallibility.
movie_title: A Monster With A Thousand Heads (Un Monstruo de Mil Cabezas) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: What makes X-Men: Apocalypse so exciting isn't really any one thing but rather its cohesion, its storytelling verve.
The most interesting part of Elstree 1976 comes when these actors express ambivalence about their odd celebrity.

Audiard has always had the heart of a genre filmmaker tempered with the eyes of a behavioralist. He gets in close to his characters - focusing on their faces, their hands, their feet - so that we feel every blow and quiver, every scream and whisper.

These films no longer have to delight and surprise us; no, their job now is to manage the brand, not screw anything up too royally, and keep us hooked for the next installment. Civil War pulls all that off mostly well.
I enjoyed it. I'm still not sure if I was supposed to.
An impressive display of stylistic control and directorial vision, even if it doesn't always hold together.
The filmmakers, by sticking to such a conventional structure, have deprived themselves of the tools to give us a real sense of Ramanujan's achievement.
Luna seduces and repels you at the same time. It's a film about the silences and cruelties between people, but it explodes with color, music, and movement.
It may start with a big burst of energy, but this is a sad, somber film about a world that's slowly, knowingly losing touch with the real.
You feel manipulated, but not in the I-can't-help-but-be-moved way that these films usually work. By the time its finale rolls around, The Choice has completely undone its own spell.
These movies were never going to transform cinema, but watching Allegiant, it's hard not to feel as if someone has pulled the rug out from under an otherwise modestly entertaining franchise.

The physicality of DiCaprio's performance is certainly impressive, as is the technical effort that clearly went into the making of the film. But as a whole, the movie arcs toward tedium; we become less involved in Glass' ordeal as he goes on.
Let Inside Out in, and it will wipe the floor with you.
Boyle does something surprising with Sorkin's endless cascades of dialogue: He turns them into music.
The Theory of Everything may not tear a rip in the cinematic space-time continuum, but as an intimate drama about two people struggling with a life they never expected, it has real power.
The surface details may be different from some of their previous films, but Two Days, One Night might be the Dardennes' masterpiece.
It's hard to do justice in words to Fury Road's nonstop, breathtaking action sequences.
There's something charming about the use of all this technology to depict what was, ultimately, a minor event.
On some level, Spectre is a betrayal of the More Serious Bond promised in Casino Royale. But it's also the first Bond film in a long time that actually lets you have fun with it.
Though often beautiful, this is an emotionally paralyzed film about emotionally paralyzed people.
A disposable genre movie that cannot scare, convince, or enlighten.
Welcome to Leith is a sober, terrifying look at the very real monsters roaming the quiet countryside.
Goodnight Mommy is a very disquieting, very suspenseful film, but proceed with caution.
It's just as often manipulative and contrived, but Jessie Nelson's film sells itself well. There's care in the details, and the characters often feel like actual people.

A marital drama filled with long, immaculately shot pauses and often tin-eared dialogue, it's perplexing and wildly imperfect. But there's something here that's quite powerful if you get on its wavelength.
What emerges is a tapestry of despair, one defined by its persistence.
The desert in Theeb feels intimate, rough, real. You can run your hands through the sand and feel the flies on your face. That realism extends to the characters as well, thankfully.
Somehow, this Peanuts feels familiar, even cozy. I can't make any great claims for it, but it feels like the return of an old friend.
The result is an enormously moving portrait of the profound way that art can transform those who come in contact with it.
he Wolfpack transcends mere social-issue concerns. It becomes a coming-of-age movie with monumental stakes -- and a strangely vibrant look at the liberating power of creativity.

The meat-and-potatoes Howard is uncomfortable in the realm of the spirit, or the metaphysical. He can film objects, and he can film people, but he can't quite film emptiness. The cosmic vastness of the sea eludes him.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The resulting film is amiable, pretty, and charming in all the right ways -- even if it ultimately settles for a fairly typical tale of a late bloomer finding his way.
It's all mostly harmless as far as these things go - lazy, sure, but harmless.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip (2015)

movie_review_blurb: I think I chuckled about three times ...
Little Men has a melancholy edge, but it's not really a depressing film. For all the despair onscreen, what remains afterwards are its luminous characterizations and big-hearted filmmaking.
The earnest enthusiasm with which Operation Avalanche begins, and the paranoia and fear toward which it proceeds, chart the course of an entire nation.
It's a lovely, deeply affecting film.
More than a movie about a slave rebellion, it's about the difficulty of reconciling the great moral chasms between thought, vision, and deed.
This is a manipulative way to tell a story, to be sure ... but it's a pointed, appropriate one in terms of this film's overall effect.
Its world is cruel and chaotic, but it unfolds with purpose and grace.

Everybody in Aferim! seems to hate and demean everyone else. And yet, they all seem like parts of the same blend of cultures - not a melting pot, but sort of a stew - that reasserts itself throughout the film.
It will probably be widely hated. But sue me; I found it is a surprisingly fun, bizarre hybrid.
It's like Lord of the Flies by way of Michael Bay, only not nearly as awesome as that sounds.
Ride Along 2, which picks up not long after the first film ended, doesn't mess much with the formula, except that everything feels more frayed and tired this time around.
It's got elements of Happy Feet, Madagascar, Despicable Me, Ice Age, and any number of other films. But most of these elements go nowhere.
Slowly ... something changes, and the functionality of Porumboui's style gives way to an ever-so-slight hint of wonder.
Any compelling sense of unease is ultimately undone as the film gradually settles for tedious schlock.

No Escape takes the casual xenophobia of something like Taken, crossbreeds it with something altogether more noxious, then asks us to kick back and enjoy the ride. We don't. We can't. And the ride isn't that great to begin with.
[A] beautiful, harrowing film.
This understated, generous film quietly sneaks up on you.
Presented as a menu of mix-and-match progressive offerings, the ideas gradually lose their power. They become little more than smug sound-bites.
Its grand intentions can't keep pace with its wordy nature, its heavy handed and blunt conversations or its story that feels more like a moebius strip than an elliptical.

It Comes at Night is not an easily watched time at the cinema, but through its perilous devastation and mood is a rewarding and valuable time, spent with your own anxiety and the lump in your throat that you try to choke down.
I'm Not Fascinating gets in and gets out with enough funny to not leave regret in its wake.

A violent romp, a mishmash of tropes and personalities, an example of what can be done when a director sits back and focuses more on the aftermath of an inciting incident than worrying about chapters or resolutions.
However good Before I Fall is at painting its portrait of a teenager in an existential crisis most severe, it is equally bad at giving way to schmaltz.
A perfect example of what is perceived as "escapism."
To fully elaborate on this summation would be to undercut the surprise and impact Fare is sure to have on unsuspecting viewers.
Burning Annie very much is a dissection and reworking of the arcs and lessons of Annie Hall, clever and introspective.
No matter what, Sylvio gave me belly laughs and evocative feels. Thus far, it is my favorite film of the year. A most disturbing year, but still.
Okja is biting with tenderness and edginess.

Don't let the many characters fool or overwhelm you, as it isn't some sort of exam for the audience. There are many details hidden and expressed directly in each shot that gives the story obsessive something to salivate over.
Kuso commits a violation far worse than gross toilet level existence; it's straight boring. A moebius strip of distasteful sickness.
There is beauty to be had in these low-budget images...Slimed is at its best when it just scratches the surface of its "message" and lets the events unravel and wash over us all.
A story that doesn't quite live up to its spirit filled images and lofty vision, but will sting no matter what? Lay off the honey, this writer says to himself.
The Florida Project is magic in the real.
Sincere in its duty but concerned in its thought, LBJ ranks as an excellent adaptation of Johnson.
Lady Bird is smoothly tender and will speak to everyone everywhere, in unexpectedly sweet and cutely funny ways, if you give it a chance to do so - which I hope you do.
The Shape of Water is a cinematic fight for that world, one that could be born out of creativity and dreaming. Out of romance. Out of the movies.

Golden Exits is a post love, post-passion and pro anti-depressant film. It is expressing its own curiosity at what it feels to be the inevitable conclusion of youth and living like there's no tomorrow.
Absolutely thoughtful, absolutely fun, absolutely funny.
[Gook] slipped on the words, but understood the music.
Foster convinces as the petrified victim turned vengeful killer and Howard is superb as the world weary detective. Together, they just about managed to save a frequently ham-fisted script.
